PERSON: Frank Lautenberg 

HEADLINE: Man in the News -- Frank Raleigh Lautenberg; 
A Known Quantity, Ready for One More Senate Run

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
Two years ago, as Frank Lautenberg was preparing to trade in his Senate seat for retirement, he was already expressing regret for his decision not to run for re-election after 18 years in Washington. "It feels lousy," he said at the time. "I'm going to miss this place."
 Apparently, he still misses it. 
 In tapping Mr. Lautenberg to fill the ballot spot occupied by Senator Robert G. Torricelli, party leaders are clearly hoping his familiar, untarnished name and his skills as a seasoned fund-raiser and advocate for Democratic causes will be an effective foil to Douglas R. Forrester, the Republican candidate, and help keep the Senate in Democratic hands. 
With a thatch of white hair and an avuncular demeanor, Mr. Lautenberg, 78, is the respected figure Democrats wanted for what they hope will be a furious 35-day campaign to keep Mr. Torricelli's seat in Democratic hands. Although he never attained the near-cult following of his Senate colleague Bill Bradley, Mr. Lautenberg was widely admired by Democrats as a liberal, hard-working legislator who championed tough environmental regulations and strict antismoking rules, including the bill that banned smoking on domestic flights and the law that raised the nation's drinking age to 21. 
"In a chaotic and confusing time, Lautenberg seems like the most reasonable choice," said David Rebovich, a professor of political science at Rider University. "He's a real trouper and a party loyalist and unlike so many politicians, he left office with quiet dignity."
And with five weeks left until the election, his name alone is worth millions. "He doesn't have to buy recognition," said State Senator Richard J. Codey, New Jersey's Democratic chairman. "People in this state know who he is." 
Frank Raleigh Lautenberg was born in 1924 in Paterson, N.J., the son of Polish and Russian immigrants. His father tried his hand as a farmer and a bartender but died when Mr. Lautenberg was 18. 
Mr. Lautenberg worked several years in a sandwich shop opened by his mother, then enlisted in the Army during World War II, serving in Europe. After returning in 1946, he attended Columbia University on the G.I. Bill of Rights and graduated with a degree in economics. In 1954, after several years of selling insurance, Mr. Lautenberg and two friends started a company called Automatic Data Processing, now known as ADP, which employs more than 20,000 people. After retiring from the company in 1982 to serve in the Senate, he returned in 2001, when he was appointed an honorary director.
With a net worth estimated at $11 million to $56 million, according to 2-year-old financial disclosure forms, Mr. Lautenberg can also be expected to reach into his own pocket to help finance a campaign that will require many millions of dollars to win.
Although he first won office in 1982 by spending $5.5 million -- most of it his own money -- on a campaign for a seat in the Senate, in later years he found the task of running for re-election onerous. When he announced his decision not to seek re-election, he cited the never-ending quest for campaign money as the main reason for his retirement.
"I did not want to sit there all those hours each day asking for money," he said at the time. 
In the end, another liberal multimillionaire, Jon S. Corzine, stepped into the breach and spent in excess of $60 million, a Senate record, to win Mr. Lautenberg's seat. 
During his years in Washington Mr. Lautenberg was known as a hard-driving senator who delivered the goods to New Jersey, including a $500 million light-rail system in Hudson County and many millions more to clean up Superfund sites across the state.
"He wasn't a Rhodes scholar type, but more like an Al D'Amato, someone who took care of business at home," said Gerald M. Pomper, who teaches political science at Rutgers University. "But unlike D'Amato, there's not much bad you could say about Lautenberg."
Party officials, however, are already quietly worrying about one potential bad thing: Mr. Lautenberg's age. Several veterans of long-ago battles could not help but note the irony of an elderly Mr. Lautenberg running against a challenger 29 years his junior. That is because it was exactly 20 years ago that Mr. Lautenberg won his first elected office by beating Representative Millicent Fenwick, who was then 72.
During that campaign, Mr. Lautenberg gained considerable traction by repeatedly questioning her "fitness" and "her ability to do the job."

SECTION: Section C; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1887 words

HEADLINE: Mystery Effect In Biotech Drug Puts ItsMaker On Defensive 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 1 

 BODY:
As director of hematology at the Hotel Dieu hospital here, Nicole Casadevall had seen such cases before. A patient in her 60's had developed pure red cell aplasia, in which the body's germ-fighting defenses go haywire and attack its own bone marrow, leaving her severely anemic and facing a lifetime of transfusions to survive.
 Dr. Casadevall knew of several diseases -- lymphoid cancer, rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus -- that could cause red cell aplasia. But this patient had none of them. Indeed, the woman had regularly been injected with a drug to stimulate the production of red blood cells while she received dialysis twice a week. Why, then, was she now unable to make any red blood cells at all? 
Four years after Dr. Casadevall began to investigate this mystery, answers remain elusive. But the pattern that she uncovered -- that her patient was just one of scores in the same condition, nearly all of whom had taken a drug made by Johnson & Johnson -- has raised doubts about not just the company but about a whole class of drugs that are a cornerstone of biotechnology. 
The Johnson & Johnson drug, Eprex, is the market-leading version of a protein known generically as erythropoietin, or EPO, that is the best-selling genetically engineered drug ever, and one of the largest-selling drugs of any kind in the world. EPO is given to patients with conditions that hamper red blood cell production -- usually people being treated for kidney problems, like dialysis patients, or for cancer.
Global sales of EPO products exceeded $13 billion last year, with Johnson & Johnson alone accounting for $3.4 billion of that. EPO drugs were the company's best-selling pharmaceutical group, providing more than 10 percent of its revenue.
It was Dr. Casadevall's work in the cloisterlike confines of the Hotel Dieu, and her publication of the results earlier this year, that alerted doctors and nurses to the problem. That alert contributed in part to increased reporting of red cell aplasia, intensifying the questions about Johnson & Johnson's drug. 
Of the 141 cases of red cell aplasia reported in EPO users, most have involved people taking Eprex in Europe, Canada and Australia. Only a handful of cases have appeared in patients using other brands of the drug, including Procrit, Johnson & Johnson's name for the EPO drug it sells in the United States.
Johnson & Johnson makes Eprex at a factory in Puerto Rico. But Procrit is produced for Johnson & Johnson at a factory in Colorado run by a competitor, Amgen, which developed the drug. Regulators and scientists seeking to explain the cases of red cell aplasia have focused on the Puerto Rico plant, and Johnson & Johnson's competitors -- mainly Amgen of Thousand Oaks, Calif., and Roche of Switzerland -- say the problem is specific to Eprex, not to their EPO drugs.
Those companies cannot help but see opportunity in the tarnishing of Eprex's reputation. Indeed, the problems with Eprex could help Amgen, which now sells a new version of EPO called Aranesp in competition with Johnson & Johnson.
Johnson & Johnson, though, contends that the handful of cases of red cell aplasia in users of its competitors' drugs are evidence that the problem, whatever it is, goes beyond Eprex. Yet J.& J., the third-largest American drug maker, is racing desperately on two fronts: to solve the mystery and to salvage its leading pharmaceutical product.
"Frankly, I'm not sure we realized when we began just how difficult and complex this would become," said Per Peterson, the chairman of pharmaceuticals research at Johnson & Johnson. "But our knowledge is evolving, and we know much more today than we did a year ago."
Dr. Peterson said the company debated whether to take Eprex off the market several times as reports of red cell aplasia multiplied, but decided not to do so, concluding that the drug's benefits far outweighed the risks. Economics, he insisted, were not a deciding factor, noting that Johnson & Johnson did not hesitate to withdraw a popular heartburn drug, Propulsid, when it was linked to dozens of deaths two years ago.
European regulators, loath to withdraw a drug that has proved valuable for hundreds of thousands of patients, have limited their response so far to recommending changes in how Eprex is administered. They have advised doctors to give it intravenously rather than through injections under the skin, noting that most cases of aplasia have been associated with injections. At the same time, they are appealing to doctors to report any new cases.
Dr. Casadevall said she agreed that Eprex should not be taken off the market. When bioengineered EPO reached the market a dozen years ago, she said, "it changed the lives" of patients with kidney disease. Because EPO is naturally produced in the kidneys, when those organs fail people often need to deal with anemia as well as receive dialysis to clean their blood.
"At long last, such patients could live without the risk of anemia," she said. "It was a revolution."
Her belief in that advance was so strong that she was at a loss to explain why her patient in 1998 was acutely anemic, despite being administered Eprex. To try to unwind the riddle, she enlisted the help of Patrick Mayeux, a biochemist at the Cochin Institute of Molecular Genetics in Paris.
Mr. Mayeux used radioactive tracers to study the patient's bone marrow, the soft tissue inside bones that produces red blood cells. He discovered antibodies that not only neutralized the red-cell-producing effect of the Eprex that the woman was taking, but also her own body's ability to replenish its red blood cell supply. Most puzzling, the production of the destructive antibodies seemed to be set in motion by the drug itself.
That unexpected conclusion was soon confirmed by a stream of new, similar cases elsewhere in Europe, Canada and Australia. In virtually all of them, patients on kidney dialysis had been injected with Eprex.
Scientists make Eprex, like other brands of bioengineered erythropoietin, by splicing the human EPO gene into hamster cells. But genetically engineered EPO is subtly different from the natural protein. In the patients with red cell aplasia, Mr. Mayeux found that antibodies treated the drug as a foreign protein -- and then did the same to the patient's natural EPO as well.
Early in 1999, after Dr. Casadevall had reviewed three cases of aplasia, she notified the pharmacological centers of Johnson & Johnson and Roche. In the meantime, reports of similar occurrences of red cell aplasia had been coming in to the drug companies from doctors and hospitals. "Perhaps at the beginning they thought it was only one or two cases," she said. "They thought it was chance, not important. But with each new case, they became more and more anxious."
Dr. Casadevall said she knew of two cases in which people who were using erythropoietin had died, though she said she did not know which brand of the protein they were being given and doubted that the deaths were related to the drugs. In most cases, patients who develop red cell aplasia are treated with transfusions or immunosuppressant drugs that neutralize the antibodies. In some cases, she said, patients undergo kidney transplants.
Dr. Peterson praised the work of Dr. Casadevall, calling it "first-rate science," adding that "she has done a tremendous service by calling attention to this problem."
Johnson & Johnson's response has taken several forms: to try to figure out why so many Eprex users have developed aplasia, to seek to shift attention to cases involving its competitors' drugs and to try to hang on to its lead in the European market.
After discovering the pattern that seemed to implicate Eprex, Johnson & Johnson reviewed the way it makes the drug at its factory in Manati, P.R. Among other changes, it reduced the amount of silicone in syringes used to inject Eprex because tiny amounts of the silicone can leak into the drug.
Johnson & Johnson also got a better grip on distribution. Because Eprex prices vary from country to country, independent dealers would buy it in cheaper countries, like Greece and Portugal, and ship it to countries with higher prices in Northern Europe. But did they keep Eprex at temperatures of 36 to 46 degrees, and protect it from light, as required? Johnson & Johnson found that one shipper did not deliver under the right conditions.
The company's troubles with Eprex were compounded last spring when J.& J. learned that the Food and Drug Administration was reviewing accusations by a former employee, Hector Arce, that he had been told to falsify data to conceal manufacturing lapses. The company denies the accusations, which Mr. Arce made in a whistle-blower lawsuit; it says he was a boiler operator not directly involved in making Eprex. The F.D.A. is still investigating.
In the meantime, Johnson & Johnson began to note red cell aplasia in patients taking competing products, including NeoRecormon, which is made by Roche, and Epogen, which is manufactured by Amgen. Dr. Peterson said Johnson & Johnson found that three people taking NeoRecormon exclusively had developed red cell aplasia. If Roche tracked reports of the condition as carefully as Johnson & Johnson did, he added, "they probably would have come in the same ballpark we have been in."
Alexander Klauser, a spokesman for Roche, disputed that. He said his company had not seen evidence to suggest the problem was with combinant EPO in general; rather, that it appears to have something to do with Eprex itself. He acknowledged red cell aplasia in one patient using only NeoRecormon, and said Roche had "no explanation" for it.
At the same time, Johnson & Johnson ordered its sales representatives to knock on doctors' doors throughout Europe to make sure that the drug was being properly stored and administered. It also wrote to doctors telling them of the difficulties that Eprex was encountering.
In an article in February in The New England Journal of Medicine, Dr. Casadevall and Mr. Mayeux professed ignorance of just how the body recognizes Eprex as a foreign protein. Despite continued research since, they can still only speculate. "The trick now is to determine the part of the molecule toward which the antibodies are directed," Dr. Casadevall said. "But it is very difficult technically."
One clue may have been in the sharp rise in reported cases of red cell aplasia in 1999. J.& J. changed the manufacturing process at the Puerto Rico plant in 1998, ending the use of a human blood protein as a stabilizer in Eprex at the request of European health officials concerned about the spread of mad cow disease.
"We clearly speculate that the removal of human serum albumin is a contributing factor to the problem facing patients," said Dr. Peterson, the Johnson & Johnson scientist.
Complicating this theory, Roche never used human blood protein as a stabilizer in its formula for NeoRecormon. Mr. Mayeux, the French scientist, said the problem might be attributable to "something in the patients themselves, some susceptibility in their immune system."
Dr. Casadevall said her first patient still relies on transfusions to survive. "She's a rather older woman with other illnesses, including diabetes," she said. "She received immunosuppressant treatment, though light, because her general health was not good. She is still not cured."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Nicole Casadevall, director of hematology at the Hotel Dieu hospital in Paris, discovered incidences of red cell aplasia in patients treated with Eprex, a best-selling bioengineered drug made by Johnson & Johnson. (Ed Alcock for The New York Times)(pg. C4)

SECTION: Section E; Column 3; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 1164 words

HEADLINE: ARTS ABROAD; 
Telling Chile's Story, Even if Chile Has Little Interest

BYLINE:  By Alan Riding 

DATELINE: PARIS Oct. 2

 BODY:
Five days after the Chilean army overthrew the elected Socialist government of President Salvador Allende Gossens on Sept. 11, 1973, Patricio Guzman was arrested by military intelligence officers. He was then interrogated in the national stadium in Santiago for two weeks before he was released and fled the country. He was lucky. While many Allende supporters were being jailed, tortured and killed, he escaped because he was "only" a documentary filmmaker.
 Yet in the nearly three decades since the coup, Mr. Guzman, a gentle-mannered man of 61, has earned a significant place in the history of Chile's failed experiment in nonviolent revolution. Through a series of documentary films, notably his monumental 270-minute "Battle of Chile," he has become a chronicler of Allende's three years in office and a collector of the bitter memories of the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, which lasted until 1990. 
 His latest film, "The Pinochet Case," which is showing at the Film Forum in New York, recounts the story of General Pinochet's unexpected arrest in London on Oct. 16, 1998, at the request of the Spanish authorities, who had charged him with genocide, terrorism and murder. It then records the 16-month legal fight until a British court approved his extradition to Spain and the British government ordered his release on grounds of ill health. 
Accompanying this reporting, however, Mr. Guzman uses the testimony of nine women -- some torture victims, others relatives of murdered or missing people -- to tell of the dictatorship. "Instead of using a voice-over to provide the background, they do that," Mr. Guzman explained in an interview in his Paris apartment. "They provide the counterpoint to the story. From journalism to memory to journalism."
The stories they tell are heart-rending. Among them were Victoria, whose son disappeared; Nelly, whose husband disappeared; Luisa, whose two sons were murdered in 1985; Cecilia, who was detained from 1981 to 1992; Ofelia, who survived torture in a house of horrors known as the Villa Grimaldi. The counterpoint of their memories are recent images of the disinterment of some of the thousands who died during the dictatorship.
At the end of the film, General Pinochet is back in Chile and, newly vulnerable after the humiliation of his experience in London, his immunity from prosecution as a senator for life is lifted and he is charged with torture and other crimes. Deemed by government doctors to be unfit to face trial, he remains under house arrest. And as if completing the circle, the movie's final image is a statue of Allende being erected in front of Moneda Palace, where he died.
But for Mr. Guzman the story is not over and perhaps never will be. It is a story fed by memories that he feels committed to keep telling even though Chile is now governed by its third elected civilian government since General Pinochet stepped down and many Chileans prefer not to look back.
"What shocks me is the lack of space for memory in Latin America," he said. "There is no great literature on repression. In Chile great writers have not spoken out with the exception of Ariel Dorfman. Movie directors turn away from the topic. Most artists feel it is a tired theme. They want to move on, to write about or cover other things. I think we'll have to wait for those who are 15 now to address this past."
Yet for the next generation, Mr. Guzman's movies will stand as a record. Indeed, when he returned to Chile in March 1971 after six years of studying cinema in Spain, his immediate thought was to record what he saw. "I sensed a different climate the moment I arrived," he recalled. "The look on people's faces, the music, the middle classes, peasants and workers in the streets, something I had never seen before in my life, a sense of fiesta so unlike Chile."
The result was a 100-minute documentary called "The First Year." But as economic conditions deteriorated in Chile, Mr. Guzman was paralyzed until he received the gift of 30 hours' worth of film stock from the French documentary maker Chris Marker. With that he resumed work with his cameraman, Jorge Muller, later murdered by the dictatorship, this time going into factories and union meetings to record what he calls "the invisible reality."
They were still at work on the morning of the coup, but Mr. Guzman had the foresight to hide everything he had filmed. And thanks to the Swedish Embassy in Santiago, he recovered his historical record four months later in Stockholm. He spent the next five years in Cuba turning it into "The Battle for Chile." "For me, the real coup was in 1979 when I finished the film," he recalled. "I suddenly had no mission and fell into a terrible crisis."
He was rescued by the search for memory, first when he made "Pre-Columbian Mexico," a television series around a Mexican village, and then in 1986 when he visited Chile for the first time since the coup to make "In the Name of God," about liberation theology under the Pinochet regime. Six years later, he returned to the subject of liberation theology, this time across Latin America, in "The Southern Cross."
"The Mexican film made me understand how a documentary can play a role in the preservation of memory," he said. "A country without documentary films is like a family without a photo album. When you see the photo, you remember your past, but the same photo also redefines your past. So there is a to and fro with memory. You return to a forgotten story, and in the process you rewrite that story."
With that in mind, then, for a film called "Chile, Obstinate Memory," Mr. Guzman returned to Chile in 1996 to trace those whom he could identify from "The Battle for Chile." "The Pinochet Case" produced a similarly powerful record. While only 9 of his 40 witnesses appear in the film, a French cable channel, Histoire, plans to broadcast the testimony of all 40 in 10 one-hour programs. Their accounts will also be published in a book.
Mr. Guzman's next project, a biography of Allende for the 30th anniversary of his death, next year, also dwells on memory. He said: "I want the memories not of political leaders, but of old people who have different memories, of people whom no one knows exist, people who retain the collective popular memory. What did Allende mean to them?"
His frustration is that Chile seems less interested in his work than the rest of the world is. His movies have never been shown on Chilean television and stay only three or four weeks in theaters. " 'Obstinate Memory' ran for four weeks in Santiago and for four months in Buenos Aires," he said. "In Santiago 'The Pinochet Case' was taken off after three weeks to make room for 'Harry Potter.' "
But his own energy seems unaffected. "I do what I do because the subjects fascinate me," he said. "I may be in a furrow, but it's not claustrophobic. Memory is a concept, but it is also an animal that enters your body. Remembering can be very powerful. It's an animal that you also have to dominate."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Patricio Guzman, Chilean documentary filmmaker, at home in Paris. (Alan Riding/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: HOUSE PROUD; 
'This Weird House': Design School for the Nervy

BYLINE:  By JULIE V. IOVINE 

 BODY:
HOMEOWNERS normally depend on contractor crews to work on their homes. Joseph Holtzman, the editor in chief of the idiosyncratic design magazine Nest, which has dwelled equally on Proust's bedroom and Farrah Fawcett memorabilia, took a different approach. He posted want ads at a dozen design schools.
 The job description was vague: students were needed "to breathe life into a showpiece house" located in a rural byway about 20 miles south of Albany, in Ghent, N.Y. No particular skills were required: applicants with enthusiasm and an inclination to debate the deeper implications of stripes versus polka dots were a plus. 
 Six students (out of 22 who applied) attended what came to be called "Camp Nest" this summer, signing on for two months of labor sweetened with a lot of creative free play. "It was like an art student's 'Real World' crossed with 'This Old House,' " Erich Nagler, 20, a junior at the Parsons School of Design in New York, said of the eight-hour days spent etching bathroom mirrors and showers in a red-and-green plaid and decorating the camp "bus," a 1984 Cadillac, with shark fins and a toothy grin. 
The two-story house was an undistinguished 1950's gabled shed, a former hunting lodge complete with walk-in freezer. In the 70's, it became the swinging weekend pad of a New York gynecologist.
Last year, Mr. Holtzman bought the house, along with five acres of woodland and several adjacent buildings, for $220,000, a purchase made possible in part by the sale of a Matisse painting that had been a gift from his father. The compound sits along the upper edge of a valley that rolls eastward toward the Berkshires. A sludgy pond on the far side of the road served as Camp Nest's modest waterfront, where the heartiest took dips after days spent elbow deep in paint and cement mix.
"I thought it would be more economical and enjoyable" to hire design students, said Mr. Holtzman, 45, whose bashful demeanor, longish flyaway hair and Mad Hatter wardrobe of many-patterned shirts lend him an air of unquenchable youth. He added, "I thought I would get more craft value and that the kids would take my direction."
The four men and two women, all in their early 20's, knew better than to expect cookouts and canoeing. As students at some of the country's more progressive design schools, including the Rhode Island School of Design and Cooper Union, they thrived on experiment. But nothing could have prepared them for immersion into the world of Mr. Holtzman, whose early issues of Nest, a quarterly, contained a story about Barbie's first dream house and a cover photograph of cat litter embellished with gold glitter.
"They wanted to know if it was a cult," said Pablo R. Garcia, a graduate student at the Princeton School of Architecture, who was the go-between for the local contractor and also the all-round recreation director. (Mr. Holtzman called him Counselor Bob.)
Unorthodox as his projects may be, Mr. Holtzman has a shrewd sense of people's attraction to eccentric aesthetics packaged with obsessive sophistication. He started Nest in 1997 with seed money from the sale of his Baltimore home. The initial circulation of 9,000 has grown to 80,000. 
Dennis Palazzolo, 22, an art student at Cooper Union, said he thought he was prepared for the adventure. Mr. Palazzolo, who wears a pair of clunky-chic glasses he made from epoxy, bone and aluminum, said, "I worked for an artist in the Hamptons the summer before on these monumental steel sculptures, and I thought that was as weird as it could get." That was before he arrived at Mr. Holtzman's work in progress.
Evi Westmore, 27, a local weaver, seamstress and jewelry maker who periodically joined the crew, said, "When I heard that there was going to be a ballroom with 40,000 balls hanging from the ceiling, I thought, 'I have to be part of this.' " Ms. Westmore was entrusted with making curtains from Mr. Holtzman's collection of original Wiener Werkstatte textiles. "It was thrilling just to handle them," said Ms. Westmore, who lined the 80-year-old fabrics from Vienna with double layers of ticking for protection. 
For all his love of the arcane, Mr. Holtzman never meant his house to be pretentious. "I want it to be a comfortable, easy house where dogs can be on the furniture, not a decorator statement," he said. "But at the same time, I want it to be a laboratory of my ideas." In this test-tube habitat, nothing was left to chance -- or left unadorned. Even the bright touches of red, blue and yellow on the exterior trim of the house are an inside allusion. "It's a Dutch-shaped house, and Dutch to me means de Stijl, so I used de Stijl colors," Mr. Holtzman said.
The camp's organization was basic. The students were paid $400 a week plus room and board. Sleeping arrangements were crude: they crashed at night on cushions in whatever rooms were not under construction. The students cooked communally (a fish-and-artichokes combo was Mr. Palazzolo's speciality, but the default meal was nachos.) On weekends they went to local diners and dives where Mr. Holtzman picked up the tab. Mr. Garcia shepherded the students through the workday and arranged field trips to MASS MoCA in North Adams, Mass., and other cultural pit stops.
Mr. Holtzman arrived from Manhattan on weekends, often with a retinue of editors, artists, photographers and antiques dealers. Conversation was constant as Mr. Holtzman weighed each design decision out loud. "Joe seemed to be making last-minute decisions," Michael Lambert, the local contractor in charge, said, "but I think he always knew what he was working toward."
The liveliest exchanges took place around bonfires built on the lawn by Mr. Nagler, a former Eagle Scout from Texas, whom Mr. Holtzman nicknamed Wilbur. There were no rounds of "Kumbaya" sung around this campfire. The campers were more likely, say, to analyze the nature of shelter, a discussion provoked when Mr. Holtzman, overheated by the flames, made a shield out of tripods and a blanket.
Down at Mario's hardware store, however, Mr. Lambert encountered local skeptics. He said: "They'd ask me, 'What are you doing with that yellow paint? Are you still down there? How long is that going to last?'
"A lot of them can't believe that anyone would think of putting stripes on the roof or painting the ridge-cap red and white. But it's brilliant the way it all holds together." 
Much of the work was grueling, like insulating the guesthouse and rebuilding a stone wall. But there was also room for free expression. John Tompkins, an architecture student at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, recalled working on the main living area, where 12,000 black and green tiles had to be laid in irregular bands. "It was a real work in progress and kind of overwhelming at first," Mr. Tompkins said. "That was when we all started to bond." The floor took several weeks to finish, with the students spending a few all-nighters listening to a dirge-pop band called Magnetic Fields. 
Mr. Holtzman encouraged the students to work out their own patterns wherever they liked. "It may have been menial labor but it never felt like it." said Mr. Palazzolo, who contributed a "blob of a tile that looked like it had melted over the field of other tiles."
After the floor was completed, and the cabinetry had been painted in crisp black-and-white optical-pop circles, the furniture arrived. Overstuffed Victorian couches and armchairs came upholstered in materials that Mr. Holtzman had custom-made in Como, Italy. One fabric is an elegantly drawn linen chintz featuring a marijuana plant. Another has line drawings of rabbits copulating, while a third has drawings of rabbits giving birth, both of cotton velvet. (The chintz is $95 a yard and the velvet $87 a yard, at www.nestproducts.com.) 
The bronze torchiers in the room came from the Andy Warhol estate. A clutch of high-backed A. W. N. Pugin chairs were designed in the 1880's for the British House of Lords. "It's all knock-around stuff," Mr. Holtzman said. "I don't want anything in here treated as if it were precious." To prove it, he invited the students to make it their dorm room. Suddenly, Camp Nest began to look more like the Nest Salon.
Painting the swimming pool took on added urgency as temperatures soared in August. But even the color palette for the pool was an experiment. The goal, Mr. Palazzolo said, was to create "a counterintuitive pool"; the standard Hockney blue wouldn't do. They considered painting it pink to suggest a gigantic gaping mouth. Mr. Holtzman hoped to achieve a deep purple, but settled for a muddy brown. Once the pool was ready, it became part of the daily ritual; the first one in signaled the end of the workday.
It wasn't all sweat and swatches. A quarry swimming hole "right out of the movies" was a favorite hangout, said Nick Delaveleye, a student at Cooper Union, who joined the group in midsummer. And when Carl Skoggard, a Nest staff writer and Mr. Holtzman's companion, returned from Berlin, there was a truly camp party, complete with a drag queen tripping out of a cake.
By August, rooms in the main house had assumed their idiosyncratic condition. One bedroom had a wall made of layers of beeswax etched with baseball diamonds, and another had cartoon-thin lines drawn around the walls to make it a "drawing of a room." By the last few weeks, the students had moved on to framing up rooms in the guesthouse (called the Rocksavage Suite, for David Rocksavage, a filmmaker and the seventh Marquess of Cholmondeley) and painting the insides of the meat locker, the future Nest archive, shocking pink. 
By September, most of the students had returned to class and were nostalgically recalling their time spent in Mr. Holztman's pattern-happy world. "He changed the way I look at things," said Mr. Nagler, who is back at Parson's. "I'm sick of the coldness and oversimplicity and the lack of interest in a lot of design today. Joe is having more fun. The places he makes are nice to be in."
In turn, Mr. Holtzman found inspiration in the students who had gathered around him. "If I can get a kid to like what I'm doing, it means everything to me," he said. But would he do Camp Nest again next summer? No. He said: "I'm not really very social. I prefer being in rooms by myself."

HEADLINE: France Telecom Names a Chief 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 2 

 BODY:
France Telecom reshuffled its board today, naming Thierry Breton, the chairman of Thomson Multimedia, to run the company and find a way to lighten its crushing $70 billion debt load.
 Board members representing labor unions and employees said that Mr. Breton, who will be both chairman and chief executive, told them he had received assurances that the French government will play a major role in any financial overhaul. The state owns 56 percent of France Telecom. 
 Last week, the French finance minister, Francis Mer, said a new chairman of France Telecom would have until the end of October to present proposals for an overhaul. But board members said Mr. Breton told them he would need about two months to sort out the group's finances and come up with a plan.
Mr. Breton, 47, comes with a track record as a turnaround artist. In five years at the helm of Thomson Multimedia, he made the company a world leader in consumer electronics through brands like RCA that are household names for Americans.
But some analysts say that only immense government aid, and not just a change of management, can right France Telecom. "If the company were not state-owned," Elie Cohen, an academic economist, told a 24-hour news channel, "it would already be in liquidation." He said France Telecom "requires serious treatment," not just "wonder workers."
Mr. Breton's name was floated as a possible new chairman almost immediately after Michel Bon, stepped down on Sept. 12, saying that France Telecom's huge losses prompted him to resign. The telecommunications company began to hemorrhage money in the second half of 2001 and ended the year with a record loss; it reported a loss of 12.2 billion euros ($11.9 billion) for the first half of 2002. 
Mr. Breton's biggest challenge will be to find 15 billion euros to pay the portion of the company's debt, about one-fifth, that comes due in 2003. To ease its cash squeeze, France Telecom cut off financing for its money-losing German wireless affiliate, MobilCom, just after Mr. Bon resigned.
But it postponed a decision on whether to raise cash by asking shareholders to buy $15 billion in new stock. Government officials do not want new stock issued because the share price is already so low -- it has shed more than four-fifths of its value since January.
Today, investors welcomed the nomination of Mr. Breton, bidding up the share price more than 10 percent, to 8.43 euros, after a similar rise Tuesday.
Mr. Breton enjoys an image of a writer and intellectual gadfly. The first of his four novels, "Softwar," published in 1984, described a subterranean war between the United States and the Soviet Union, a story some have interpreted as prefiguring the deployment of software viruses as weapons of conflict. Yet if his performance at Thomson is a guide, Mr. Breton will work quickly and thoroughly to transform France Telecom.
After arriving at Thomson in 1997, Mr. Breton sharply reduced costs and expanded revenue, in part by de-emphasizing hardware like TV sets and video players and emphasizing services like media consulting. During his tenure, hardware fell from supplying 90 percent of Thomson's revenue to just 40 percent.
After the refinancing, Mr. Breton's toughest task at France Telecom will be facing down French unions. France Telecom was carved in the 1990's out of the former telecommunications ministry, and roughly four-fifths of its 148,000 employees in France have civil service status, meaning they are almost impossible to fire or lay off.
Throwing down a gauntlet, the big, Communist CGT union said it was "out of the question to give a blank check to the management of France Telecom."
Many of France's largest unions plan joint mass demonstrations on Thursday to protest against the layoffs and loss of benefits that they foresee if more public services are privatized and exposed to market forces. The protests are expected to cripple the operations of France Telecom, as well as French electric and gas utilities, the postal service, the national rail system, the airports and Air France for the day.
Success by Mr. Breton is crucial to the conservative government of Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin, which is struggling with an economic slowdown that has eroded tax revenue and raised the cost of unemployment benefits. Mr. Raffarin wants to sell stakes in other state-owned companies to replenish the treasury. But after the turmoil at France Telecom, he will find it hard to persuade small French shareholders to invest in other privatized enterprises, analysts said.
At a meeting on Tuesday, Thomson's board voted to divide the posts of chairman and chief executive, which Mr. Breton held. The board named Frank E. Dangeard, a lawyer and former investment banker who was Mr. Breton's right-hand man at Thomson, to be chairman, and Charles Dehelly, the No. 3 under Mr. Breton, as chief executive.

HEADLINE: Footlights 

BYLINE:  By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
 Latin Beat
From West Africa the vibrant music crossed the sea, evolving and throbbing its way out of the Caribbean to New York. Here stars like Machito, Tito Puente (left) and Tito Rodriguez, joined by countless composers, arrangers and dancers, spread the joy of Latin music. Beginning Saturday, the story of salsa will be documented at the Museum of the City of New York with all manner of memorabilia. The show, "Raices: The Roots of Latin Music in New York City," through Jan. 26, is a collaboration between the museum and the nearby Raices Latin Music Museum at Boys and Girls Harbor, a Smithsonian Institution affiliate.

Getting a Life
"There never was yet an uninteresting life," wrote Mark Twain. "Inside the dullest exterior there is a drama, a comedy and a tragedy." In Hartford, the art of biography will be in the spotlight from 9:15 a.m. to 5 p.m. on Saturday, in the Wallace Stevens Theater at the Hartford Financial Services Group. The Mark Twain House will sponsor a symposium with speakers and panelists like the Pulitzer Prize-winning biographers Justin Kaplan ("Mr. Clemens and Mark Twain"), William McFeely ("Grant: A Biography") and Edmund Morris ("The Rise of Theodore Roosevelt" and "Theodore Rex").

Lost and Found
To the rising Nazi party, they were degenerate artists. As Germany struggled with runaway inflation during the Weimar Republic, a men's clothing manufacturer befriended these artists and swapped suits and coats for their self-portraits. His name was Siegbert Feldberg. In time, like many of the artists, he left Germany, taking his collection, easy to pack and deemed of lesser value by the Nazis because the works were on paper. Included were self-portraits by Max Liebermann, Kathe Kollwitz, Oskar Kokoschka (left), Erich Heckel and other late Impressionists, Expressionists and members of the New Objectivity movement. From Sunday through Dec. 8, the McMullen Museum of Art at Boston College, in Chestnut Hill, Mass., documents these artists -- many of them Jews who died in the Holocaust -- with 56 works in "Reclaiming a Lost Generation: German Self-Portraits From the Feldberg Collection, 1923-1933."

New and Bigger
The grand opening and dedication of the new University of Minnesota College of Architecture and Landscape Architecture expansion and building, designed by the acclaimed New York architect Steven Holl, is scheduled for Saturday in Minneapolis. The copper-clad and translucent glass building, Ralph Rapson Hall, bears the name of the longtime (1954-1984) head of the School of Architecture, whose modernist works include the United States embassies in Stockholm and Copenhagen and the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis.
 LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

HEADLINE: Japan Looks to Eastern Russia for Oil 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: KORSAKOV, Russia 

 BODY:
While the United States courts western Russia as a new source of non-OPEC oil, Japan is looking to the Russian Far East, ensuring that Sakhalin Island will become a major supplier of oil and gas to Japan within a decade.
 In the largest foreign direct investment in Russian history, an expected $13 billion is starting to pour into two gas and oil projects here on Sakhalin Island, a Siberian Kuwait of hydrocarbons that begins only 25 miles above Japan's northern tip. 
 "Japan seeks to diversify its energy sources away from the Middle East," said Andy C. Calitz, commercial director for the Sakhalin Energy Investment Company, a multinational oil and gas group here that is led by the Royal Dutch/Shell Group. "Japanese demand launched Alaska. Japan launched Brunei. Japan launched Australia. And Japan is going to launch Sakhalin." 
In 2003, Sakhalin Energy is to start work on a 560-mile pipeline down the island to feed gas from an offshore operation to what is to be the largest liquefied natural gas plant in the world. From an ice-free terminal a few miles east of here, tankers are to start supplying, in late 2006, a dozen gas terminals around Japan, the world's largest importer of gas by ship. Sakhalin Energy, the first energy producer on the island, has been pumping and exporting oil since 1999.
A group led by Exxon Mobil is developing a Sakhalin offshore section, with the goal of producing oil in about three years. The project's target of 250,000 barrels a day is the equivalent of 6 percent of Japan's daily oil imports. In 2006, Exxon Mobil plans to start building a gas pipeline to Japan, potentially a 1,000-mile, $16 billion undertaking.
"The Japanese see the obvious benefit of having this enormous gas station on their border," said William D. Miller, executive vice president of BP Sakhalin, a BP-led group that plans to drill its first exploratory well in 2004 in a third international block. He said that based on existing information about Sakhalin's offshore oil and gas reserves, "You can compare it to Alaska's North Slope."
With Russian companies saying they can one day supply 10 percent of American oil imports, Lukoil, the largest producer, has gone to Houston promoting a plan to build pipelines and terminals to make Russia's northwestern port of Murmansk an export outlet to the United States. Russian and American government officials and oil company executives have met at the first U.S.-Russia Commercial Energy Summit.
"There could truly be a fabulous energy linkage between the United States and Russia," said Jeffrey Valkar, director of the American Business Center, a promotion office financed by the United States government, in the island's capital, Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk.
But geography and infrastructure dictate that most of Sakhalin's oil, and virtually all of its gas, will go to Asia, largely to Japan.
An oil tanker can go from this port to Tokyo in three days, about one-third the time it takes to go to California. And Asia, eager to escape the $1.50 a barrel "Asia premium" charged by Middle East exporters, is expected to swallow up almost all of Sakhalin's oil exports in coming years. Moreover, Asia is expected to register the world's fastest growth in energy demand in this decade.
As for the gas, there are no liquefied natural gas terminals on the West Coast of North America. Shipments from here are also expected to be largely consumed by Japan, a nation whose industries already pay twice as much for gas as those in Europe and nearly four times as much as those in the United States.
"The price of energy in Japan is probably the highest in the world," Alexander N. Panov, Russia's ambassador to Japan, said in a recent news briefing in Tokyo. "With the cheap gas from Sakhalin, there will be no reason for the high cost of energy. Otherwise, Japan's economy will lose its competitiveness."
The difference in gas prices is caused largely by pipelines. There are no international gas pipelines in Asia. Plans are being drawn up for lines linking Siberian gas deposits to China and South Korea, and for the line linking Sakhalin to Japan.
With Asian countries promoting natural gas as a cleaner alternative to domestic coal or imported oil, Tatsuo Masuda, president of the Asia Pacific Energy Research Center, a regional study group financed by the Japanese government and based in Tokyo, estimated that $100 billion worth of natural gas pipelines and liquefied natural gas centers would be built in Asia in the next 15 years. To cut carbon dioxide emissions, Japan has set a goal of increasing the natural gas share of Japan's energy consumption to 20 percent in 2010 from 13 percent today. And Russia has the world's largest known natural gas reserves.
For half a century, Sakhalin was as accessible to Japanese investment as the far side of the moon. In the summer of 1945, Soviet troops expelled Japanese soldiers and settlers from the island's southern half, ending four decades of Japanese occupation. To this day, there is no World War II peace treaty between Russia and Japan. Cities in the southern part of the island are dotted with monuments to Soviet heroes who fell fighting "the samurai."
But now, with economists forecasting that Sakhalin could supply 10 percent of Japan's oil and gas imports within a decade, Japan is racing to engage its northern neighbor. Japan's newest consulate is in Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk. On Oct. 11, the foreign ministers of Japan and Russia are to meet in Moscow to pave the way for a visit by Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi to Moscow this winter.
"Almost all our oil comes from the Middle East," said Akinari Segawa, correspondent for the new bureau here of NHK, the Japanese government television network. "For security, we want to diversify. Japan has to take gas and oil from Sakhalin."
This summer, Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk's dilapidated Soviet-era air terminal was host to a steady stream of business-suited energy company executives from Tokyo and other Asian capitals. With flights from Hokkaido and Seoul increasingly booked, All Nippon Airways is considering starting a flight next spring between Tokyo and Sakhalin.
"We had visits over the summer from all our major buyers -- Japan, China, Taiwan, South Korea," said Chris Wilshaw, an executive in Tokyo with Sakhalin Energy's marketing office. "It's like the opening of the North Sea, or the Gulf of Mexico."
Security of supply is often in visitors' minds, Mr. Wilshaw said. Japan, the world's largest importer of natural gas, was unnerved in 2001 when the Tokyo Electric Power Company was unable to import natural gas for six months from Aceh, Indonesia, because of separatist violence there.
Mr. Wilshaw declined to say if any supply contracts had been signed, saying only that he thought "the market commitment" was solid enough for company executives to decide in December to go ahead with $9 billion in planned investments.
In addition to Shell, the Sakhalin group includes Mitsui & Company and the Mitsubishi Corporation. "This project is anchored in Japan," Mr. Calitz, the group's commercial director, said.
With Exxon Mobil planning to build a pipeline capable of delivering 800 million cubic feet of gas a day to Japan, the company's local unit, Exxon Neftegas Project Services, opened a marketing unit in Tokyo in late August. In the production venture, Exxon Neftegas Ltd. is the operating partner of a group that includes a Japanese company, the Sakhalin Oil and Gas Development Company, two Russian companies and an Indian company. In the pipeline venture, Exxon Mobil's partner is the Japan Sakhalin Pipeline Company, whose shareholders include the Itochu Corporation, the Marubeni Corporation and the Japan Petroleum Exploration Company.
"Diversity of supply is an important issue for energy buyers world-wide, and this pipeline would introduce an abundant, reliable and competitive source of energy for Japanese gas buyers," said Jack King, who is in charge of the new gas marketing office.
With about $2 billion scheduled to be spent on development on this island every year until the end of the decade, Sakhalin's 591,000 residents are bracing for a major boom.
"Come next summer, and we are going to hit a logjam of people -- cargo, airplanes, hotels, you name it," predicted James R. Sexton, an American business consultant who has worked here for the last decade. "It's exciting times, just like Alaska was decades ago."

HEADLINE: War, Murder and Suicide: A Year's Toll Is 1.6 Million 

BYLINE:  By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 

 BODY:
Violence kills more than 1.6 million people each year, and suicide claims almost as many lives as war and homicide combined, according to a new report by the World Health Organization that experts say is the first comprehensive documentation of the problem of global violence.
 The 346-page report, to be released Thursday in Brussels by Dr. Gro Harlem Brundtland, the director general of the health organization, reviews thousands of studies to catalog homicide, suicide and armed conflict, as well as violence against women, the elderly and children. It found that violence accounts for 14 percent of all deaths among men, and 7 percent among women. 
 The study challenges health ministers to view violence as a pressing public health problem, and its release is timed to coincide with a new campaign by the World Health Organization to promote violence-prevention efforts.
"Violence leaves no continent, no country and few communities untouched," the report says. "Although it appears everywhere, violence is not an inevitable part of the human condition, nor is it an intractable problem of modern life that cannot be overcome by human determination and ingenuity."
Violence, the study found, is tied to income; the vast majority of violence-related deaths occurred in low-income countries. Like other health problems, violence is not distributed evenly; men accounted for more than three-quarters of all homicides, with the highest rates among men ages 15 to 29.
Police statistics are a poor way of estimating violence in other nations, the study found, because in many countries victims are afraid to report violence. In South Africa, for example, a survey showed that 50 to 80 percent of victims of violence received medical treatment for an injury without going to the police.
The study found that violence against women by their male partners occurs in all countries, regardless of economic class and religion. Data from Australia, the United States, Canada, Israel and South Africa show that 40 to 70 percent of female murder victims were killed by their husbands or boyfriends. 
But the situation is not the same for male murder victims. In the United States, for instance, only 4 percent of men murdered from 1976 to 1996 were killed by their wives, ex-wives or girlfriends.
Violence, particularly war, seems to beget more violence, the study found. "It's a cycle," said Dr. Etienne Krug, the lead author of the report. "We have evidence that after wars, the levels of assault and violence remain higher than before," in part because there are more guns available, and young men have been trained to fight.
The report's main premise -- that violence can be studied as a health problem and prevented in much the same way as disease -- is not new. It originated at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in Atlanta, which in 1983 opened a violence epidemiology branch to track patterns of violence -- a move that was regarded as strange at the time.
"We were viewed as weirdos on the very fringes of public health," said Dr. Mark L. Rosenberg, a former C.D.C. official who helped lead that effort. But in the two decades since, he said, programs to prevent suicide, youth violence and child sexual abuse are now commonplace.
Though there is no definitive proof that such programs contribute to an overall decline in violence, he said, "public health measures are being applied, and a number of them have been found to be effective."
Dr. Krug said: "Violence is predictable, and therefore preventable. We can study it, just like disease, understand the causes, and act on these causes."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 14, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Oct. 3 about the decoding of the malaria parasite's genome and an unrelated graph that day comparing worldwide causes of death by violence and disease showed differing figures for annual deaths from malaria. Statistics for the disease vary widely because records are inadequate. The estimate of 2.7 million annual deaths was the upper range provided by the genome researchers. (That figure was repeated in The Week in Review on Oct. 6.) The World Health Organization gives a more conservative estimate -- 1 million dead a year, most of them children in Africa.

HEADLINE: 3 Fed Officials Say Rates Are Low Enough 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 

 BODY:
Three Federal Reserve Bank presidents said today that interest rates were low enough to keep the economy expanding through a tepid recovery.
 A 41-year low in the Fed's benchmark overnight bank rate will ensure a "plodding recovery," said Jack Guynn, president of the Federal Reserve Bank in Atlanta. 
 J. Alfred Broaddus Jr., the president of the Federal Reserve Bank in Richmond, said that people should not "expect too much from monetary policy to steer the economy." And Robert T. Parry, president of the bank in San Francisco, said the current level of interest rates would give the economy the lift it needed without inflation. 
In separate speeches today, the three Fed officials, none of whom currently vote when the Federal Open Market Committee sets rates, signaled that while business spending on new equipment needed to increase, the 11 rate reductions since the start of last year needed time to work through the economy.
"The Fed has been trying to facilitate the transition from recession to recovery by aggressively cutting the Fed funds rate," Mr. Guynn told a Rotary Club in Columbus, Ga. "Even with the current accommodative stance of monetary policy, the other thing we need right now is patience."
Mr. Guynn said he did not think that lower interest rates would cure problems like the decline in investor confidence and excess capacity, which both appear to be hampering the recovery.
The Fed will be watching, he said, to see whether businesses are investing more and whether inventories are rising to meet demand. 
"I think the most likely path over the next year or so will be one of moderate growth," Mr. Guynn said. "I realize this may not sound so great, compared to the outsized gains we witnessed in the late 1990's, but it ought to be a good bit more sustainable." 
Mr. Parry said in a speech in San Francisco that there was still "a lot of uncertainty about the strength and durability of the expansion." But he added that the current level of interest rates was appropriate and likely "to promote the economy's expansion while maintaining the favorable rates of core inflation we've seen latterly." 
While Mr. Broaddus said companies were "pretty pessimistic," he pointed to a "few glimmers of light," like a second-quarter increase in investment in software and equipment.
"All this suggests that business firms may now be positioned to loosen their purse strings a little," he said, "even if the economy continues to grow at a moderate pace." He addressed the Baltimore Security Analysts Society. 
A decline in consumer confidence, Mr. Broaddus said, has not had a "strongly negative impact on household spending." 
Mr. Guynn was less upbeat, noting that consumer spending, adjusted for inflation, had "moderated considerably." "The latest numbers," he said, "suggest that consumers are adjusting to lower expectations of real income gains." 
All three policy makers said a lack of job creation, war with Iraq and a sustained decline in stocks could further undermine the economy.

HEADLINE: New Details on Deaths of 8 Japanese Seized by North Korea 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: FUKUOKA, Japan, Oct. 2 

 BODY:
Japanese diplomats fresh from a visit to North Korea provided the first detailed accounting today of the deaths of eight of their compatriots kidnapped by the North Koreans beginning in the late 1970's.
 The diplomats said the North Korean government had also told them that a ninth missing Japanese woman was alive and had been married to an American military defector for two decades. 
 According to the account, the eight died of causes ranging from suicide to automobile accidents and heart disease. This went beyond the vague blanket explanation of "disasters and natural causes" that North Korea provided two weeks ago when Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi was visiting. 
Four additional abducted Japanese citizens found to be still living in North Korea have reportedly expressed eagerness to see their Japanese relatives, the officials said. But several have married in North Korea and have family there, and had reservations about being separated.
The new information in the 13 cases has been greeted with widespread disbelief in Japan, and appears to have aggravated the political headaches caused for Mr. Koizumi by the diplomatic breakthrough with his long-isolated neighbor. A strong initial boost in public opinion polls after his one-day meeting with the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, has since been subsumed by persistent questions about the handling of the missing persons issue.
News of the American military defector, meanwhile, provided a little more detail about a man the United States government knew to be living in North Korea.
The Japanese diplomats said North Korean officials had told them that one of the Japanese abductees, Hitomi Soga, had married Charles Robert Jenkins, of Northampton, N.C., who defected to North Korea in the 1960's. Ms. Soga was abducted from a secluded Japanese island while shopping with her mother in August 1978, and married two years later, they said. The couple have two daughters, 19 and 17, both students at the Pyongyang University of Foreign Studies. Efforts to reach the Jenkins family in North Carolina today were unsuccessful.
As for the abductees reported dead, their relatives held widely broadcast news conferences this evening angrily denouncing the North Korean explanations as lies. 
"My first impression is that the facts were hastily made up, and that they were just piling up lies," said Takuya Yokota, the younger brother of Megumi Yokota. Ms. Yokota was kidnapped in 1977 at age 13, and the North Korean authorities said she killed herself at a Pyongyang mental hospital while undergoing treatment for depression.
"This has just reaffirmed for me how horrible a country North Korea is," added Ms. Yokota's mother, Sakie.
A teenage girl in North Korea is said to be Ms. Yokota's surviving daughter, and the diplomats returned with some of the girl's hair for DNA tests.
"I don't believe it at all," said Kayoko Arimoto, whose daughter Keiko disappeared while studying in London in 1983 when she was 23. "It just can't be that they all died in disasters and so on, with their remains washed away. It's a made-up story."
North Korean authorities said Keiko Arimoto died on the same day as another of the abductees, Toru Ishioka, whom she reportedly married in Pyongyang. The simultaneous deaths fed suspicions here that the couple had been executed.
Japanese officials said today that according to North Korean authorities, the two died in a home accident in 1988, along with their young daughter. Gas from a coal heater poisoned the three while they were sleeping, the officials said. 
The controversy has presented the Japanese government with a difficult choice: whether to favor increasingly impassioned popular sentiments about the abductees, or to pursue rapprochement with North Korea, with which it has never had diplomatic relations.
Today, despite the renewed outcry over the missing persons, Mr. Koizumi vowed to proceed with his normalization efforts. "They will start as planned," he told reporters, referring to diplomatic talks scheduled for next week. "North Korea appears to have responded sincerely to the investigative team."
Mr. Koizumi has said he is determined to proceed because he believes that Japan's diplomacy can help lower tensions in one of the most heavily armed regions of the world and that it can encourage North Korea to open its economy and reconcile with its neighbors.
North Korea acknowledged the kidnappings during Mr. Koizumi's visit last month, and issued a rare apology. According to Pyongyang, the abductions were carried out in order to train North Korean spies in Japanese customs and to use the abductees' identities.
In addition to revealing the causes of death, North Korean officials told visiting Japanese diplomats that one of their country's agents had been executed for his role in the kidnappings, and that another was sentenced to 15 years in prison in 1988.

HEADLINE: Gurkenhobel: It Slices, Dices, Causes a Fuss 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BERLIN 

 BODY:
The German elite may be busy talking about damaged relations with the Bush administration after the narrow election in September, but the tabloids have moved on to the case of the Gurkenhobel -- the cucumber slicer that has caused a new set of sharp insults to fly between eastern and western Germans. 
 Thirteen years after the fall of the wall and the investment of nearly $1 trillion into the east, much still divides Ossies and Wessies, and the vitriol is never more acid than between one Ossie who has made it in the west and another who hasn't. 
 Gertraud and Helmut Weyhe, easterners, live in Johanngeorgenstadt, in Saxony, but went to a health spa in the west, in the Bavarian town of Bad Fussen. There, for 25 euros ($24.50), they bought a plastic kitchen utensil with a steel blade from Horst Giessmann, 68, the manufacturer, who sold his products from a stand. 
Once home, they didn't like their Gurkenhobel, so they mailed it back to Mr. Giessmann, who wrote them a blistering letter with their refund, misspelling their surname. Whenever he gets the rare complaint, he said, it's always from the former eastern zone. In the past, easterners would have been ecstatic to buy such an extremely valuable product "under the table." 
Now, he continued, "from the Ossies who benefited exclusively from the fall of the wall, there is a kind of complaint hysteria," so much so that businesses would contribute voluntarily to the reconstruction of the wall, "preferably twice as high." 
It was Western money to pension funds that made the Weyhes' spa stay possible, Mr. Giessmann wrote. "I recommend you go back to using your former East German scrap because you cannot cope with the demands of a valuable, high-quality product." He then said that because the box was damaged, "we are deducting 50 cents for the package." 
The press went mad with the story, especially the tabloid Bild, which got a "four-star chef," Eckard Witzigmann, to test the Gurkenhobel. "The device fulfills its purpose, but not in a particularly professional way," he said. "I'd rather use a sharp knife." 
Ossies were outraged, Wessies embarrassed. 
Mr. Giessmann finally admitted that he's an Ossie, too, having moved to Gerolzhofen, in Bavaria, after the wall fell. The mayor of the little town of 7,500, Hartmut Brauer, apologized to the Weyhes and all Ossies. "I couldn't believe that an inhabitant of my town could say something like that," Mr. Brauer said. 
Mr. Giessmann, somewhat chastened by the furor, finally told ARD television: "I'd like to apologize to the people in the east. It was not my intention to attack them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A German cucumber slicer rekindled old east-west tensions. (Victor Homola for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: More Economic Turbulence 

 BODY:
How unfortunate that Tuesday's 347-point bounce in the Dow Jones industrial average did not occur a day earlier. It might have made the third quarter slightly less painful for some investors. As it was, the quarter, which ended on Monday, was the worst for stocks since the 1987 crash, meaning that Americans will see significant declines in their retirement accounts when they receive their quarterly statements. Even with Tuesday's rebound, the Dow is still down 20 percent for the year, while the market as a whole, which resumed its losing ways yesterday, is closing in on its third consecutive year of declines. No wonder many investors are throwing in the towel. 
 A lot of uncertainty has been generated by all the talk of war, but the main reason for Wall Street's dismal performance is skepticism about the sustainability of the anemic recovery that began last year. The biggest drag is the inability of businesses to boost profits. Companies are still suffering the aftermath of the 1990's overinvestment binge. To cite one dramatic case, only 3 percent of fiber-optic cable laid by telecom companies is actually being used. Companies are now loath to spend on capital projects or workers. For his part, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, frets that excess capacity across a number of industries has deprived companies of their pricing power. 
 Until quite recently, only consumers have been upbeat. Indeed, the lowest inflation and interest rates in decades have made this a great time to be a consumer, and to some extent robust retail spending and a healthy housing market have compensated for the stagnation in the business sector. But businesses and consumers cannot indefinitely pretend to inhabit separate economies. Consumer confidence is even now beginning to fray, and is likely to continue doing so if unemployment rises further and talk of war intensifies. 
There are no easy prescriptions for jump-starting the economy, and the United States is getting little help from overseas. Europe and Japan, suffering from an even more protracted slump, continue to look to America to lead the way. This has kept the dollar relatively strong, which helps explain the nation's soaring trade deficits and adds to deflationary fears.
If it weren't for the debate over a war with Iraq, the economy would probably be the leading topic on the campaign trail. Those third-quarter retirement account statements may soon give it greater prominence.

HEADLINE: Spano Proposes 31.7% Increase In County Tax For Westchester 

BYLINE:  By WINNIE HU 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 2 

 BODY:
The Westchester County executive, Andrew J. Spano, today proposed a 31.7 percent increase in the amount the county raises through property taxes, the largest increase since 1968 and the second since Mr. Spano took office. 
 Mr. Spano, a Democrat who was first elected in 1998 and once pledged to cut the county's share of the property tax, said the increase was needed to cover the sharply rising costs of Medicaid and other state-mandated programs. But some critics have pointed to Mr. Spano's own spending increases as a contributing factor. 
 The proposal, if approved by the Westchester County Board of Legislators, would be the second-largest county property-tax increase in Westchester history. It would fall just short of the 32 percent increase in 1968 to raise money for the county's share of a newly enacted Medicaid program. 
For a typical homeowner in the county, Mr. Spano's proposal would mean an increase in the county property-tax rate to $4.59 per $1,000 of property value next year, from $3.83. Officials caution that these are average rates and that actual rates vary widely by municipality. But based on these rates, a homeowner with a house valued at $500,000 could see a tax increase of about $380 a year.
The county tax is only a share of the total property taxes on a home. Depending on the municipality, county property taxes account for 15 percent to 20 percent of the average tax bill of a homeowner. The remaining taxes pay for school districts, as well as city, town and village operations.
Several county legislators, both Democrat and Republican, said today that they were unlikely to support such a large increase. "I don't see anybody really wanting to vote for a 31 percent tax increase," said Andrea Stewart-Cousins, a Democratic legislator. "It's huge. It's horrific. I think we're all shocked looking at that."
George Oros, the Republican minority leader, accused Mr. Spano of creating a budget mess with chronic overspending and then trying to blame Albany for the problem. Mr. Oros said he would demand cuts in county programs and services rather than accept the 31 percent tax increase. "I think it's an outrage to even propose something like that," he said. 
Mr. Spano announced his tax proposal during a news conference in which he largely blamed state lawmakers and officials for passing on fiscal burdens that have crushed the county's budget of more than $1 billion. Westchester officials are projecting a budget gap of more than $100 million next year. 
"This is the perfect storm," Mr. Spano said. "This is 9/11, this is Albany sending mandates, this is the economy all coming together at one time and it has impacted everybody, but it has been exacerbated for county governments throughout New York."
For instance, Mr. Spano said, Westchester's share of Medicaid expenses alone will increase by $36.3 million next year to $207 million. In comparison, he said the cost of all county-run programs and services, including parks, the bus system and the Police Department, would amount to about $96 million. 
Mr. Spano, who was elected last year to a second four-year term, had pledged to achieve a 15 percent reduction in property taxes by the end of his first term. 
But in his first three years, his proposed cuts added up to only 7.3 percent; the actual cuts adopted by the County Legislature amounted to 8 percent. And last year, Mr. Spano proposed a 9.5 percent increase, which would have effectively erased those cuts. The Legislature adopted an increase just under 4 percent. 
Mr. Spano said that state-mandated programs would cost the county a total of $626.7 million next year. Of that amount, $46.3 million would come from operating funds left over from 2001, and $118.1 million from sales tax revenue for 2003. The proposed property-tax increase would raise the remaining $462.3 million. The tax increase would raise $111.2 million more than what was raised this year.
Mr. Spano also renewed his calls today for raising the sales tax rate by one percentage point -- an increase of 14.8 percent.
Westchester now has a 6.75 percent sales tax outside the cities of Mount Vernon, New Rochelle, White Plains and Yonkers, which impose sales taxes ranging from 7.75 percent to 8.25 percent.
Even as Mr. Spano was blaming Albany for the budget problems, Gov. George E. Pataki was seeking to defuse similar criticism from county leaders across the state. Mr. Pataki proposed new legislation today that would provide the counties, including New York City, with about $172 million in relief. 
The bill would let counties keep state Medicaid funds advanced to them in previous years that they are required to pay back. The money was originally supposed to help counties weather cash-flow problems associated with changes made to clinics for mentally ill, mentally retarded and disabled people. 
Several county executives and the Republican leader of the Senate endorsed the plan, but it was unclear if it would be acceptable to the Democratic majority in the Assembly. Campaign aides to the Democratic candidate for governor, H. Carl McCall, have charged that the property-tax crisis can be laid partly at Mr. Pataki's feet, since much of the spiraling cost of Medicaid is caused in part by new programs he and lawmakers adopted.
