LENGTH: 4682 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "RICHARD AVEDON: PORTRAITS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 5). Just eight years after the last Richard Avedon show, here's a survey of portraits. The fashion analogy is obvious: the repackaged product, a clever campaign to market the same old goods. But the show is gorgeous: a pitch-perfect mix of modest-size, big and unbelievably big prints, each an exquisitely made object. Whatever else the works might be, they are unforgettable. Celebrity only partly accounts for their status. Mr. Avedon brings other factors to bear: a sense of spectacle, clinical precision, energy, movement even in static head shots (the figures often seem so tense they look ready to jump out of the pictures) and an irrepressible attraction to power. His career dovetails with the era of the paparazzi, the tell-all media, the obligatory scandals and secret sufferings of the rich and fashionable. You might say he raised this cultural fixation to a neurotic art. The trade-off with him is always between style and substance. It's the conflict of our culture. No wonder his pictures are so embedded in our imagination. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $7 for students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* JUDY CHICAGO: "THE DINNER PARTY," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Feb. 9). This exhibition welcomes back Ms. Chicago's extravagant installation banquet of ceramic plates and handmade table runners dedicated to 39 women. A feminist landmark, it is joining the permanent collection 22 years after its first appearance at the museum. It is amazing to see. Made with the help of hundreds of volunteers from 1975 to 1979, "The Dinner Party" sums up the first stage of feminist art, reflects the late 70's rematerialization of the art object and is startlingly prescient of the art of the late 80's and 90's in its ambition to be both aggressively visual and politically charged. Despite being almost as much a part of American culture as Norman Rockwell, Walt Disney, W.P.A. murals and the AIDS quilt, it still retains much of its original revolutionary fervor. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; $3 for students and 62+ (Roberta Smith).

* "CULTIVATED LANDSCAPES: REFLECTIONS OF NATURE IN CHINESE PAINTING WITH SELECTIONS FROM THE COLLECTION OF MARIE-HELENE AND GUY WEILL," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Feb. 9). This show is basically a rotation of the permanent collection, of the kind required to protect light-sensitive silk scrolls and ink-painted album pages. But the Met has a flair for turning necessity into a virtue by reintroducing work along thematic lines and introducing fresh material to lend a sense of event. Such is the case here. At the center of the reinstallation is a group of splendid Ming and Qing dynasty paintings recently given or promised to the museum by the New York collectors Marie-Helene and Guy Weill. They are a genuine attraction in themselves and a logical link in the continuum that this museum's remarkable Chinese holdings span from beginning to end. Hours and admission: See above (Holland Cotter).

* EXPOSED: THE VICTORIAN NUDE, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 5). For the latest overview of British naughtiness, you may once again go to (where else?) Brooklyn, for this show of not very prudish Victorian art. "Exposed" has even more naked women without their pubic hair than the last Vanessa Beecroft show at the Gagosian Gallery. The naked young maidens here, shackled to a rock or draped over the oars of a ship (the boatmen bravely stare straight ahead) or riding horses or just standing there with an anaconda wrapped around their bodies are Andromeda, the Sirens, Godiva and Harmonia. The artists include Sargent, Frederic Leighton and Herbert Schmalz, whose "Faithful Unto Death" presents half a dozen or so naked damsels, loosely bound to herms, awaiting lions in the Circus Maximus. Lawrence Alma-Tadema imagines apple-flushed Victorian women soaking in a Roman plunge bath. Fortunately, the show does not stint on genuine porn. Perfume and underwear advertisers today clearly have nothing on the feisty Victorians. The show ends with works by Walter Sickert and Gwen John, artists at the turn of the last century who dispensed with the kinky fantasies of antigravitational breasts and painted what they really saw. From Alma-Tadema to Ms. Beecroft and cold cream commercials. From John and Sickert to Lucian Freud, who could never be confused with Herbert Schmalz. Hours and admissions: See above (Kimmelman)

* "FACING THE MASK" and "RECENT ACQUISITIONS: SELECTIONS FROM THE PERMANENT COLLECTION," Museum for African Art, third floor, 36-01 43rd Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-7700 (through March 2). The Museum for African Art, formerly of SoHo, makes the leap to a new home in Long Island City, with a very beautiful if surveyish show, "Facing the Mask," which happens to be all about moving. Some of the moving is physical, some psychological and spiritual, and it is embodied in more than 70 stunning masks, no two alike, from across sub-Saharan Africa. Some were used for popular entertainment; others were moral forces incarnate. Their purpose was transport, and they are supplemented by films of masquerades in action. Also on view is a selection of work from the museum's still small but growing permanent collection. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 65+ (Cotter).

* "POUSSIN, CLAUDE AND THEIR WORLD: 17TH-CENTURY FRENCH DRAWINGS FROM THE ECOLE DES BEAUX-ARTS, PARIS," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Dec. 1). Over the centuries the Ecole des Beaux-Arts, the world's oldest surviving art school (founded in 1648), assembled an enormous collection of works to instruct its students in the discipline of drawing, which it considered paramount to their training. Among the holdings, those from the 17th century, the great age of Nicolas Poussin and Claude Lorrain, are especially outstanding. The 71 on display here survey French drawing from 1620 to 1680, when Classicism came to French art, aiming to restore High Renaissance ideals of clarity, order and balance with the Italian painter Raphael as a revered model. The show's emphasis is on the works of Poussin (1594-1665) and Claude (1604-1682), a history painter and a landscapist. But lesser-known masters like Simon Vouet, Eustache Le Sueur and Charles Le Brun are also included. Wicked doings in the Bible, sex in mythology, the ordered schematics of French architecture and the pomp and circumstance of the French court are some of the subjects covered by these drawings, which should send any aficionado to the Frick on the run. Hours and admissions: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; students and 62+, $5 (Grace Glueck).

* "BILL VIOLA: GOING FORTH BY DAY," Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 12). An ambitious meditation on the epic themes of human existence, this frescolike video installation consists of five panels, shot using the latest technology and projected simultaneously on the walls of one huge gallery. Each of the panels deals with a specific theme: rebirth, journey through life, disaster, death and resurrection. Inspired by the works of Renaissance painters like Giotto and Luca Signorelli, it relates as much to still painting as it does to the moving images of cinema and television. For one, except for a few scenes, the action is almost in slow motion, suggesting the stasis of looking at paintings and allowing the viewer to shift attention from panel to panel without losing focus. The liveliest scene is "The Deluge," in which a series of ordinary street events occurs before the facade of a Classical-looking house. They are interrupted by a tumultuous flood pouring out of the building's apertures that sends people running for their lives. The work was mostly shot before the Sept. 11 disaster, but is amazingly prophetic of it. If some of the imagery is corny, it is still a deeply felt and provocative piece of work. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $9, students and 65+ (Glueck).

* "WINOGRAND 1964," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 860-1777 (through Dec. 1). In 1964 the photographer Garry Winogrand crisscrossed America in a slow, black 1957 two-door Ford Fairlaine, taking nearly 20,000 photographs along the way. Here are around 150 of them, most of them never shown before. Some are not terrific. Winogrand was a hit-and-miss artist, and the show could have been edited. But others are great, and together they make a fresh, divinely eccentric portrait of America after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. The resonance with 9/11, though obvious, goes unstated. A poor skeptic, Winogrand clearly saw the fragility and the preciousness of what binds people together. Many of the pictures seem fragile, too: they're fleeting stories sometimes so provisional as to be barely coherent, irreducible, like life, to a simple message. They record the effects of new places -- airports, malls, suburbia -- that Winogrand recognized before other photographers, along with the peculiar new rituals they inspired. Winogrand captured how America once again transformed catastrophe into commerce, an inevitable but also strangely redemptive process. Hours and admission: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $9; $6, students and 62+ (Kimmelman).

Galleries: Uptown

GEORGE BASELITZ, "Paintings and Drawings From the 1960's," Zwirner & Wirth, 32 East 69th Street, (212) 517-8677 (through Nov. 2). Before this German Neo-Expressionist started turning his canvases upside down, he made earthy, saturnine paintings and drawings right side up. His gnarly, muddy pictures from the 60's of people and animals have an evocative, primordial quality and sometimes, as in a small ink portrait of a bare-chested Antonin Artaud, a strange delicacy. His new, sketchy and thinly painted upside-down canvases based on Soviet Social Realist images from the 1930's, through tomorrow at PaceWildenstein (534 West 25th Street, Chelsea) are more interesting conceptually than visually (Ken Johnson).

MARKUS LUPERTZ, "Semiramis," Knoedler, 19 East 70th Street, (212) 794-0550 (through Nov. 16). Titled after the Babylonian Queen Semiramis, creator of the legendary Hanging Gardens, Mr. Lupertz's paintings, in which rectangles of florid, clotted Abstract Expressionist painting are set off within internal borders, might be a meditation on beauty and decadence. Superficially, these medium-size canvases by the head of the Dusseldorf Academy of Art resemble the paintings of Howard Hodgkin, but they are animated more by oblique irony than by lyrical hedonism (Johnson).

Galleries: 57th Street

TOLAND GRINNELL, "A Mobile Home and Other Necessities," Mary Boone Gallery, 745 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 752-2929 (through Oct. 19). This artist goes to even greater lengths than usual to state the obvious, handmaking a 31-piece suite of luggage that has all the comforts of the most luxurious Upper East Side co-op apartment to remind us that we live in an era of material excess. The works have an empty-headed muscle-bound perfection in which message is overwhelmed by medium. But the impeccable pale yellow caning with forest green leather trim should be optioned by Vuitton or Hermes pronto (Smith).

* "THE HEAVENLY TREE GROWS DOWNWARD: SELECTED WORKS BY HARRY SMITH, PHILIP TAAFFE AND FRED TOMASELLI," James Cohan Gallery, 41 West 57th Street, (212) 755-7171 (through Oct. 19). Smith (1923-1991) is best known for his archival recording project "Anthology of American Folk Music." But he was also a filmmaker and an inventive painter. Some of his paintings and early films are shown here, and they reflect his many interests, from alchemy and psychoactive drugs to jazz and modernist art. He is joined in this show by two fine contemporary painters, Mr. Taaffe and Mr. Tomaselli, who admire his work and, in different ways, share his sensibility. Mr. Taaffe's contribution adds up to a laboratory of new ideas; Mr. Tomaselli shows some of his best collage-paintings to date (Cotter).

SOL LeWITT, "New Wall Drawings," PaceWildenstein Gallery, 32 East 57th Street, (212) 421-3292 (through Oct. 12). For Mr. LeWitt, a white wall is a challenge, like a bare stage to a choreographer. At PaceWildenstein he has attacked the pristine walls with bold onslaughts of color, orchestrating red, yellow, blue, purple, orange and green into six continuous geometric drawings that form a spectacular color environment. The most dazzling runs more than 58 feet and is 12 feet high. It consists of bars of different lengths and colors played off against one another lengthwise, crosswise and diagonally on a ground of vivid red. A contrapuntal romp (Glueck).

Galleries: SoHo

* KAFFE FASSETT, "Pattern as Obsession," Luise Ross, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 343-2161 (through Oct. 26) Notwithstanding the exhibition's title, this London artist is less obsessed than delightfully inventive in using the domestic arts of knitting, needlepoint, rug hooking and sewing to produce colorful, optically absorbing essays in patternmaking. A funky, folk-art-like quality is belied by the sophisticated play with harmony and dissonance (Johnson).

* 25TH ANNIVERSARY BENEFIT SELECTIONS EXHIBITION, the Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166 (through Oct. 26). Nearly 400 drawings by artists who have previously exhibited at this valuable institution over the last 25 years create an initial impression of wondrous creative fertility. With extended looking, one starts to feel a certain leveling decorousness, but there are intriguing oddities, like Stavit Allweis's picture of a wild-eyed girl in a pool of water, a kind of surrealistic fairy painting (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

WILLIE COLE, "Before and After," Alexander & Bonin, 132 10th Avenue, at 18th Street, (212) 367-7474 (through Oct. 12). Mr. Cole continues to toy subversively with icons of Western culture: the Virgin as a suicide bomber; the Last Supper as a gathering of gun-toting terrorists; photographs of old irons that resemble African masks; bicycles reconstructed to resemble Cubist spins on African antelope sculptures; a pool table reduced to the cruciform intersection of green-felt gutters (Johnson)

WILL COTTON, Mary Boone Gallery, 541 West 24th Street, (212) 752-2929 (through Oct. 19). With a dry, thin touch, Mr. Cotton continues to paint giant images of supersweet desserts, like flans in a lake of syrup, that are more repulsive than mouth-watering. His project might be a comment on a culture of instantaneous gratification. Now he has added to the mix nubile young women, naked or in underwear. Dusted with sugar, drenched in chocolate or smeared with frosting, these misty dream girls loll about in hypoglycemic dazes (Johnson).

* FERUS, Gagosian Gallery, 555 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 741-1111 (through Oct. 19). A tribute to the life, times and art of Ferus, the farsighted gallery that was arguably the point of origin of the Los Angeles art scene but that also reflected its artistic moment -- the fertile decade from 1957 to 1967 -- as fully as any New York gallery. Major works by Ed Ruscha, Frank Stella, Ellsworth Kelly, Billy Al Bengston, Robert Irwin, Larry Bell and Jay DeFeo and others make the show a museum-caliber treat (Smith).

* MICHAEL HURSON, Paula Cooper Gallery, 521 West 21st Street, (212) 255-1105 (through Oct. 12). At the heart of this show are seven drawings done from a reproduction of Seurat's painting "Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte." They reiterate the painting's gliding figures and majestic recession of space, while replacing its seamless surface with the quirky, slightly anxious, multitextured intimacy that Mr. Hurson has developed over the years and puts to excellent use here (Smith).

* ROBERT MELEE, "You Me and Her," Andrew Kreps Gallery, 516 West 20th Street, (212) 741-8849 (through Oct. 12). Picasso had his wives and lovers. William Wegman has his Weimaraners. Mr. Melee has his mother. She is the muse of his current show and, as always, an arresting presence: past middle age, partial to Phyllis Diller wigs, Alice Cooper eyeliner and alcohol, she is the subject of photographs and videos notable for their mingling of affection and aggression. They exist in some transcendently abject universe where inhibitions and animosities fall where they may, where perversity is pleasure and decay a kind of innocence. You may not want to live there, but you won't forget your visit in a hurry (Cotter).

"THE MICROWAVE," Cristinerose/Josee Bienvenu, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 206-0297 (through Oct. 19). "Words have become the disease of the information era," announces the oracular publicity release for this intriguing 11-artist group exhibition. Be that as it may, most of the participants play at transforming the textual into the visual. The ghosts of film subtitles haunt Stefana McClure's minimalist color fields; Stephen Sollins whites out words from television schedules; Marco Maggi constructs miniature architectural models by cutting into reams of typing paper; and Jacob El Hanani draws allover fields of eye-strainingly fine abstract calligraphy (Johnson).

JOAN MITCHELL, HORACE BRISTOL, Robert Miller Gallery, 524 West 26th Street, (212) 366-4774 (through Oct. 12). A selection of works from four decades by the estimable Abstract Expressionist Joan Mitchell includes some especially fine, sensuously gnarly examples from the late 1950's and early 60's. Bristol, an early Life magazine staff photographer, made photographs for the Navy in the 1940's. His clean, romantic, sepia images of planes parked on aircraft carriers or flying in formation and group portraits of sailors on and off the job look more like film stills than journalistic documents. They have an odd resonance now in a time of war anxiety and patriotic agitation (Johnson).

YOSHIYUKI MIURA, Von Lintel Gallery, 555 West 25th Street, (212) 242-0599 (through Oct. 12). Using industrial materials, Mr. Miura makes sculptures as visually gripping as they are physically seductive. The centerpiece here is a circular work consisting of hundreds of vertical steel rods, each with a golden bronze tip, which grow taller as they progress concentrically from the center. The geometric order gives way to shifting, optically pulsating patterns of radiating, glinting gold dots and vibrating black verticals (Johnson).

ANTONIO PETRACCA, "Forecast: Sunny and Clear, High in the Low 80's," Kim Foster, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 229-0044 (through Oct. 12). Rendering cropped, snapshot images of the twin towers, construction cranes and ground zero workers with a fine eye for light and a soft yet exacting touch, this Battery Park City painter has produced a low-key meditation on 9/11 (Johnson).

ELLIOTT PUCKETTE, Paul Kasmin, 293 10th Avenue, at 27th Street, (212) 563-4474 (through Oct. 12). Ms. Puckette continues to work with her trademark device of crisp, tapering white lines that suggest improvisations by an 18th-century engraver. The whiplash calligraphy is cut with a razor into blotchy, watery fields of gray or a single color painted on wooden panels, but it gives the impression of floating in front of atmospheric space as though it were painted on glass. The play between surface and depth is appealing, in part because it seems so ripe for further complication and development (Johnson).

* JULIA SCHER, "Security by Julia XLV: Security Landscapes"; RICKY SWALLOW, "Tomorrow in Common," Andrea Rosen Gallery, 525 West 24th Street, (212) 627-6000 (through Oct. 12). Ms. Scher's latest installation is like a prison camp in a zany parallel universe. Within a spiral, cyclone fence structure, lights flash, overhead fans spin, computer-driven monitors track viewer movements and speakers broadcast peculiar announcements in a woman's voice: "Your sensate probes are being measured now." Mr. Swallow's remarkable carved wood sculptures -- a tire, a down sleeping bag -- look like actual objects that were turned to wood by a sorcerer (Johnson).

Other Galleries

KAREN BARTH, Cheryl Pelavin, 13 Jay Street, TriBeCa, (212) 925-9424 (through Oct. 12). Ms. Barth squeegees, smears, puddles and otherwise manipulates paint into lush, layered abstractions. At once spacey and sensuously material, they call to mind Gerhard Richter's abstract paintings but they are unambiguously romantic (Johnson).

* "BETWEEN WORD AND IMAGE: MODERN IRANIAN VISUAL CULTURE," Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780 (through Dec. 7). This no-frills exhibition is about the dynamics of cultural borrowing, the inseparability of art and politics, and the interplay of modernism and Islamicism. It begins with painting and sculptures from the 1960's in which Western styles and Iranian themes merge. It continues with riveting photographs documenting the arrival of the Iranian Revolution in 1979. And it concludes with art that the revolution produced: political posters inspired by both the Western counterculture and militant Islamic ideology. Depending on the amount of synthetic thinking you're willing to do, the results can seem richly layered, or disjointed and undercooked. But the materials and the ideas on display are fascinating (Cotter).

Last Chance

ANN CRAVEN, Klemens Gasser & Tanja Grunert Inc., 524 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 807-9494 (through tomorrow). At first glance you might think Ms. Craven's paintings take off rather prettily on real creatures. But no, these deer and birds are fakey simulacra, the kinds of wildlife found on greeting cards and kitschy calendars. The deer, or dear, as Ms. Craven prefers to call them, pose fetchingly in green grass; the birds, of mixed ancestry and shrill plumage, perch on branches against blurry floral backgrounds. But this sprightly, deliberately slick artificial aviary goes on too long. After all, there isn't much new in the story of kitsch befouling nature (Glueck).

* MATT MARELLO, "The Pollock Project," Pierogi, 177 North Ninth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 599-2144 (through Monday). This wry yet mythically resonant meditation on the cult of the Dionysian artist features video projections in which the artist has digitally inserted himself into clips of Jackson Pollock painting, the Led Zepplin percussionist John Bonham drumming and the action-movie star Bruce Lee performing with nunchakus. A fourth shows the view from a car driving at night. Actual drumsticks, nunchaku sticks and a paintbrush, all carved from wood found near the site of Pollock's fatal car crash, are displayed in a vitrine like sacred relics (Johnson).

ALIX PEARLSTEIN, "Episode," Artemis Greenberg Van Doren, 730 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 445-0444 (through tomorrow). The basic tensions of family life are the subject of a breakthrough video installation, enacted with comic flair yet emotional accuracy by four able actors who never say a word. With the help of a constantly roving, tilting camera and all-white background, the work has a loopy spatial quality that can even set in motion the viewer who wants to keep up with the action, which is projected on opposite walls (Smith).

"POP PATRIOTISM," Momenta Art, 72 Berry Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 218-8058 (through Sunday). This group show satirizes commercial exploitation of post 9/11 patriotism. Thomas Sherrod's lovingly painted teddy bear paints stars and stripes on a dollar sign in the sky; David Opdyke's "Suburbanistan" remaps Afghanistan as a suburban tract; Christy Rupp offers "Taliban Barbie," the real doll in a burka; Heidi Schlatter's video compiles a montage of narcissistic pop stars singing patriotic anthems; and the show's curator, Peter Scott, displays his collection of red-white-and-blue kitsch, including keychains, magazine covers and flip-flop sandals (Johnson).

SCOTT RICHTER, Elizabeth Harris Gallery, 529 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 463-9666 (through tomorrow). Mr. Richter piles up pigment on tables or wall plaques in luscious, thick, gooey layers that make the viewer long for a lick. The works need no other justification for their existence than the pure pleasure of paint, yet they do have references, to Pop Art, to Minimalism, to the Hudson River School, to the palettes of different painters admired by Mr. Richter, even to world events. The piece de resistance is a table, "Big Sky," dedicated to Frederic E. Church. It celebrates the romantic tints of the Hudson River School, whose canvases made the American wilderness into gorgeous stage sets. A smooth, shiny, hardened wall of paint sweeps up from the back edge of the table, its nuanced sunset colors shimmering over a flat yellowish-orange ground that ends at the table's front edge in thick encrustations and gobbets of paint. It evokes those sublime landscapes, yet gives new dimensions to paint as its own subject (Glueck).

"SACRED MATTER: KAREN DOLMANISTH AND DEBORAH MASTERS," Smack Mellon Studios, 56 Water Street, Brooklyn, (718) 834-8761 (through Sunday). Installation art is well suited to the accumulative and performance-based modes of creation seen in this joint show of two artists at mid-career. Ms. Masters, best known for her figurative sculpture, presents an assemblage-style environment in which she tells the story of her life through thousands upon thousands of hoarded objects arranged in a series of altars. Ms. Dolmanisth's installation is a circular enclosure made from upright branches; dresses and nightshirts hang from the ceiling above it like an airborne audience to a ritual (Cotter)

* MISSY STEVENS, "A Year of Change"; PRUE VENABLES, "Objects," Nancy Margolis Gallery, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 343-9523 (through tomorrow). Using needle, thread and beads, Ms. Stevens makes tiny, tightly knit tapestries of riveting optical and material richness. Her images may seem whimsically simple-minded, but as in the poetry of Emily Dickinson, formal ingenuity and heartfelt moods ranging from ecstasy to grief give the work a depth that belies the seemingly naive surface. Ms. Venables's classical serene domestic ceramics nicely complement Ms. Stevens's busy quirkiness (Johnson)

IVAN WITENSTEIN AND DAN FISCHER, Derek Eller Gallery, 526-530 West 25th Street, Chelsea, (212) 206-6411 (through tomorrow). Each of the seven fiberglass and cast-resin sculptures in Mr. Witenstein's impressive New York solo debut, titled "Here Comes the Son, Here Comes the Knight," is like a psychedelic version of American-style Social Realism, with references to war, racism, popular culture, 19th-century literature and 20th-century history molded together with a visionary zeal. Mr. Fischer revisits photo-realism in detail-perfect graphite drawings based on magazine illustrations of art world stars past and present. These images look every bit as weird as the figures in Mr. Witenstein's sculptures, and are no less virtuosically made (Cotter).

GRAPHIC: Photos: An oil field worker from "Richard Avedon: Portraits," at the Met. ($;Richard Avedon/Metropolitan Museum of Art); Daniel Ford's "Colossus," one of nearly 400 works in the 25th Anniversary Benefit Selections Exhibition at the Drawing Center in SoHo. (The Drawing Center)

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section F; Column 1; Escapes; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1724 words

HEADLINE: DRIVING; 
The Rhythm of Utah's Highway 12: Climb, Turn, Gasp

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW BROWN 

 BODY:
UTAH took nearly four decades to build all 122 miles of its Highway 12. Sporadically from the 1940's to the 1980's, construction crews blasted, cut and paved their way through rugged hills and cliffs. Initially, the road was built to move cattle, supplies and mail for the people in five small towns in the southern part of the state -- even now, their total population is less than 2,000. But when the last stretch, over the massive and heavily forested Boulder Mountain, was finally paved in 1985, it didn't take travelers (and tourism promoters) long to discover that this two-lane farm-to-market road was also the best tour of Utah's red-rock desert that can be taken in a short trip, a weekend or even a single day.
 It's a path through some of the most diverse and stunning scenery on the Colorado Plateau, linking Bryce Canyon and Capitol Reef National Parks, and many who take it aren't making their first visit. On each trip, there's something new to discover -- a side road or trail leading to an overlook or a waterfall, the colors and smells of a new season, a new place to eat. The road is passable year-round, and the gold leaves of aspen trees on Boulder Mountain were added last week to the palette of greens, reds, browns and tans in the rocks and vegetation along the route. 
 Even people who live here can't easily resist the attraction of the landscape. "Every day it still affects me," said Louise Liston, a former commissioner of Garfield County, Utah, who lives in Escalante, the largest (with 1,063 people) of the towns along the highway. She moved to Escalante from Milwaukee as a teenager 50 years ago, but, she said, she still feels renewed each morning when she looks out her picture windows at the green junipers and vermilion cliffs of the Escalante Mountains to the north, or at the long dark silhouette of the Kaiparowits Plateau on the southern horizon.
Highway 12 is roughly semicircular, connecting U.S. 89 and State Highway 24. Starting from U.S. 89, the highway ascends to Red Canyon, named for the surrounding hills and cliffs, colored by iodized iron in limestone rock. Two short tunnels hewn out of the limestone suggest what the road builders were up against.
At the 13-mile mark is the turnoff to Bryce Canyon, where throngs of tourists gaze at the brilliant red-orange spires, bridges and other rock formations sculptured by water and wind. A short trip could become a long one if you enter this justly beloved park.
Past the Bryce turnoff, the road descends into Bryce Valley and the town of Tropic, named by settlers in 1892 for its seemingly mild climate. Like most towns along Highway 12, Tropic has a Mormon church and a cluster of houses; it's not uncommon to spot people gathered to celebrate a holiday, birthday or family reunion.
Like the others, too, it has a facade of recently built convenience stores, restaurants and motels. The rental cars, sport utility vehicles and motorcycles zooming along with the occasional farmers' pickups have had their effect. The area's economy has expanded from cattle ranching and alfalfa fields to accommodate a growing tourist trade.
Heading southeast, the next town is Cannonville, one of two gateways to the Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument, extending across 1.9 million acres of federally owned land. The area was designated a national monument by the Clinton administration in 1996 to protect the Kaiparowits Plateau from coal mining.
At the monument's visitors' center in Cannonville, Dave Mecham, a member of the staff, warned against turning onto any of the many tempting dirt roads off Route 12 if there is any chance of rain. Some of these roads lead to wilderness where one can hike into sandstone slot canyons narrower than an arm or overlook hollows so deep it's difficult to see the bottom. But a cloudburst on a dirt road in this country can strand the beefiest four-wheel-drive vehicle in a slick, slimy mess. "Locals say, 'All you have to do is spit on the road and you'll get stuck,' " Mr. Mecham said.
From November to March, despite the early impressions of the founders of Tropic, there is also the possibility of snow to consider.
By this point the rhythm of Route 12 has established itself. It's not just the obvious cycle of a car groaning up the hills and coasting down the other side. It's a recurring pattern of building anticipation before a blast of eye-popping scenery, and then a brief lull before the buildup starts again.
The rich geological history of the area accounts for the variation in scenery. Cannonville is surrounded by huge smooth mounds and cliffs of dark reddish brown slickrock, indicating a time of high temperatures and dry conditions during the Jurassic period, when nature laid down this layer of earth. Alan Titus, a paleontologist for the Grand Staircase monument, said the arid climate allowed the iron in the sandstone to oxidize, giving the rock its color.
A few miles later, as the road climbs to Henrieville, it passes through a later stratum, formed when the area was under water and home to more organic life and less oxygen. The result is not so scenic -- a drab gray and brown landscape -- but it is rich in fossils and dinosaur remains. "The area has one of the best records of life on land during the closing days of the age of dinosaurs," Mr. Titus said. He is reluctant to say where these fossils are for fear of looters' ransacking the area before experts can take an inventory of the ancient history embedded in the rock.
Color appears in rocks again as the road heads east into Escalante, where there is a second office for the monument. Slow down to avoid the speed trap and take in the view to the south of alfalfa fields and farmhouses against the background silhouettes of the Fifty-Mile and Navajo Mountains.
The anticipation builds again in the climb out of Escalante, and then peaks as the road winds through a landscape of tan-colored petrified sand dunes, once part of a windblown desert that stretched from Wyoming to southern Nevada. The horizontal lines crisscrossing the ancient dunes indicate the direction the wind blew the sand, which is now rock-hard and dotted with pinyon trees.
The highway bottoms out at the Escalante River, choked with lush green vegetation, and then climbs the side of a rust-colored sandstone cliff and plateaus atop a ridge. That's where a startling vista of the Escalante Canyons, a labyrinth of deep channels breaking up the expanse of petrified dunes, appears. Pull off at a turnout to take in the view. There are no guardrails along this section of Highway 12, which local residents have named the Hogsback, or Little Burma Road, and it snakes along a ridge with fatal dropoffs on either side.
The next town is Boulder, and depending on how much time you've taken to stop and look, you may have made it here in as little as two and a half hours. If it's time for refreshment, Boulder is the spot. The best food along Highway 12 is served there, at either Hell's Backbone Grill (dinner with a glass of wine, $35) or the Burr Trail Grill (pancake breakfast with coffee, $5.90).
Boulder is primarily a ranching community, and its scenes of horses grazing in green pastures surrounded by buff-colored rock hills make it the most picturesque town on the drive. Residents had their mail delivered by horseback until 1935, when the first road from Escalante, Hell's Backbone Road, was completed by the Civilian Conservation Corps.
The final stretch of Highway 12 climbs to an elevation of 9,200 feet over the east side of Boulder Mountain, which sits atop the Aquarius Plateau, before its long descent into the town of Torrey, the gateway to Capitol Reef National Park.
Boulder Mountain is covered with a dense forest of pine and aspen trees. To the east and south of the mountain, in contrast to the alpine setting, is a panorama of pink, red and tan plateaus and cliffs. The silhouettes of the Henry Mountains (the last range to be mapped in the lower 48 states), Navajo Mountain and the Kaiparowits Plateau are in the distance.
At a scenic overlook, a plaque describing the features of the colorful expanse stretching south below the mountain says the area within view is larger than the state of Connecticut. That's plenty of space for those who love the desert for its scenery and solitude.

WHERE TO GO
Hoodoos, Pictographs and a Photogenic Park
Part of the challenge of a drive on Route 12 is deciding which of several beautiful side trips to take. There won't be time for all of them unless you have many days. Here are four of the best.

BRYCE CANYON NATIONAL PARK
Fifty miles of trails take visitors into amphitheaters of unusual orange and pink spires and pinnacles, called hoodoos, shaped primarily by water erosion. The park covers 56 square miles and can be explored by car as well as on foot or horseback. The turnoff for the park is about 13 miles southeast of Highway 12's junction with U.S. 89 and is well marked. The entrance fee is $20 per car.

KODACHROME BASIN STATE PARK
National Geographic photographers named this landscape after the film they used to shoot its towering sand pipes, jutting up to 170 feet in the air. Ancient springs filled up with sediment, solidified and outlasted the softer sandstone, which has eroded away. Turn off the highway at Cannonville. Take the main road south through town for about 10 miles to the park entrance. The fee is $5 per car.

CALF CREEK FALLS
Observant hikers can spot ancient American Indian cliff structures and pictographs along the 2.75-mile walk to the falls, which cascade 126 feet over moss-covered sandstone. The water is cold but refreshing, especially in summer heat. For drinking, take plenty of your own water. The Calf Creek Recreation Area is west of Route 12, and the sign for the turnoff is about a mile north of where the highway crosses the Escalante River.

BURR TRAIL
This former cattle trail was widened and paved by Garfield County, over environmentalists' protests, in the 1980's and 90's. It passes through the tall red sandstone cliffs of Long Canyon and descends switchbacks cut into the domes, fins and undulating rock shapes of Waterpocket Fold before ending up at Lake Powell along the Colorado River. Some stretches are gravel, but a passenger car can handle the entire drive. Turn east off Highway 12 near the Burr Trail Grill, at the south end of Boulder. MATTHEW BROWN

HEADLINE: SHOPPING LIST; 
Fattening Up the Feathered, Not the Furred

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE HAMLIN 

 BODY:
OCTOBER is bird month, at least for humans. It's when the need to nurture kicks in, when people, as well as birds, flock to feeders, seed and suet.
 "Fall is definitely our busiest time of year, as soon as it starts to get a little chilly," said Sharon Dunn, a co-owner of Duncraft, a 50-year-old bird supply company in Concord, N.H. 
 The urge to feed the birds isn't diminished by the fact that they don't really need us. "They're well equipped to get all their nourishment in the wild, even in the dead of winter," said Robert Cataldo, the owner of Bird Watcher's Country Store in High Falls, N.Y., a virtual nest of bird paraphernalia. 
Bird feeding is simply the primal pleasure of having a direct sightline to, say, a beautiful red cardinal against a snowy landscape. Or, in the summer, watching a mother bird bring her fledglings to a backyard feeder to teach them to eat (and to bathe, if there's a birdbath nearby).
Birds are the most gracious of guests, well mannered, appreciative and lively, unlike squirrels, those rowdy members of the Sciuridae family, notorious gate crashers who show up to ransack and pillage, invited or not.
Bird suppliers report that squirrel-repellent bird feeders are their biggest sellers. Sure, squirrels can be cute, especially when they gather together in acrobatic brigades. But they have no compunctions whatsoever about muscling in on a bird-feeding station, even when they are capable of collecting their own snacks.
Chili powder, sprinkled around a bird feeder, sometimes works to repel squirrels (they hate it, although birds are fine with it). But, because of rain or wind, ground hot red pepper flakes often need to be replenished every day, not an option for those who feed birds only at their weekend homes. 
Mr. Cataldo estimates that at least half of his customers are city residents who spend weekends in the country and are soliciting avian guests for the first time.
"They get started with a simple feeder and then they get hooked," he said. "They start coming in once or twice a week, upgrading and refining. Then, if they get really hooked, they want a bird feeder for their city fire escape or terrace, one that is pigeon-proof. The squirrel-proof feeders fend off pigeons, too."

Tops in the Bird Market
Virtually everything to do with birds is stocked by two stores in the Northeast that ship all over the country. Duncraft has an outlet store in Concord and over the last half century has evolved into a prominent bird-related catalog and online store and a manufacturer of its own line of bird feeders. It also offers a newsletter that answers bird-feeding questions. For information: www.duncraft.com or (800) 593-5656.
The Bird Watcher's Country Store sells, according to Mr. Cataldo, "absolutely everything to do with nurturing birds, as well as bird tchotchkes and bird art." For information: www.birdwatcherscountrystore.com or (800) 947-2347.

Foiling the Unwanted Guest
Duncraft's Squirrel-Proof Feeding Station Selective, a hanging bird feeder, consists of a 20-inch-long clear plastic tube with four portholes for feeding surrounded by a protective wire grid, with space for two suet cakes. At $69.95, this feeder is ideal for small birds (cardinals can't quite squeeze through the grid). The Absolute II, $79.95, can hang from a tree limb or sit atop a pole (included). It's an all-steel green hopper accessible to all birds but not to squirrels: when a heavy paw hits one of the two spring-weighted perches, a shield drops down, shutting off the seed supply. And the Yankee Flipper feeder is just about as bad as it gets for squirrels. A video clip on the Duncraft Web site shows what happens when a squirrel lands on the bottom perch of the 21-inch clear plastic tube feeder: the perch spins, and the squirrel is flipped off. The feeder runs on a nickel-cadmium battery, is not harmful to birds or squirrels, and costs $99.95.

A Nutritious Spread
A great birdseed smorgasbord will encourage birds to become regular visitors. Big bags of supermarket birdseed may seem economical but can be wasteful, because they often contain filler that birds just scatter on the ground. Duncraft sells its own custom blends, for all seasons and all regions starting at $12.50 for 10 pounds. At the Bird Watcher's Country Store, an equally varied choice of nutritious seeds, made by Lyric, starts at $3.89 for four pounds.

Nesting Together at Night
As adorable as it is, Duncraft's Winter Roost, $39.95, also serves a very practical function -- on icy nights it provides a cozy bedroom for small birds that fly into the white pine house though a hole and huddle together for warmth. Meant to be hung on a fence or a tree, it's 9 by 7 1/2 by 19 1/2 inches.

GRAPHIC: Photo: FLY-IN -- The Winter Roost, and bird feeders from Duncraft and the Bird Watcher's Country Store. (Tony Cenicola/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Seeking Investment, Egypt Tries Patent Laws 

BYLINE:  By ABEER ALLAM 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Oct. 3 

 BODY:
As a high-level Egyptian delegation visits Washington this week to discuss increasing American direct investment in Egypt and bolstering the modest $3.1 billion in American-Egyptian trade, a battle is raging here over a new intellectual property rights law, which the United States had said was a prerequisite for a free-trade agreement.
 At the center of the battle are an American pharmaceuticals giant with a blockbuster drug and a powerful domestic pharmaceuticals industry trying to protect its $5.5 billion turf. 
 The law, which took effect in June, is in line with standards outlined in the World Trade Organization's Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights Agreement, which Egypt signed in 1995. For the first time here, trade secrets and industrial design are protected. The new law also affords patent protection to drugs, not just the manufacturing process, as has been the case. 
That was music to the ears of many multinationals here, including Pfizer-Egypt, the local unit of Pfizer Inc., which finally succeeded in its four-year quest to obtain permission from the Egyptian government to manufacture and sell its popular impotence drug, Viagra, in Egypt.
But local pharmaceutical companies raised a storm after the exclusive rights were issued to Pfizer in June, accusing the ministry of health of helping multinational drug companies to exploit Egypt's poor.
Egypt has the largest, most established pharmaceutical industry in the Middle East. The country is also the largest drug consumer in the region, and its exports constitute 30 percent of the Middle East drug market.
So despite the new law, Pfizer-Egypt's Viagra was on the market just two months when the Ministry of Health announced it would authorize 12 local companies to produce a generic version of the drug to sell at one-twentieth of Pfizer's market price of about $5.20 for each 50-milligram pill.
(A generic version of Viagra smuggled from Syria and India has been widely available in Egypt for years, for as much as $40 a pill. It dropped to $1 after Pfizer's drug became available.)
"We will definitely grant market authorization for all Egyptian companies that applied to produce Viagra," said Dr. Mostafa Ibrahim, president of the Ministry of Health department that administers pharmaceuticals. "We have to think of the interests of the poor people."
Besides, Dr. Ibrahim said, the ministry's decision does not violate the new law, since pharmaceuticals are given a grace period until 2005 in developing countries like Egypt.
But many legal and diplomatic experts dispute this, saying the protections are already in place. The drug, they say, is covered by the data protection provisions in a 2000 ministerial decree as well as by the patent provisions in the new law.
"Viagra is entitled to data exclusivity protection under Egyptian law for five years after its market authorization," said Karim el-Helaly, an intellectual property lawyer here, so local companies should not be allowed to start to produce generic versions until 2007.
The fight over Viagra is a prime example of the problems Egypt faces abroad as well as domestically as it positions itself in the global economy.
Diluting the protection of such a prominent drug right after the law was signed, some experts say, will hurt Egypt's efforts to lure foreign investment and expand trade opportunities.
Pfizer, of course, is furious. "It is against the law that was just approved," said Dr. Ahmed el-Hakim, the company's director of external affairs and health policy in the Middle East. "It is important to protect companies investing here."
The Egyptian economy, after growing steadily in the 1990's, is now stagnant, and the unemployment rate keeps rising. American direct investment fell to $390 million in the fiscal year that ended June 30 from $1.6 billion in the period two years earlier. Exports for the current year remain around $7 billion, or less than 10 percent of gross domestic product, despite the government's decade-long efforts to bolster trade.
Egypt is also facing dwindling American aid. It wants to get quota-free and customs-free access to the American market, especially to its garment industry.
And the country hopes to attract foreign investment to build up its information technology industry, so it can become a regional hub.
But Egyptian pharmaceutical companies, which had been freely producing generic drugs under permission called licensing -- obtained from the Ministry of Health and not involving any patent holders -- fear losing business to foreign companies.
To further their cause, they argue that exceptions to the new law need to be made that take poverty into account. And though they lost their initial battle against the patenting of pharmaceuticals, they have friends, not to mention colleagues, in high places.
"Respecting international agreements does not mean selling medicine in Egypt at the same price as New York," said Dr. Sarwat S. Bassily, chairman of the big generic drug maker Amoun Pharmaceutical Industries -- one of the 12 that recently received the government's permission to produce the generic Viagra -- and the chairman of the Health Committee in the upper house of Parliament
Still, the drug spat is only one piece of the intellectual property puzzle.
Egypt is considered to have one of the poorest records in the Middle East in protecting intellectual property rights. It tops the United States trade representative's priority watch list on protection matters. 
In a country of almost 70 million people, most of them poor, imposing a culture of respecting intellectual property rights is tough going. People mainly depend on cheap knockoffs -- whether they be generic drugs or computer software copied by people selling door to door. An estimated 90 percent of American academic books available in Egypt are pirated copies, sold at low prices, often from kiosks operating inside the universities. Nearly all American music available in the Egyptian marketplace is pirated.
The American software industry lost about $12 million from piracy here in the year ended in June, according to the Business Software Alliance, a nonprofit group of big American and Egyptian software makers that monitors piracy. But Ghada Khalifa, spokeswoman for the alliance, says the situation has improved in recent years as the Egyptian culture ministry has raided many companies using illegal software and put them out of business.
"Five years ago the piracy rate was up to 85 percent, now it's 58 percent," Ms. Khalifa said. "The government itself is almost 100 percent compliant, but the private sector is a problem."
Apart from software, American companies estimated they lost $82 million from piracy in Egypt in 2001.
Mindful of the need to honor international agreements and appease foreign companies, intellectual property rights advocates here have gone so far as to seek the intervention of religious scholars to tell their fellow Egyptians that it is un-Islamic to copy other's work.
Egypt's highest religious authority, the Mufti, issued a religious decree against piracy earlier this year.

HEADLINE: Dubai Journal; 
Living High and Aiming Higher, Come War or Peace

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates 

 BODY:
This thriving city-state on the crossroads between Asia and the Middle East likes to shock. In fact, it has made something of a business of shocking people.
 Once just another Arabian entrepot that lived off duty-free goods and trade, Dubai has reinvented itself, transforming its skyline with innovative -- some would say bizarre -- architecture and promoting itself as a financial and transportation hub for the region. 
 In contrast to the urban decay in Egypt and nervousness in Jordan, Dubai is thriving, focusing its energies not so much on politics as on the making and spending of money. 
While elsewhere in the Middle East the talk is of an Iraq war that nobody wants, Dubai is quietly preparing to cash in on whatever might happen in Iraq. "Either you look at life from a positive aspect or a negative aspect," said Mohamed Abdullah al-Gergawi, the American-educated chairman of Dubai's Financial and Investment Authority.
If there is a war in Iraq, Dubai will remain a neutral safe haven, he said. In the aftermath, the city would benefit from Iraq's reconstruction. "We don't want war, but every time there is war in the area, Dubai has benefited," he said.
If a peaceful solution is found and economic sanctions on Iraq are lifted, Dubai will also gain. 
Meanwhile, projects move ahead. The latest is a man-made island shaped to resemble a palm tree, with trunk, 17 fronds and an encircling crescent. 
The distinctive shapes have begun rising from the sea, and with a twin island planned for next year, the $3 billion project is considered the most ambitious land-reclamation effort since the Hong Kong Airport. 
"Our problem was that Dubai had run out of beach," Mr. Gergawi said. "We were brainstorming one day. Someone said, 'Why don't we make an island.' " 
But just one blob in the sea was insufficient. The plan for a series of finger islands arranged in the shape of palm trees evolved as the best way to maximize the amount of beach front, he said. The two clusters of islands will yield 80 miles of beach for housing and hotel development.
Environmental concerns? Mr. Gergawi said they had been taken into account. Even if every detail of how so many people and structures would exist on slender slivers of sand is not quite clear, it is the attitude that matters. 
In a move intended to show Dubai's economic strength after Sept. 11, Emirates Airlines, the national carrier, placed a $15 billion order for aircraft from Boeing and Airbus, including the latest 550-seat superjumbo model. 
Emirates has since emerged as one of the world's few profitable airlines, posting an 18 percent increase in passengers last spring, many of them tourists from neighboring Arab countries and Western Europe.
The aircraft purchase was also intended to help offset an image of Dubai as a backwater of shady deals. Loose financial laws allowed Al Qaeda to move money in and out of here with ease. 
Dubai has cooperated with American officials in efforts to tighten the financial laws, Western diplomats said. "They are working with us to clean up the system," one said.
The cooperation comes from necessity. The United Arab Emirates is a federation, and the seven separate emirates do not share oil revenues. Dubai has only small oil reserves, and those are diminishing fast. This is in contrast to the far richer Abu Dhabi, which sits on an oil pool large enough, according to OPEC, to make the United Arab Emirates the world's third-largest holder of oil reserves. 
The most talked-about building in Dubai remains an over-the-top luxury hotel, the Burj Al Arab, where Russian gangsters with suitcases of cash and Saudi sheiks vie to occupy palatial suites with gold-plated taps, gold-leaf banisters and screaming color schemes of crimson, citrus and carrot.
The exterior of the Burj Al Arab is shaped like a full-blown spinnaker, and its outside walls are covered with a milky Teflon-coated fabric as protection from the searing sun. Built by the ruler of Dubai, Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum, the hotel consists of 202 duplex suites. The two royal suites, which rent for $8,000 a night, are occupied only occasionally. The basement seafood restaurant, enveloped by walls of an aquarium and reached by an elevator designed as a faux submarine, is not always full either. 
But who cares? The hotel, with its revolving bed in the royal suite, is more talking point than hostelry. Nelson Mandela is said to have been dismayed by the opulence. But Bill Clinton, twice a guest, talks up Dubai as an exemplar of the possible marriage between Islam and the modern world.

PERSON: Alan Olmsted 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
A Landlubber Whose Mind Is on the Harbor

BYLINE:  By NICHOLE M. CHRISTIAN 

 BODY:
SORRY ferry fans. Alan Olmsted, the man at the helm of New York City's effort to revive river commuting, is not a ferryboat kind of guy. 
 He does not love them; he does not wax nostalgic about the glory days of grand old ferries gliding around the New York Harbor. Mr. Olmsted doesn't even have much time to frequent ferryboats, except for the "few times a month" when he is not drowning in meeting after meeting after meeting. 
 "I grew up riding the subway," confesses Mr. Olmsted somewhat apologetically. "I wasn't into boats." 
Yet in his 10 years as executive director of what he likes to call "the city's little ferry think tank" (officially the Office of Private Ferries), Mr. Olmsted, 39, has come to know everything there is to know about ferryboats in New York. 
Name a pier and he'll give you history, chapter and verse, tell you to the minute how many boats are coming and going. 
"Most people," he says, "don't realize the New York Harbor is the busiest ferry harbor on this continent." 
Ticking off nautical tidbits is the job, Mr. Olmsted says, not boasting about his successes as the go-to guy in steering the return of ferryboats to city-owned piers. Only under prodding, intense prodding, does he mention, quickly, how he -- and his staff, he insists -- made real Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's dream of building a Yankee Stadium ferry landing. 
But ferry systems were never part of the path Mr. Olmsted plotted for himself. This is his story: bright kid from Queens walks out of Princeton in the late 1980's with a master's degree in public affairs and urban planning, his head filled with dreams of becoming a big-time urban planner. Big like his dad, a senior planner for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority or maybe, one day, even as big as that other Olmsted, Frederick Law, of Central Park design fame. (They are ninth cousins, five times removed, he says.) 
On his way, Mr. Olmsted says he took a "respectable" job as a project planner for the city's Department of Transportation. It was to be a temporary detour, until he and another bright young star cooked up a little idea that quickly grew big. 
Huddled at their desks, Mr. Olmsted and his pal, Peter Hallock, secretly applied, on the city's behalf, for a $3 million federal grant to reduce traffic congestion by upgrading an old rotting pier at the foot of Wall Street. Redo the pier, they reasoned, and you'll help ferryboat operators give commuters a reason to get out off the road. 
The idea had one problem. 
"It wasn't even a D.O.T pier then," Mr. Olmsted was explaining recently, standing along the edge of what is now Pier 11, his voice straining to be heard above the growl of an incoming ferry and the drone of a helicopter overhead. "But we didn't care. We knew it needed a capital project. The agency responsible for Pier 11, they didn't even know we were applying. We said, 'Let's get the money and figure out the jurisdiction later.' "
They got the money. Ferryboat fans got a redone Pier 11, now one of the busiest in the New York Harbor, what with 400 commuter boats docking each day. And Mr. Olmsted found a reason to forget all about his plan to move on to "something more glamorous."
These are at least thrilling, and sometimes unending, work days for Mr. Olmsted's outfit. (This might explain why he's still a bachelor.) 
The number of private ferryboat companies (six) floating around the harbor and the number of people (70,000) riding them each weekday are soaring, at least compared to what he calls the "cowboy days, when no one took ferries seriously." 
Mixed in with the success, he says, is a bit of sadness. Many of the new riders found their way to the water after Sept. 11, when ferries suddenly became the only easy commute into Lower Manhattan for thousands of New Jersey PATH train riders. "I look forward to the day when that railroad is back, and people can choose the commute that is best for them, not just taking ferries because they have to, though I believe a lot of the new riders will stay." 
BUT he predicts other riders will benefit from a budding feud between New York Water Taxi, a reborn ferry service owned by the real estate mogul Douglas Durst, and New York Waterway, the nation's largest private ferry company, continues to heat up. There is also buzz among people in the ferry business, Mr. Olmsted says, on the city's efforts to expand East River ferry service, with new or improved landings at places like the Battery Maritime Building on South Street, at East 34th Street and at East 90th Street. 
Explaining his role in all of this, Mr. Olmsted says only that he has "a hand in the little things." Little things like persuading the M.T.A. to put the East 34th Street ferry landing on a bus route, and "walking New York Water Taxi through the bureaucratic obstacle course of setting up at Pier 11." 
Those little things, he concedes, have helped bring about a wave of change in private ferry service. "You don't have to be any sort of ferry fanatic to see that ferry service in New York makes sense," he says. "Ferries have a role to play again. Maybe they're headed into a different kind of glory day."

PERSON: Lorian Marlantes 

HEADLINE: Lorian Marlantes, 59, President Of Rockefeller Group Since '95 

BYLINE:  By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Lorian L. Marlantes, president of Rockefeller Group International, a corporation with interests in commercial real estate and telecommunications, died on Saturday at his home on the Upper East Side after a long illness. He was 59 and lived in Manhattan and Greenwich, Conn. 
 The family did not disclose the cause. 
 Mr. Marlantes held executive positions with the Exxon Corporation and the Penn Central Corporation before he joined the Rockefeller Group in 1982 as vice president for strategic planning and analysis. After a subsequent stint with the telecommunications services division of the Rockefeller Group, he was named in 1990 to head the subsidiary that manages Rockefeller Center.
In 1995, Mr. Marlantes was named president and chief executive of Rockefeller Group International. In that position he sought to widen the company's involvement in commercial real estate beyond the Midtown complex that was built in the 1930's.
He oversaw its national growth as a developer as well as the operations of its worldwide subsidiary, Cushman & Wakefield. He was also on the board of the Rockefeller Group, of which the Mitsubishi Estate Company, one of the world's largest real estate companies, became the majority shareholder in 1989.
Lorian Louis Marlantes grew up in Oregon and graduated Phi Beta Kappa in economics from the University of Washington in 1965. After a year in India as a Fulbright scholar, he earned a master's in economics at Stanford University. He received a Ph.D. in business economics from Stanford in 1971.
Mr. Marlantes is survived by his wife of 34 years, Carol Weida Marlantes; two daughters, Elizabeth, of Washington, and Catherine, of Manhattan; his parents, Leo and Elna, of Seaside, Ore., and a brother, Karl, of Seattle.

HEADLINE: Hispanic Voters Hard to Profile, Poll Finds 

BYLINE:  By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 

 BODY:
Though Hispanic voters identify more with Democrats than they do with Republicans, they have little party loyalty and defy easy categorization on issues like taxes and abortion, according to a new poll by the Pew Hispanic Center.
 This ideological ambivalence, coupled with a surging population of younger voters, makes Hispanics an attractive voting bloc that could swing from one party to another, the survey showed. 
 So far, the opportunity to capitalize on their growing numbers has largely been squandered. While more and more Hispanics have registered to vote, fewer have actually cast ballots. 
Hispanics have always been a hard group to characterize politically because their opinions typically vary by nationality, the region where they live and whether they were born in or outside the United States.
"There is a mixture of beliefs and attitudes that are very hard to pigeonhole," said Roberto Suro, director of the Pew Hispanic Center, which conducted the survey along with the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation. "Latinos are not necessarily a Democratic lock."
More than half the Latino Republicans questioned said they would rather pay higher taxes for more government services than pay lower taxes for fewer services, while 17 percent of non-Hispanic white Republicans stated that preference. 
On social issues, Latino Democrats expressed more conservative values than their non-Latino white counterparts. Thirty-four percent of Hispanic Democrats said they believed that divorce was unacceptable, compared with 13 percent for non-Hispanic white Democrats. Twelve percent of Latino Democrats said they thought abortion should be legal in all cases, compared with 26 percent of non-Latino white Democrats who expressed the same belief.
"Latinos born outside the United States, as a group, have particularly more intense and socially conservative views than those born within the country," said Mollyann Brodie, vice president and director of public opinion and media research for the Kaiser Family Foundation.
The poll of 1,329 registered Hispanic voters, 838 non-Hispanic whites and 136 non-Hispanic African-Americans was conducted by telephone from April to June and has a margin of error of 3.6 percentage points. It is part of a broader survey of Latinos in the United States that will be released in December.
Among those interviewed, 45 percent said they were United States citizens who were registered to vote. Of those, nearly half called themselves Democrats, one-fifth said they were Republicans and another fifth labeled themselves independent.
Democrats, for the most part, have been more aggressive in reaching out to Hispanic voters.
"Republicans don't have an institutional network to get Hispanics out to vote," said Rodolfo de la Garza, a political science professor at Columbia University who conducted a separate study of Latino voting patterns for the Tomas Rivera Policy Institute, a research organization on Hispanic issues.
His analysis, of Harris County, Tex., and Los Angeles from 1992 to 1998, found that despite a spike in the number of Hispanics registered to vote, their turnout was usually poor.
But President Bush, who received 35 percent of the Hispanic vote in Texas, has helped narrow the gap between the two parties. Though only 27 percent of Latinos in the survey said they had more confidence in Republicans than Democrats on economic issues, the numbers changed sharply when Latinos were asked to choose between Democrats in Congress and President Bush. Forty-two percent said they had more confidence in Mr. Bush.
They also demonstrated party ambivalence in other ways. When asked which of the two major political parties is more concerned about Hispanics, 45 percent said the Democrats, but 40 percent said they sensed no difference between the two sides.
Education was cited as the most important issue by 58 percent of registered Latino voters, and it was especially important to Latinos who were born outside the United States. The economy was the next priority, followed by health care and Medicare.
Immigration was also an important topic. About half of the Hispanics surveyed said they thought too many immigrants were living in the United States. But about three-fourths said the United States should continue allowing the same number of Latin Americans into the country as it has been, or should allow more.
About half of Latino voters said they get their news on television in English. Twenty-seven percent said they watch English and Spanish news, and 19 percent tune in to Spanish newscasts most of the time.

HEADLINE: Robotics Slumps, but Recovery Is Predicted 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

 BODY:
Investment in industrial robots plummeted in Japan and the United States in 2001, but a recovery is expected over the next three years, according to an annual survey by the United Nations Economic Commission.
 The overall rate of investments in robotics around the world fell by 3 percent last year. 
 The rate of growth was steady in Europe, helping to offset a decline of 40 percent in Japan and a decrease of 17 percent in the United States.
By 2005, the number of robots is expected to exceed 960,000, growing at an annual rate of 7.5 percent, according to the results of the yearly survey. 
The commission's survey, totaling 380 pages this year, was done in conjunction with the International Federation of Robotics.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Gateway, Lands' End and Avaya, with budgets totaling $225 million, drop their agencies.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE fourth quarter, typically a make-or-break time for advertisers, is under way with three large marketers deciding to break up with their agencies.
 The marketers -- Gateway, Lands' End and Avaya -- are estimated to spend more than $225 million on advertising annually. Their decisions are indicative of the increasingly volatile relationships between advertisers and agencies as signs emerge of a slowdown in spending by consumers, who have been providing whatever growth the economy has been able to muster. 
 Gateway, the struggling maker of personal computers, has become notorious for frequently changing agencies. This time the company dismissed Siltanen/Keehn in El Segundo, Calif., which has served as the creative agency on its account only since January; spending is estimated at more than $180 million. 
In another surprise, Gateway said it would shift most of the duties for creating campaigns to the Arnell Group in New York, owned by the Omnicom Group. Gateway has been working with Arnell, but on graphic-design assignments, not advertising.
Greg Lund, a spokesman for Gateway in Poway, Calif., confirmed a report of the dismissal of Siltanen/Keehn that appeared yesterday in the online edition of the trade publication Adweek.
Mr. Lund said the decision came after Gateway worked for eight months with Arnell on a brand project that included redesigning the corporate "cow spot" logo and Gateway's retail stores. Only four days ago, Gateway distributed a news release describing the project that included information about two commercials created by Siltanen/Keehn.
"Arnell has a deep understanding and appreciation for our brand and what it could do," Mr. Lund said, adding that new commercials from Arnell would start running "in time for the holiday season." The fourth quarter will bring a battle among computer makers like Gateway, Dell and Hewlett-Packard to stimulate what has been moribund demand.
"Mooooooove over, computer industry," Peter Arnell, chairman and chief executive at Arnell, said, laughing, during a brief interview. Arnell is best known for campaigns for brands like Banana Republic, Donna Karan, Reebok and Samsung.
Gateway is the most recent in a string of assignments landed by Arnell since it was acquired by Omnicom in June 2001. Others include the Chrysler Group division of DaimlerChrysler; the Masterfoods USA division of Mars; and the Kmart Corporation, to design prototypes of stores that Kmart is testing in Chicago and Detroit, which feature a lime-green logo in place of the red "K."
Under Siltanen/Keehn, Gateway pitches have ranged from humorous brand campaigns featuring Ted Waitt, the chief executive, with a "talking" cow, to stylish product-focused ads selling a new line of laptop computers. Before being selected as the creative agency for Gateway, Siltanen/Keehn had worked on projects for four months, inheriting its duties from a team at Gateway. Before that, Gateway had tried to hire Fallon Worldwide in Minneapolis, part of the Publicis Groupe, as its creative agency after parting ways with McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising in New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.
"Prior to us doing Gateway's advertising, nobody had ever said, 'Hey, that Gateway ad is great,' " said Rob Siltanen, chairman at Siltanen/Keehn. "We prompted that response on a variety of occasions." He declined further comment.
Turning to Lands' End, the catalog and Internet apparel retailer in Dodgeville, Wis., the company yesterday named McKinney & Silver in Raleigh, N.C., part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners division of Havas, as agency of record. Spending was estimated at $20 million.
The Lands' End account had been handled briefly by Element 79 Partners in Chicago, an agency recently opened by Omnicom. Element 79 inherited the account in May from an Omnicom sibling, the Chicago office of DDB Worldwide, when Lands' End was acquired by Sears, Roebuck & Company. The shift was intended to alleviate a conflict at DDB Chicago because the agency works for a Sears rival, J. C. Penney.
McKinney & Silver, which will create national television and print campaigns for Lands' End, was chosen after a three-month review that had been narrowed to that agency and two others: Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis, part of the Partnership unit of Interpublic, and the Richards Group in Dallas.
The account is the first major assignment landed by McKinney & Silver since the arrival in February of Brad W. Brinegar as president and chief executive from Leo Burnett USA in Chicago, where he had been chief executive.
"We put our hearts and souls into this pitch," said Janet Northen, a spokeswoman for McKinney & Silver, "and our blood, sweat and tears."
This is the second instance in two days of a division of Arnold Worldwide Partners landing an account from another agency. Boston Market, the restaurant chain owned by the McDonald's Corporation, announced on Wednesday that it would shift its account, with spending estimated at $35 million, to Arnold Worldwide in Boston from Suissa Miller in Los Angeles, owned by Interpublic.
As for Avaya, the provider of communications systems and equipment that was spun off from Lucent Technologies, the company named McCann-Erickson in New York as its agency of record. Spending was estimated at $25 million.
Avaya, based in Basking Ridge, N.J., had worked for more than two years with the San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding, part of the FCB Group division of Interpublic. McCann-Erickson is also the agency for Lucent, though that troubled company has drastically reduced its ad spending.
The decision by Avaya came after a six-week review that included McCann; DWP/Bates Technology in Atlanta, part of the Bates Worldwide unit of the Cordiant Communications Group; Doremus in New York, part of Omnicom; and Mullen in Wenham, Mass., part of the Partnership division of Interpublic.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
72 Condo Lofts Set for New Rochelle

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 30 

 BODY:
A former Bloomingdale's branch, empty for 25 years in a once-bustling downtown neighborhood here, is being converted to 72 condominium lofts. City officials and lenders see the project as pivotal to a larger effort to restore economic vitality to the area.
 The developers are spending close to $15 million to convert the five-story building to market-rate lofts that are being marketed to artists, computer graphics designers and other professionals as places where they can live and work. 
 Scheduled for completion late next spring, Davenport -- Lofts on Main, as the 100,000-square-foot building is called, is to offer apartments with 13- to 15-foot-high ceilings, oversize windows and interior spaces of 900 to 1,800 square feet. Prices for the condos are expected to range from $185,000 to $400,000, said the developers, 554-560 Main Street Associates. 
Because the Community Preservation Corporation, a nonprofit consortium of banks and insurance companies based in Manhattan, expects the project to spur a revitalization of the surrounding neighborhood, it plans to lend money not only to 554-560 Main Street Associates but also to surrounding property owners.
"The Bloomingdale's project is a pivotal one," said Sadie McKeown, a senior vice president for the consortium. "If you walk up and down the street, you can see a number of other buildings also hungry for this kind of renovation." 
The Community Preservation Corporation gave the Davenport's developers an $11.1 million construction loan, the largest ever issued by its Hudson Valley branch, in Hawthorne, Ms. McKeown said. It expects to issue $15 million more in 30-year loans to upgrade some of the smaller mixed-use properties in the neighborhood, which the city designated a business improvement district three years ago.
Ralph DiBart, executive director of the New Rochelle Downtown Business Improvement District, said the city also recently rezoned the spaces above the stores in the area from commercial to residential so owners could convert empty office space to housing.
So far, the lending consortium has received five more preliminary applications from property owners in the business improvement district, with most of them wanting to build apartments above their stores. One, a restaurateur, hopes to expand his business.
The principals of 554-560 Main Street Associates, Mona Gora-Friedman, Joseph Klaynberg and Stuart Polinsky, bought the former Bloomingdale's last spring for $3.5 million from Grand Metropolitan Development, which had owned it for several years.
Richard S.Granoff, the project's architect, said the major challenge facing the developers was converting the brick and limestone structure, which was designed for retail use, to a residential use while trying to preserve as much of the building's original character as possible.
"We've had to work around existing steel columns and windows with sills that were six feet above the floor," Mr. Granoff said. The windowsills were lowered, making the existing tall windows even larger, and several hundred new windows were cut into the west side of the building, where there were none. The windows on the south side of the building look out on Long Island Sound, Davenport Bay and surrounding park areas.
The interiors will feature upscale kitchens with wood cabinets, slate counters and stainless steel appliances as well as marble bathrooms. The 900-square-foot loft unit's living room will be 18 feet by 18 feet; the bedroom will be 11 feet by 15 feet. The unit will also include a bathroom, a kitchen and an entry hall.
A typical 1,700-square-foot unit will have a 20-foot-by-20-foot living area, a separate 18-foot-by-40-foot area, a 16-foot-by-12-foot bedroom, one and a half baths, a kitchen and an entry hall. A 20,000-square-foot sixth floor is being added to the 80-year-old building for 13 penthouse units with terraces. 
Each loft is designed to enable residents to conduct business from home, and wiring for high-speed telecommunication services is being installed.
Four blocks away, New Rochelle's $17 million Intermodal Transportation Center, which will be a hub for Amtrak and Metro-North train service, is expected to be completed next spring, at about the same time the condos are ready to occupy.
