HEADLINE: Warren Buffett Moves to Help Group Trying to Reduce Nuclear and Biological Threats 

BYLINE:  By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
In a small but significant philanthropic gesture, Warren E. Buffett is opening his huge wallet to help support a group founded by Ted Turner and former Senator Sam Nunn whose aim is to reduce the threat of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons.
 Calling the threat posed by nuclear and other unconventional weapons "the ultimate problem" confronting mankind, Mr. Buffett said yesterday that he had decided to give the group, the Washington-based Nuclear Threat Initiative, $2.5 million over five years and become an adviser to its board. His commitment to the group is to be announced on Friday. 
 "It's not that much money," said Mr. Buffett, American's second wealthiest man, who runs the investment company Berkshire Hathaway. But he said he hoped it would "encourage other businessmen to get involved" in confronting a challenge that "boggles the mind."
"The genie was let out of the bottle in the 1940's," he said, referring to the creation of the atomic bomb. While there was no "putting it back into the bottle," Mr. Buffett said, the "best answer is what Sam Nunn is doing."
The initiative was founded almost two years ago with a pledge of stock that Mr. Turner held in AOL Time Warner that was then worth about $250 million. Since January 2001, the group has spent roughly $37 million on projects such as helping secure nuclear material stored in Russia, helping create a revolving fund to respond quickly to infectious disease outbreaksand, most recently, removing highly enriched uranium from a poorly secured reactor in Belgrade to a safer site. 
But the group has been hard pressed by the 77.9 percent decline in the price of AOL Time Warner stock. Mr. Turner has told the foundation that he would "do what he can to meet the $250 million commitment." But Mr. Nunn said in an interview, "There is no binding commitment beyond the number of shares." As a result, Mr. Nunn said, although the group was not cutting its staff of 32 and still planned to spend $30 million on projects this year and $25 million in 2003, it would be unable to undertake any expensive new projects. He said he would raise more money.
Given the fragile state of the stock market, Mr. Nunn said, "Warren Buffett's commitment is even more important than it would normally be at this stage." 
Mr. Buffett said he had long been concerned about the danger posed by weapons of mass destruction but had not gotten involved because he did not initially believe the danger could be mitigated by money. As he came to know of the tive's work through his friendship with Mr. Nunn on the Coca-Cola board, he said he became convinced that the group's projects could make a difference.
"You don't want an Einstein or a Russian biological warrior to be starving," Mr. Buffett said, referring to American and international efforts to ensure that scientists with such deadly expertise are gainfully and peacefully employed. Investments in keeping such people and material out of harm's way, he said, "may increase the probability of getting through the next 50 years."
Mr. Buffett also supported President Bush's stance on Iraq, arguing that limiting the threat of Saddam Hussein's unconventional weapons might limit the danger he posed. 
"If I thought the probability was high that a nation of some resources was developing really potent weapons to use against me, and that there was a high probability that he would use them, I think you have to act pre-emptively," Mr. Buffett said.
He declined to discuss what impact a war against Iraq would have on the economy. "People think I know what I'm talking about," he said. "So I have to be careful." 
He said he looked forward to being consulted by Mr. Nunn and Mr. Turner as they saw fit. Mr. Nunn said Mr. Buffett's involvement with the initiative would be particularly valuable not only in fund-raising, but also in persuading pharmaceutical companies and other biotech concerns that it is worth investing in research and development efforts that rely on skills of former Soviet scientists.
Mr. Turner called Mr. Buffett to thank him for his gift to the initiative. "Ted comes in technicolor," Mr. Buffett said, adding that he admired him for thinking in terms of "big causes" and committing large sums to them.

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Hardware: EMC Plans To Lay Off 1,350 

BYLINE:  By Barnaby J. Feder (NYT) 

 BODY:
 EMC, the leading vendor of data storage systems, said late yesterday that sales had dropped off at the end of the third quarter, making it unlikely that the company could return to profitability this year, and that it would lay off 1,350 employees, or 7 percent of its work force. EMC estimated that it had revenue of $1.25 billion in the quarter, at least 10 percent less than Wall Street had expected. "The harsh reality of reduced budgets and the uncertainty of the economic and geopolitical climate are weighing heavily on business confidence," said Joseph M. Tucci, chief executive of EMC, which is based in Hopkinton, Mass. EMC's shares, which closed at $5.01 in trading during the day, fell as much as $4.32 in after-hours trading. Shares of other data storage companies, including Emulex, Brocade Communications Systems, Network Appliance and McData also fell after EMC's report.

HEADLINE: Defining Evil in The Wake Of 9/11 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN

 BODY:
IT seems all too familiar: on a fall morning in a major city, civilization is disrupted. In less than a half-hour, buildings are destroyed, thousands are killed, the sky turns dark with dust. Philosophers and religious leaders invoke the concept of evil. Some blame the sinful behavior of the citizenry and cite divine retribution; others believe that civil society will soon restore itself.
 But this is Lisbon, not New York; Nov. 1, not Sept. 11; 1755, not 2001; and the event is not a terrorist attack but an earthquake followed by raging fires and tidal floods. The philosopher Susan Neiman compares these events in her new book, "Evil in Modern Thought: An Alternative History of Philosophy" (Princeton University Press), and the contrasts are more telling than the similarities. Ms. Neiman, a Kantian scholar and director of the Einstein Forum, an interdisciplinary research institution in Potsdam, Germany, treats the Lisbon earthquake as a turning point in European intellectual history. It redefined the way evil was thought about -- something, she suggests, that is not likely to happen as a result of 9/11. 
 But the subject of evil is now becoming the focus of unusual attention. New books are out about fundamentalism and evil, like "When Religion Becomes Evil," by Charles Kimball (Harper San Francisco), and about the psychology of evil, as in "Becoming Evil: How Ordinary People Commit Genocide and Mass Killing," by James Waller (Oxford University Press). In "Radical Evil: A Philosophical Interrogation" (Polity Press), Richard J. Bernstein, a philosopher at the New School University, begins by quoting Hannah Arendt, who declared in 1945, "The problem of evil will be the fundamental question of postwar intellectual life in Europe." 
But Arendt's prediction was right for only a short time. Despite all the horrors of the 20th century, including the Gulag, the Cambodian killing fields and the "ethnic cleansing" in the Balkans, the "problem of evil" began to seem somewhat quaint. Mr. Bernstein writes, "It is almost as if the language of evil has been dropped from contemporary moral and ethical discourse." 
In fact, when the word evil was used by President Bush to describe the terrorist attacks, it was partly because it was an anachronistic term, premodern in its force. He seemed deliberately to seek an antique religious aura, asserting the existence of moral absolutes in an era that doubted them.
Ms. Neiman is too subtle a reader of Kant to believe that evil is that simple, but it is also, she argues, so important that much of Western philosophy is an attempt to comprehend it. We apply the concept, after all, when we cannot make sense of a horrific event. Evil is not just an ethical violation; it is an "epistemological" violation, she writes; it disrupts and challenges our interpretations of the world. 
In the premodern era, Ms. Neiman explains, evil referred as much to natural catastrophes as to willful acts. One of the tasks of philosophy and religion was to interpret such cataclysms. So suffering became a result of original sin. A catastrophe was divine punishment. Then, in the 17th century, Leibniz invented the term theodicy to describe his defense of a God accused of creating an evil world; the word later came to mean an attempt to account for evil itself. Leibniz argued that we really live in the best of all possible worlds. Bad things seem to happen to good people because we lack God's omniscience.
But in Ms. Neiman's account, the earthquake in Lisbon disrupted all that. The world was becoming more scientifically intelligible, and a modern economy was developing. So when disaster struck, the old theodicy was inadequate. The earthquake caused philosophical trauma. Kant wrote about it. Voltaire and Rousseau argued over it. Gradually, Ms. Neiman says, the idea of a catastrophe being a "natural evil" disappeared; its divorce from the notion of "moral evil" became "part of the meaning of modernity." 
Explaining moral evil in a world of autonomous actors while still maintaining faith in Providence was no easy task, and Ms. Neiman eloquently outlines the attempts. In the 18th century, Rousseau "replaced theology with history," she argues, by suggesting that evil and suffering were the results not of original sin but of error and misguided civilization. Later, Hegel turned history into theodicy by explaining all suffering and evil as unavoidable elements of an evolutionary process. Marx responded with an economic theodicy -- an account of societies and their evils -- complete with prescriptions for healing suffering. Freud turned inward, tracing evil and suffering to thwarted infantile desires and to civilization's inevitable discontents.
These varied theodicies tried to account for evil, to make it comprehensible, at times even to dismiss it. Ms. Neiman seems to suggest that by the first part of the 20th century, "moral evil," like "natural evil" before it, had come to seem almost a banal idea, little more than another element of the natural world or a reflection of psychology or economics. 
But then came yet another trauma, one that was as disruptive to the 20th century as Lisbon was to the 18th: Auschwitz. Only this time, Ms. Neiman argues, it undermined the very possibility of constructing a theodicy. "The problem of evil began by trying to penetrate God's intentions," she writes. "Now it appears we cannot make sense of our own."
More than 50 years later, where are we? Oddly, when Ms. Neiman comes to the events of 9/11, she seems ill at ease. She says that they leave a "sense of conceptual helplessness." In her discussion, two notions of evil seem to confront each other: the post-Auschwitz and the pre-Lisbon. This is a small part of the book, but it may be more important than Ms. Neiman realizes. 
She argues that the attacks did not reflect new forms of evil; in fact they were "old fashioned" in their elemental power. They harked back to the Lisbon earthquake, seeming like a "natural evil" in their swift horror. "Crude forms of theodicy" even developed as a result, including at least one assertion that the attacks were the consequences of American sin. 
Yet despite her recognition of pre-Lisbon evil, she is astonishingly condescending to those who immediately called the acts evil; she ascribes to those unnamed figures a "simple and demonic" view of evil, one encouraged by watching "old westerns." 
On the other side, she describes those with supposedly more sophisticated views, influenced "less by Hollywood than by Chile and Vietnam and Auschwitz and Cambodia."
"We have learned," she writes (for she includes herself), to see evil in the acts of governments and to see "starvation furthered by corporate interests." In other words, more sophisticated people have learned to discover evils that they feel have been perpetrated by the West.
Yet she is palpably uncomfortable with the responses of this second group, for their post-Auschwitz view of Western evil has led them to a "paralyzed moral reaction" to Sept. 11, as if they couldn't condemn one evil because they believed in another, as if by calling the attacks evil, they would be lending support to "those with fewer scruples." This view of the attacks, she writes, "appeared to relativize them" and "risked a first step toward making them justifiable." She insists that the attacks be forthrightly described as evil -- which wouldn't preclude condemning other evils as well. 
In much of this analysis, she has accurately described an intellectual debate that continues. But her condescension toward those who first condemned the acts as evil and her denigration of their scruples don't seem to fit with her conclusion: that these people were actually correct. She remains uneasy in her convictions and in the company she must keep.
But the opposing view, with its mentions of Vietnam and "corporate interests" can spur unease in other ways. These evils -- if evils they are -- are not instantly perceived but are judged evil according to particular interpretations and political theories. But aren't these theories also theodicies, some with their own "simple and demonic" views of evil? Suffering is explained by material forces latent in economics and power politics. Even 9/11 is treated as a consequence of more fundamental evils: those created by imperialism and Western power. 
There is, then, good reason for Ms. Neiman's discomfort, for in many ways the experience of Sept. 11 does resemble Lisbon. It seems to challenge regnant theodicies. Simply applying the label evil leaves the event without a modern context; it does not show how that evil is to be understood. But the supposedly more sophisticated post-Auschwitz view is also a problem. The terrorists' motivations and beliefs may not be easily reduced to familiar notions of "root causes." 
So both the pre-Lisbon and the post-Auschwitz view of evil seem unstable. Interpretations are in dispute. This is an almost classic response to the experience of evil; and in its wake, new theodicies may one day start to replace the old.

HEADLINE: Kill the Energy Bill 

 BODY:
Negotiators from the House and Senate have been struggling to reconcile two different versions of a multibillion-dollar energy bill. They would do themselves and the nation a tremendous favor by junking the whole thing and agreeing to start all over again next year. Though the Senate bill is preferable to the House's, neither version would measurably improve the nation's energy security or lessen its dependence on Mideast oil now or in the future -- which is what the whole exercise was supposed to be about. Both are also suspect on environmental grounds. 
 There are bound to be a few good things in a bill this big, and there are. Both versions include various tax breaks for greater energy efficiency and renewable, non-fossil fuels, like wind and solar power. The Senate is also pushing some potentially useful incentives to make the energy transmission markets more reliable and decentralize them. 
 Nevertheless, these and other useful ideas are buried under an avalanche of subsidies for traditional producers of fossil fuels -- oil, natural gas and especially coal. In that sense, the bill points in exactly the wrong direction, enriching industries that already have plenty of investment capital while doing relatively little to encourage newer technologies that could lead the way to a less oil-dependent energy future. 
Even some of the "renewable fuel" provisions are not what they seem. The worst example is a so-called ethanol mandate that would triple the amount of ethanol used as a fuel additive over the next 10 years. There are no persuasive environmental arguments for ethanol; clean-burning gasoline can be made without it. Nor is it attractive as an alternative fuel. Ethanol is produced from starches, mainly corn, but as of now it requires nearly as much energy to produce as it gives back. The ethanol mandate amounts to a giveaway to the big corn producers and the politicians who represent them.
The most important step this nation could take to ease its dependence on Middle Eastern oil is to tighten fuel economy standards, which have not changed since 1985. In March, however, the Senate bowed to union and industry pressure and rejected an effort to increase fuel efficiency by 50 percent over 13 years, a technologically feasible move that would have saved 2.5 million barrels of oil a day, or roughly our current imports from the Persian Gulf. The conference committee's response is a pathetic little measure that aims to save about 25 million barrels over five years (or about 10 days' worth of imports). Loopholes in the measure would cancel out even this modest saving.
The terrorist attacks and California's power crisis challenged Congress to devise a comprehensive, innovative energy strategy. It has failed to do so. The new Congress that convenes in January should make a fresh start.

HEADLINE: A Pension Fund Chief Bets on US Airways 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

 BODY:
In its new partner, the Retirement Systems of Alabama, US Airways is dealing with a pension fund that not only seeks out crafty investments but has another critical motivation: jobs for Alabamans.
 That's a far cry from what the airline expected when it tried to link up with the Texas Pacific Group, a group of financial managers experienced in turning around failing carriers. 
 The Alabama pension fund has no aviation track record. Rather, it has an idiosyncratic chief executive, David G. Bronner, who after hearing about the Texas Pacific offer, simply decided to top it.
The fund's bid, initially rebuffed, was accepted by US Airways last week. It calls for the fund to invest $240 million of state pension money into US Airways, in return for a 37.5 percent stake after the airline emerges from bankruptcy protection next year. The Montgomery-based pension fund is also putting up $500 million in financing and will restructure leases it holds on $340 million worth of US Airways planes. 
Mr. Bronner, in an interview, insisted he has no plans to interfere with management, but in the same breath made no secret of his agenda.
"The investment provides me with an opportunity to say, 'If you are going to expand in x, y or z, there's no reason why it can't be in Alabama,' " Mr. Bronner said by telephone from his office. That may mean more US Airways flights to Alabama's major cities or putting back-office operations in the state.
And doubtless he will not be shy about persuading executives to make those moves. Over the years, he has sunk millions of dollars from the $25 billion fund into hotels and golf courses, and bought hundreds of newspapers and dozens of television stations. Moreover, he has used those assets to attract tourists and even more business to the state, as when he offered free advertising last winter to help wrest a $1 billion Hyundai plant away from Kentucky.
While he insists that whatever US Airways decides to do must make financial sense, even broaching the state's agenda worries some public policy experts and industry analysts.
"You have to separate out what is an economic development goal from a prudent approach to investing," said Randall W. Eberts, executive director of the W. E. Upjohn Institute for Employment Research in Kalamazoo, Mich. "When you bring the two together too closely, you run the risk of putting both in jeopardy."
Raymond Neidl, who follows airlines for Blaylock & Partners in New York, was a bit more sanguine. "If it makes business sense, fine, but there should be no pressure," he said. "Putting routes in because one of your principal owners wants it will ruin the airline."
Mr. Bronner, 57, admits his bid shocked David N. Siegel, the US Airways chief executive, who was on a business trip to South America when Retirement Systems made its bid. Mr. Siegel had worked with the Texas Pacific Group to reorganize Continental Airlines in the 1990's, and had brought the turnaround specialists in to repair US Airways. Mr. Bronner wants Mr. Siegel to manage the airline just as he would have if Texas Pacific had prevailed.
"We do not run any of our operating companies," Mr. Bronner said. The reorganization plan gives the pension fund 5 of 13 seats on the board, but Mr. Bronner said he had not decided who would fill them.
Mr. Bronner's unorthodox series of investments and uncanny timing have won him comparisons to the billionaire financier Warren E. Buffett, a source of pride for Mr. Bronner, who has yet to meet Mr. Buffett. Another comparison is apt, too.
In 1989, Mr. Buffett made his own disastrous investment in US Airways, an action he later termed "temporary insanity." Mr. Bronner said Mr. Buffett's experience was one reason he will not become involved in running the airline. "That's why you have professional nuts to run it," said Mr. Bronner, who was advised in his move by Rono J. Dutta, the former United Air Lines president.
Unlike Mr. Buffett, a confessed "air-oholic," Mr. Bronner said he has had no lifelong desire to run an airline. Indeed, Mr. Bronner, born in Iowa, was rebuffed in his only earlier attempt to enter the business. The summer after his freshman year at Mankato State University in Minnesota, he tried to land a job as a baggage handler at United in Chicago.
Instead, he wound up working for the Rock Island Railroad, completed his undergraduate and master's degrees, then moved to Tuscaloosa to attend law school as well as earn a doctorate in administration at the University of Alabama. (In Alabama, he is often given the "doctor" title.) Serving at the university for a year as assistant dean, he was named chief executive of the pension fund in 1973, when it had only $500 million in assets.
His first huge risk came in 1975, when New York City was gasping financially. As he was walking the streets and looking up at skyscrapers during a trip to Manhattan, he remembered thinking: "This is the best and neatest city in the world. They're not going to turn off the lights." And soon his pension fund became the biggest investor in Consolidated Edison bonds.
Mr. Bronner came to New York's aid again during its late 1980's fiscal crisis, buying $200 million in city bonds, and investing $100 million in 55 Water Street, built by the real estate firm Olympia & York. The firm subsequently went under, taking most of the value of Mr. Bronner's investment with it. He pitched in to take control of the building, investing millions more for renovations and upkeep. Now that investment is worth $830 million. 
Asked whether his heart really lies in New York, not Alabama, Mr. Bronner replied, "I'd rather visit."
Back in Alabama, Mr. Bronner is a weighty political presence, his quips and barbs attracting frequent attention. Two years ago, he ruffled some feathers by praising former Gov. George C. Wallace as "a good politician" for listening to voters and getting ahead of their concerns. He also caused a flurry of debate last year by declaring that Alabama needed to raise taxes so residents could get better services and education. "Low taxes are good," he said, "but the lowest taxes in America are dumb."
Friends say he relishes the spotlight. "Dr. David takes no prisoners," said Theodore J. vonCannon, president of the Birmingham Metropolitan Development Board. Mr. vonCannon has no problem with Mr. Bronner's direction of the state's pension fund. "The important thing is to make money, but he can meet that goal and create jobs for the state," Mr. vonCannon said. "I think it is marvelous."
Mr. Bronner's quest to shift US Airways' operations to Alabama will be merely a sidelight once the airline comes out of bankruptcy, contends John Ash, a Washington-based aviation consultant. "US Airways is a high-risk situation, but there are a lot of high-risk situations that pension funds get into."
Mr. Bronner's action has support, too, from US Airways' unions, whose representatives will receive seats on the board. "We'll take Mr. Bronner at his word, much as we were going to take Texas Pacific Group at their word, that he's not going to meddle in the company," said Jeff Zack, a spokeswoman for the Association of Flight Attendants.
Mr. Zack said the unions are not concerned about getting assistance from a right-to-work state's pension fund. "If they were to move their headquarters to Alabama," he said, "that would be another story."
Mr. Bronner has no such plans, nor will one of Alabama's airports become a US Airways hub. "That would be a stretch," he said. But Marc Pelham, director of marketing at the Mobile airport, said he would like to see direct flights to Washington and Florida, supplementing the three each day to Charlotte, N.C. Such a move might be possible, Mr. Bronner said, as US Airways adds efficient regional jets after it emerges from bankruptcy.
Mr. Bronner said the turnaround plan would ultimately make US Airways into a viable competitor to low-fare carriers, which, he contends, may beat US Airways on cost, but cannot compete in scope. "People can always talk about JetBlue," he said, "but what's he got -- 20 airplanes? That's nice. But they can't service 59 million passengers like US Airways."

HEADLINE: A Double Whammy on Long Island 

 BODY:
Faced with sluggish sales tax revenues and soaring pension, health insurance and Medicaid costs, counties in the New York metropolitan region are facing cuts in popular services and hikes in local taxes to balance their budgets. And Albany isn't helping. On Long Island, the Nassau County executive, Thomas Suozzi, confronts a fiscal double whammy. Not only must he surmount the current economic downturn, but he must do so even as he grapples with the financial crisis left behind by his Republican predecessor, Thomas Gulotta. 
 Mr. Suozzi's 2003 budget proposal shows him moving aggressively to balance the books and overhaul creaky government operations. For example, his plan contemplates shrinking the county payroll by 1,400 workers -- a reduction of about 15 percent over the next 12 months. It also includes the 19.4 percent increase in the county portion of the property tax bill, which the Legislature's Democratic majority approved last spring. He has warned that future tax increases may be necessary if the economy does not rebound, mandated costs continue to rise or unions refuse givebacks. 
 One big-ticket item that Nassau must trim is the police budget. Including generous overtime benefits, an average Nassau County police officer now makes $101,000 a year, far more than the average New York City officer makes.
Unlike Mr. Gulotta, who posed only meek opposition to police contract demands in order to preserve the police union's endorsement, Mr. Suozzi has not been shy about criticizing the county's unduly generous police contracts. He has called on the unions to accept a three-year pay freeze, and more than $30 million a year in contract givebacks. Otherwise, Mr. Suozzi has warned, he may need to make drastic cuts in buses and parks, and programs for teenagers and the elderly.
The police should not be made scapegoats for the county's fiscal debacle. But Mr. Suozzi is right to inform the public -- and the state arbitration panel that will probably decide the longstanding contract impasse -- about some of the real trade-offs ahead. Will the county keep its senior centers open or continue to pay officers a 10 percent bonus for "night" work that begins at 11 a.m.? Posing such choices aloud may be smart negotiating strategy on Mr. Suozzi's part. But the truth is that Nassau is broke; it cannot afford both.

HEADLINE: Some Urban Areas Find Ways to Grow 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE 

 BODY:
Despite the dearth of new jobs across much of the nation, some metropolitan areas around the country are growing again by selling themselves as lower-cost alternatives to more expensive cities.
 One place where this is readily apparent is the Baltimore metropolitan area, where an estimated 40,000 people living in the city and its surrounding suburbs have gained jobs since the beginning of the year, helping cut the area's unemployment rate from 5.5 percent in January to 4.8 percent in August, according to the most recent local data available. That was well below the national average and considerably better than most other major cities. 
 Baltimore has done so partly by the spillover of people and businesses from Washington, less than 50 miles away, which has much more expensive housing and has suffered from the decline of some of its high-technology industries.
In much of the country, unemployment rates are still relatively high, averaging just under 6 percent over the summer, according to the Labor Department, roughly the same as at the beginning of the year. 
But while many regions, particularly the industrial belt around the Great Lakes, the Southwest and the high-technology centers of the West Coast, are still languishing, rays of light from several areas -- like Baltimore, and in different ways, Denver and Las Vegas -- are breaking through the clouds hanging over the economy.
"People and businesses are trading down, trying to find the cheapest places to live and work," said Mark Zandi, chief economist for the research firm Economy.com.
Boston; New York; Washington; San Jose, Calif.; Portland, Ore.; and Seattle, among others, have been "paying the price," he said, as companies seeking to expand have sought cheaper areas with strong appeal to potential employees, particularly those looking for a less stressful place to live.
Unemployment in New York, for example, rose to 7.1 percent in August from 5.9 percent a year earlier; the jobless rate rose to 7 percent in Portland, from 6.3 percent, and 7.6 percent in San Jose from 5.8 percent.
With the gain in jobs in and around Baltimore has come a boom in new office space in crystalline towers and refurbished brick bastions as well.
"There has just been building after building, and everything's worked," said Raymond A. Mason, the chairman and chief executive of Legg Mason, a financial services firm based in Baltimore. "There has been no apparent diminution. The downside which some areas have seen has just never been visible."
The fallout from last September's attacks may also be helping the suburban expanse between Baltimore and Washington attract employers because of its lower visibility and the perception of greater safety compared with New York and downtown Washington. Last October was a record month for new members of the Baltimore-Washington Corridor Chamber of Commerce, which spans four suburban counties between the cities, said H. Walter Townshend, the chamber's president and chief executive.
Baltimore's efforts to cut crime and enliven its downtown also appear to have paid off. When the opportunity arose to fill a role as a less expensive substitute for Washington and other big East Coast cities like Philadelphia and New York, Baltimore was ready.
"We are making a much more conscious effort to market to Washington," said Martin O'Malley, Baltimore's mayor. "If you peel away the knocks that we had against us -- that were once founded in reality -- you find a wonderful city." 
At a home-buying fair last month organized by Live Baltimore Marketing Center, a not-for-profit organization working with the mayor's office, more than a third of the 700 people attending came from out of town. The number who ventured from the Washington area -- more than 100 prospective homeowners -- was double that of the previous fair, in May. Home prices have been rising steadily in three-quarters of Baltimore's neighborhoods, but they remain well below those in most other big East Coast cities.
Cindy Bacon, a co-owner of Obrycki's Restaurant in East Baltimore, said most of the people moving to the city appeared to be either young professionals or retirees. Those groups are the same that Persephone Meacham, property manager of the Munsey, a newly renovated luxury apartment building in downtown Baltimore, said she was seeking. Mr. Mason agreed that after recessions of recent years depleted Baltimore's industries and reduced the city's population, it became "much less of a blue-collar town."
Much of the job growth here is indeed occurring in the suburbs. In Baltimore County, which surrounds the city, some companies that held off on expansions in anticipation of the recession are now back on track, said Robert L. Hannon, the county's director of economic development.
Owings Mills, a western suburb, was the perfect place for Toyota Financial Services' new administrative nerve center, said Michael R. Groff, the company's vice president for planning and development.
"We, like a lot of companies, looked for a balance of a good place to do business, availability of affordable housing, and quality and availability of the work force," he said. More than 400 employees, about 80 percent of them hired from the local area, work in the company's new 100,000-square-foot office building.
Elsewhere in the country, Denver appears to be another beneficiary of the trading-down phenomenon. This year, despite the loss of telecom jobs, the Denver metropolitan area has gained 32,000 jobs; its unemployment rate has fallen to 5.3 percent from 6 percent.
Though job growth in greater Denver had been faster before last year's recession, and the downturn in telecommunications dealt the area some early reverses, its economy appears to be getting back on track. "We're not getting hit with huge, huge layoffs," said Patricia L. Silverstein, president of Development Research Partners in Littleton, Colo., and the Denver Metro Chamber of Commerce's consulting economist. "Most of our job hits recently have been in smaller numbers."
Joe Blake, the Denver Metro Chamber's chief executive, said that signs of a true recovery were not yet apparent. But he said this year's job growth could signal a continuation of a trend interrupted by the recession: young, well-educated workers choosing Denver's relaxed pace and high quality of life rather than settling in older business hubs.
"We have had a strong underlying growth in small business that's reflective of the entrepreneurial work force that we have here," Mr. Blake said.
Mr. Zandi also cited the Riverside area in Southern California as an increasingly attractive alternative to companies looking to put operations in less expensive places than Los Angeles, which is more than an hour's drive to the west, or the San Francisco Bay area.
In many other areas of the country, the pace of growth is being determined less by the current economic cycle than by longer-term effects, said William C. Dunkelberg, chief economist of the National Federation of Independent Business. In New England, he said, stable industries like insurance and medical care have insulated the economy from the worst of the recession's aftermath. But on and near the West Coast, there is "a huge amount of capacity in technology which is now exceptionally weak."
Mr. Dunkelberg's monthly survey of small-business owners, last conducted in August, provides a stark illustration of the weakness in the Pacific states. Only 7 percent of owners there said they planned to expand their companies in the next six months, compared with 14 percent nationwide. Sixteen percent of employers said they would shrink their work forces by February, compared with 7 percent nationwide.
Oregon and Washington, both with unemployment rates of 7 percent or higher in August, are suffering from a sharp falloff in business confidence, Mr. Dunkelberg said. The situation around Seattle could get worse, Mr. Zandi added, because of slackening in Boeing's production of aircraft.
By contrast, in the Eastern corridor from northern New Jersey to Charlotte, N.C., Mr. Dunkelberg said, business confidence is as high as in New England. One factor behind that more optimistic outlook results from the fact that the region, including greater Baltimore, is home to many of the biggest military contractors, beneficiaries of the recent emphasis on heightened national security.
Mr. Mason said Maryland was benefiting from boom times at aerospace and military specialists like Lockheed Martin, whose headquarters are in Bethesda, Md., outside Washington, and Northrop Grumman, whose electronic systems division is based in Baltimore. "All of those are thriving right now."
Despite the varying trends now perceptible across the nation, Mr. Zandi said, the differences are not as wide as they were in earlier recessions. The reasons, he said, include increased mobility of workers and capital, the continued strength of the housing markets, and the ability to use information technology to knit together far-flung enterprises.
"We have more options and information, and people are willing to use it," he said. "You don't see persistently high unemployment or low unemployment to the degree you did in the past. People will move more readily now because they can sell their home. In the last recession, even if you wanted to move, you couldn't."

HEADLINE: Pataki Campaign Has 12 Times the War Chest McCall Has as the Race Winds Down 

BYLINE:  By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

 BODY:
With 32 days until Election Day, H. Carl McCall, the Democratic candidate for governor, remains at a serious financial disadvantage. His rival, Gov. George E. Pataki, has 12 times as much money to spend in the final month of the campaign, according to documents filed yesterday.
 Mr. McCall, who is trailing in the polls and has spent the last week on the defensive against accusations of impropriety, has kept his public appearances to a minimum while trying to to raise money. 
 Records filed with the State Campaign Finance Board show he raised $596,330 in the past two weeks, spent $1.48 million during that time and now has $1.1 million left for ads, mailings and get-out-the-vote drives before Nov. 5.
That is a fraction of what Mr. Pataki and a third-party candidate, Tom Golisano, have in their campaign coffers.
Mr. Golisano, the self-financed Rochester billionaire who is the Independence Party candidate, is helping drive this race toward breaking the spending record for a statewide campaign, set at $91 million in the 2000 Senate race.
All the candidates combined -- including Andrew M. Cuomo, the Democrat who quit the race the week before the primary -- have spent nearly $89 million and are on pace to break the $119 million national record for a non-presidential contest, set in the 1998 governor's race in California.
Because Mr. Pataki did not have to weather a Republican Party primary, he was not required until yesterday to update the campaign filings from his main campaign account since July. Yesterday's filing was the first glimpse of his biggest war chest in nearly three months, and it showed he raised more than $3.4 million for it since mid-July.
The Pataki campaign has spent more than $27 million overall and raised more than $40 million since Mr. Pataki's re-election funds were established, the filing shows. Nearly $10 million of that was spent in recent weeks on a blitz that has included a series of television advertisements across the state. Mr. Pataki, a Republican seeking a third term, has about $12.2 million left, about 12 times more than Mr. McCall.
Mr. Golisano, who defeated Mr. Pataki in the Independence Party primary on Sept. 10, has spent the most, however, with $8.75 million paid out in the past two weeks. That increased his total spending to about $39.7 million.
Altogether, Mr. McCall has raised more than $12 million and spent about $11 million.
His dwindling campaign account suggests he is hampered by money problems at a time when his rivals are increasing their television advertising to capture voter interest in the pivotal final few weeks of the race.
Mr. McCall has not been helped in his fund-raising efforts by the controversy over referral letters he wrote, on state comptroller stationery, for friends and relatives seeking work at companies with business before the pension fund that Mr. McCall oversees. While insisting he had not broken any laws, he apologized Thursday for any impression of impropriety.
Mr. McCall's aides said they had expected all along that he would be outspent by his rivals, and that they did not believe the controversy slowed his fund-raising.
"It can always go better," Steven Greenberg, a spokesman for Mr. McCall, said. "But we have enough money to match the governor on TV and we know we will have enough to get a positive message out about Carl McCall and the truthful message about George Pataki."
He noted that Mr. McCall is expecting a surge of money from a fund-raiser on Oct. 23 with President Bill Clinton. McCall advisers have said that while it may seem late in the game, there was a possibility Mr. McCall's running mate, Dennis Mehiel, a millionaire, could loan the campaign money to tide it over. Mr. Mehiel has made such loans to the campaign in the past, but not during the latest filing period.
Mr. Golisano, who has set no limit on how much of his personal fortune he will tap, has done the most to push the race to record spending levels. He has made no apologies for his spending, instead criticizing Mr. Pataki for not counting in his spending reports appearances he makes in his role as governor in state-funded commercials promoting the state or its programs.
Spending has been further inflated by the Democratic primary, which was competitive until Mr. Cuomo, the former federal housing secretary, dropped out. He had raised about $12.8 million and spent about $11.3 million. Mr. Cuomo has not disclosed what he plans to do with his remaining money, though his aides have said some of it would pay off campaign debts.
Mr. Pataki spent the day upstate making announcements about economic development grants. In Rochester he doled out $1.5 million in economic aid for businesses, the latest in a series of such announcements he has made in recent weeks. Although critics have questioned the timing of the announcements, Mr. Pataki has made no apologies.
"I'm not going to stop because it happens to be October," he said.
Mr. McCall held a news conference at City Hall in New York City to attack the governor on a range of issues, saying he had not done enough to equalize wages between men and women. He also cast doubt on reports that the governor and the Republican-controlled State Senate were moving closer to an agreement on a bill, delayed for decades, that would prohibit discrimination in housing and employment on the basis of sexual orientation.
"I would think that people would see through that for what it is," Mr. McCall said. "It's an election-type ploy because they know that they don't enjoy support among communities in New York who are concerned about such legislation."

HEADLINE: For Stalled Produce, Only Bite Is at Headquarters 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: SALINAS, Calif., Oct. 4 

 BODY:
Last Sunday, Tanimura & Antle Inc., one of the nation's largest vegetable growers, shipped 20 truckloads of broccoli to the Port of Oakland to be exported to Japan and Taiwan.
 But all that broccoli is still sitting there, and Charles Schreiber, director of international sales for the Salinas company, is alarmed that the broccoli, worth $320,000, will spoil if West Coast ports do not reopen soon. 
"You feel helpless," Mr. Schreiber said. "We have 20 containers sitting there, and every day the product gets older and we can't do a thing about it. That's a hard pill to swallow." 
Worse yet, he said, is that his company, which normally exports half its produce, has many acres of broccoli and celery still to harvest, and no one knows what to do with all that fast-ripening produce. Some broccoli, he said, may be left in the field to rot.
From California's endless vegetable fields, to Washington State's bountiful apple orchards to factories in the Midwest to apparel companies in Manhattan, a similar refrain is being heard -- the weeklong shutdown of 29 seaports is starting to bite, and bite hard.
The joint General Motors-Toyota auto assembly plant in Fremont, Calif., with 5,100 workers, has shut because of a lack of parts, and auto executives say more plants will close next week. Railroads have stopped shipping Midwestern grain to the West Coast because of a backup of freight cars, and toy and apparel retailers are panicking that they may not get the hottest items in time for the holiday season.
With worries mounting daily, leaders of several industry groups met with White House officials today to describe the shutdown's escalating damage and to urge President Bush to use emergency powers to reopen the 29 ports and order the coast's 10,500 longshoremen back to work.
The ports handle half the nation's imports and exports, and while many executives and economists said a brief shutdown would have little effect, they predicted that the damage would become serious if the ports stayed closed for more than a week.
"I am surprised that more people don't see this as a national emergency, both economic and security," said David Littmann, chief economist at Comerica Bank in Detroit. "If the port shutdown were to last three to four weeks, it would essentially destroy the growth that the economy is enjoying. The damage starts at a billion dollars a day, but when you get to layoffs of truckers and the shutdown of the Toyota-G.M. plant in California and the cost increases that will turn consumers off, the damage accumulates and becomes exponential."
The economic damage is stirring a fierce political debate that has for now been overshadowed in Washington by the debate over Iraq. Business lobbyists and their Republican allies support an 80-day cooling-off period, while organized labor and many Democrats oppose it. 
In San Francisco today, the port operators and the International Longshore and Warehouse Union began a second day of talks with the top federal mediator. Port officials said progress was slow, but they said they hoped that the ports might be reopened this weekend.
After saying last Friday that they were temporarily closing the ports for 36 hours, the port operators announced an indefinite shutdown on Sunday and locked out the longshoremen, saying they were engaged in a job slowdown. Union officials said the workers were merely observing safety precautions.
With the longshoremen locked out since last Saturday, nearly 200 ships are idling in West Coast ports, waiting to be unloaded. In Hawaii, which relies heavily on imports, some stores have run out of basics, like toilet paper and canned foods. On Thursday, the Pentagon said it would begin shipping cargo to its Hawaii commissaries to make sure that the 122,000 active and retired members of the military obtain the food and other goods they need.
Alaskans, too, worried about obtaining basic goods, but the two sides agreed today to resume shipments to that state, something that is also being considered for Hawaii.
Some large retailers sought to minimize the impact of a possible port shutdown by speeding their imports last summer. But many small and medium-size companies did not have as much foresight and are being squeezed badly. Officials at Olivia Miller Inc., a fashion accessories company in Manhattan, fear that the company may be forced out of business because it has $1.2 million worth of slippers -- big sellers during the fall -- stranded on ships.
Susan Lee, Olivia Miller's chief operating officer, said: "We sell a seasonal product, and if the shutdown doesn't end soon, our products won't be able to get there in time and our customers might start canceling their orders. If this goes on a long time, we can potentially lose $1.2 million in sales."
Perhaps no businesses will be hurt more by the port closings than the thousands of farmers who grow perishable fruits and vegetables. Here in Salinas, home of John Steinbeck, some growers have delayed the harvest of their vegetables, reducing the hours of their farmworkers, hoping that the ports will reopen soon. 
For Washington's apple growers, the lockout is especially frustrating because this is one of their best crops in years. "Every day this dispute drags on represents another day of sales lost in our foreign markets, and you can't get those sales back," said Welcome Sauer, the Washington Apple Commission's president. 
Nick Kukulan, president of the Paramount Export Company, a produce exporter, estimates that $7 million in grapes, pears and other produce -- in about 350 refrigerated containers -- are stranded and inaccessible at the docks. If the ports reopen soon, he said, that aging produce may be sent quickly the domestic market and sold at a fraction of its normal value. Unless the ports reopen soon, though, he added, that produce will be good for nothing.
He said growers faced cascading problems. Not only might the stranded produce go bad, but growers might have to divert produce to the domestic market, perhaps reducing prices in a market that already pays less than export markets. Another fear is that if Asian grocers cannot stock American produce for several weeks, they may turn to growers in Europe or elsewhere, perhaps causing a long-term market loss for American agriculture. 
"This whole thing is a triple whammy for the American farmer," Mr. Kukulan said.

HEADLINE: A Proud Badge In Hartford Is Tarnished Like So Many 

BYLINE:  By PAUL ZIELBAUER

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 4 

 BODY:
For six years, Gregory J. DePietro was not just an ordinary cop. Working the toughest neighborhoods, he was considered an example of what was right with Hartford's embattled police force, hauling in some of this city's most violent drug suspects at a time when several colleagues were being indicted, tried and sent to prison for committing outrageous felonies on the job. 
 Nowadays, Greg DePietro is still no ordinary cop, but for all the wrong reasons. 
 In admissions that have stunned police officials here, Officer DePietro said that he and other Hartford officers had stolen weapons and jewelry from suspects and crime scenes, flushed drug evidence down the toilet, filched department property and fudged departmental reports during his years on the force. 
On Thursday, after a 10-month internal investigation, he resigned rather than face the likely prospect of being fired. 
For the Hartford Police Department and Chief Bruce P. Marquis, a former F.B.I. agent brought in from Texas two years ago to turn around a force stung by one high-profile embarrassment after another, Officer DePietro's revelations, reported by The Hartford Courant on Tuesday, are a humbling reminder of the work left to be done. 
But what struck many here as downright bizarre was the way in which he confessed them: during a job interview last December with the West Hartford Police Department.
His revelations came out during his second interview, as he sat with a West Hartford detective, police officials said. Officer DePietro later told investigators from his own department that he had decided to come clean to avoid being caught lying about his past during the polygraph test that the West Hartford police administer to all job candidates.
"I'm a very sensitive person," he told Hartford police investigators, according to an internal report quoted by The Courant. "I was trying to be so specific for this interview because of the fact that I was going to be wired to a lie-detector machine."
Moreover, responding to 130 yes-or-no questions given to him by the West Hartford detective, Officer DePietro affirmatively answered numerous questions about whether he had lied or stolen, and admitted that he had kept knives and narcotics seized from criminal suspects, the report said. 
On one occasion, Officer DePietro told West Hartford officials, a partner had stolen a shotgun he had found in the back of an abandoned vehicle, the report said. Another time, the officer said, he was among a group of Hartford officers who flushed what appeared to be cocaine down a station-house toilet because they did not have time to book the three suspects they had taken the package from, the report said. 
This is not what his bosses expected from Officer DePietro, 31, who won a statewide award in 1998 for bravery. And this is not what the Hartford police were hoping to hear after years of scandal. 
"This is just devastating," said Sgt. Maura Hammick, a Hartford police spokeswoman. "You feel very betrayed. Honestly, I wondered what police department he was working for." Chief Marquis was traveling out of state and could not be reached for comment, she said. 
Since 1998, seven officers or former officers have been convicted on federal charges that they coerced city prostitutes into performing sex acts in police cars, sometimes while the officers were on duty. 
Before that, a nationally recognized expert hired by the city concluded, in a meticulous audit of the department, that it was "dysfunctional" and lacking the policies, personnel and discipline needed to serve a city this size adequately.
The department is still investigating Mr. DePietro's charges implicating more than a dozen of his former colleagues, Sergeant Hammick said. But not all officers are convinced he did everything he confessed to. "A lot of things were taken out of context and hyperbolized," said Sgt. Mike Wood, the president of the police union in Hartford. 
The West Hartford police chief, James J. Strillacci, said in an interview today that no one really knows what compelled Officer DePietro, a seasoned policeman, suddenly to admit a laundry list of potential crimes. "It was possible that he was so immersed in a culture that allowed such things, that he thought he wouldn't get caught," he said.
Asked if Mr. DePietro could ever find another job at a police department, Chief Strillacci said, "I would think the news stories about him make him pretty much unemployable in law enforcement. Some people are just too dumb to be police officers."

HEADLINE: To Find Teachers, Raise Hand High and Yell, 'Me!' 

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO 

DATELINE: HAPEVILLE, Ga. 

 BODY:
Fulton County has gone digital in its search for teachers.
 In the spring, the county school district sent 10,000 CD-ROM's to student teachers around the country. To the sounds of techno music, the disc announces, "Welcome to your future" and "Exceptional salaries starting at over $36,500 yearly." 
 The recruiting campaign is working. This year, for the first time in a decade, most schools in the district opened with no teacher vacancies. 
The Fulton County schools are not alone in finding that aggressive recruiting, combined with higher salaries, can go a long way toward easing persistent teacher shortages. Similar tactics have been effective in Fulton's neighboring districts, as well as in New York City; Clark County, Nev.; and Kansas City, Kan. 
Shortages continue in many parts of the country, particularly in the West and the South. But in most other areas, the problem has eased. 
"Some districts' long-term efforts to recruit and improve working conditions and salaries, coupled with the economic downturn, have produced surpluses," said Tom Carroll, the executive director of National Commission on Teaching and America's Future, a research organization based at Teachers College at Columbia University. "But for every district that has enough teachers, somewhere else, there is a shortage."
In Georgia, where at least a dozen districts have said they are at full strength, the number of vacancies dropped to 1,500 this summer from 3,800 last summer.
"It feels right," said Juanita Nelson, the principal of Hapeville Elementary School here, who was forced to hire many uncertified teachers in previous years. "I didn't have to use even one substitute teacher this year."
Fulton County, with an annual education budget of $550 million and close to 5,000 teachers, has made a major commitment to education. In the last 10 years, teacher salaries have gone up 3 to 5 percent annually. County revenue has grown largely as a result of population growth.
Money is a big reason that Rhonda Bennett, a fifth-grade teacher at Love T. Nolan Elementary School, moved here from Tampa in July. A teacher for 10 years, Ms. Bennett was paid $32,000 a year in Florida and needed to work for the after-school programs to make ends meet. 
"We just didn't make enough," said Ms. Bennett, whose husband owns a small business. "We couldn't lead a comfortable existence."
In Fulton, Ms. Bennett is paid $51,000. Her Tampa colleagues are closely monitoring the success of her move and might follow suit. "I can be their guinea pig," she said.
Rick L. White, who is Fulton County's chief recruiter of teachers, has a budget of $100,000 a year, excluding salaries. He scours education newsletters and newspapers from far-flung cities for budget troubles and teacher layoffs. When he finds them, he places newspaper advertisements, schedules visits and snatches up the best of the newly jobless.
He and his colleagues drive the country roads of the Carolinas, Alabama, Florida and Tennessee and ride jets to Johannesburg, New Delhi and Sydney to sell Fulton to any teacher willing to listen. In the last school year, his team visited 130 job fairs and teacher conferences.
The soft economy has helped Mr. White and other recruiters. In Nevada, George Ann Rice, the chief recruiter for the Clark County School District, which includes Las Vegas, is finding she can be choosy. "We don't have to take you just because you are breathing," Ms. Rice said. "We can now only take those who will work well with children."
In New York City, where entry-level salaries rose to $39,000 this year from $31,910 last, what officials called the most crippling shortage in decades is effectively over.
But nationally the shortage remains. In Maryland, the Prince George's County and Baltimore School Districts had to hire uncertified teachers to fill 20 percent of their positions this year. In Montana, 1 in 10 certified teacher positions was open in late summer. North Dakota had to re-hire retired teachers at the last minute to fill classrooms.
The new federal education law calls for a "highly qualified" teacher in every classroom by 2006. Although the definition of "highly qualified" varies by state, districts nationwide are struggling to find certified teachers, said Mildred Hudson, chief executive of Recruiting New Teachers, a nonprofit organization.
A number of recruiters around the country complained that the legislation has made their job much harder by forcing them to compete for the limited supply of certified teachers.
Fulton County has a powerful weapon: it pays first-year teachers $36,500. The national average is $29,000, according to a report released in July by the American Federation of Teachers. 
Mr. White flaunts this advantage. The Fulton CD-ROM flashes the salary figures in bold letters. Fliers distributed at job fairs boast of the salary range, which reaches $75,000 for experienced teachers.
"I am very confident when I go recruiting," Mr. White said. "When I have my signs up, other recruiters don't want to sit next to me."
On the other hand, Montana teachers are leaving the state in large numbers, citing low pay as the No. 1 reason, according to a report commissioned by the Montana Board of Education. The state, which pays beginning teachers $21,700, ranks 49th in the nation in starting teacher salaries, with North Dakota 50th.
Good salesmanship can also play a role in filling vacancies. Ms. Rice, the recruiter for Clark County, Nev., knows how to court the qualified.
At the airport, she has put up a huge sign: "Elvis has left the building. We now have a vacancy. Call." In movie theaters, recruitment commercials are shown with the previews of coming attractions. On highways, trucks display the district's phone numbers and Web address. 
Ms. Rice also grows her own teachers. She appeals to stay-at-home mothers to take the district scholarships to get teaching degrees. "We cannot sit on our hands to wait for people to think of us," she said.
Here in Fulton County, a similarly aggressive approach helped Mr. White recruit Brittany Featherstone, 22, a native of Rochester, who had never intended to leave New York. 
The Fulton district has created a system where principals can view an application for a teaching position as soon as it is filed online. 
Although Ms. Featherstone majored in special education, one of the areas where there are severe teacher shortages, school districts in the Rochester area had been slow to respond to her applications. But on the same July day that Ms. Featherstone applied online for a teaching job at Fulton, Ms. Nelson, Hapeville Elementary's principal, called her to arrange interview. The next week, Ms. Featherstone moved to Fulton.

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN; 
The Trailing Upstate Economy

BYLINE:  By DAISY HERNANDEZ

 BODY:
 The state Democratic Party's Coordinated Campaign Committee released four 30-second advertisements attacking Gov. George E. Pataki's economic record upstate, each one slightly tailored to address local issues in Syracuse, Rochester, Buffalo and Albany. The ads are meant to help H. Carl McCall, the Democrat who is running against Mr. Pataki.

PRODUCER: Axelrod & Associates

ON THE SCREEN: A photograph of Governor Pataki and a quotation from his 1994 campaign against Mario M. Cuomo ("After eight years of broken promises, it is time for someone else") followed by images of abandoned streets, empty work lockers, construction sites and newspaper headlines charging corruption in economic development.

THE SCRIPT: Announcer, referring to the Pataki quote: "That's what George Pataki said in 1994. Well, eight years have passed. And Pataki's record? The upstate economy has trailed the nation. And Syracuse ranks near the bottom for business. Our electric rates, the second highest. All the while the state's economic development program has been mired in politics. Check Pataki's record: after eight years of broken promises, it is time for someone else."
The ad says the same for Rochester, but differs slightly for Buffalo and Albany, citing them as being last or at the bottom in job growth.

ACCURACY: Upstate New York actually had an increase in jobs under Governor Pataki, but not to the same degree as employment increased in New York City and its suburbs. The greater issue has been a shift in the economy upstate, from manufacturing to high-tech, with traditional manufacturing areas experiencing a greater loss of jobs. Electric rates are indeed among the nation's highest. Democrats have accused the governor of rewarding political supporters with economic development aid and jobs. Further, while the economy was strong, Mr. Pataki was arguably as short-sighted as the next politician in shoring up weak local economies.

SCORECARD: This ad picks up where ads by Tom Golisano, the Independence Party candidate who is needling Governor Pataki, left off. Like Mr. Golisano, the Democrats -- on behalf of Mr. McCall -- are making jobs and the upstate economy campaign issues. The ads are well timed: Mr. McCall has had trouble raising money for his own ads, and for a week he has been on the defensive over letters that he wrote in his own version of a jobs program in which he used his official stationery to pass on resumes for friends, acquaintances and family members. DAISY HERNANDEZ

GRAPHIC: Photo

HEADLINE: Masters of the Universe 

BYLINE:  By BILL KELLER; E-mail: billkeller@nytimes.com

DATELINE: MOSCOW 

 BODY:
The prime opinion-slinging show on Russian TV these days is called "Svoboda Slova," "Freedom of Speech." It's like "Crossfire" on steroids, with antagonists exchanging muscular polemics while a fever chart of audience opinion tells you who's winning the argument. The other day the subject was Iraq, and it was a depressing glimpse of how America looks these days from outside its sanctuary of self-absorption.
 One guest disputant on the Iraq side was Baghdad's ambassador to Moscow. He studied journalism in the Soviet Union, and it shows: he tried to change the subject to Hiroshima. Another was a leader of a sleazy, quasi-Fascist party in the Russian Parliament, who warned that after the power-drunk Americans devoured Iraq they would soon be nibbling at Russia's entrails. This was not a pair that radiated credibility. 
 The pro-American side was represented by a sober duet of Dmitri Simes, a conservative, Russian-born American scholar, who defended the Bush administration's case by remote feed from Washington, and the genial former foreign minister Andrei Kozyrev, who argued that Iraq had made this mess for itself by continually defying the United Nations. 
The studio audience started out 75 percent opposed to "tough measures" against Iraq, and by the time the show was over, the opposition had grown to 85 percent. You could fairly sum up the Russian consensus this way: 
* In threatening Iraq, President Bush is mainly after cheap oil, and probably some cheap votes in the next election. 
* America may pretend to be promoting lofty democratic ideals, just as the Soviet Union pretended to be exporting Socialist ideals. But America likes the tyrants who serve its interests. Saddam -- like Osama bin Laden's compatriots in Afghanistan -- was once a beneficiary of American largess, back when he was fighting Iran, and he might still be on the American dole if he hadn't tried to kill the first President Bush.
* The Bush overtures to the U.N. are laughably insincere, a belated effort to dress up an attack that is foreordained.
* Whatever happens, it will be bad for Russia (self-pity is the Russian default position) and terrible for ordinary Iraqis.
* America could care less about that.
From Russians I've talked to, that indictment seems to be pretty much the mainstream view. Many Russians now see us the way we once saw them -- expansionist bullies, disguising our appetite as humanitarian vision. The fact that much of this attitude stems from a post-Soviet inferiority complex doesn't make it any prettier to hear.
To what extent the inscrutable Vladimir Putin shares his countrymen's cynicism is hard to know. The Russian president has played the situation like the judo black belt he is. He has already invoked the new Bush Doctrine of defensive pre-emption against neighboring Georgia, where the Pankisi Gorge has been a highway for separatists bedeviling Russia in the province of Chechnya. This bluff accomplished three things: It got Washington's attention; it delighted the Russian military, which still loathes Georgia's president, Eduard Shevardnadze, for humiliations he inflicted as Mikhail Gorbachev's foreign minister; and it seems to have prodded Mr. Shevardnadze into cracking down harder on the rebels.
Mr. Putin has also rushed to shore up his commercial ties with Iran, Iraq and North Korea, the countries the White House insists on calling "the axis of evil." Hardly anyone seriously believes Mr. Putin feels any ideological kinship with those three regimes, but they just happen to be among the few countries that buy Russian manufactured goods.
If you believe (as I do) that Saddam Hussein represents an insufferable menace, and that a convincing preparation for war is a prerequisite for any serious reckoning with him, it is tempting to dismiss the nattering of the Russian elites. We can be sure that President Putin -- the calculating pragmatist -- will swallow our Iraq venture, as he has swallowed our intervention in the Balkans, the expansion of NATO, the discarding of the ABM treaty, the basing of American troops in nearby Central Asia and the various other take-it-or-leave-it Bush administration initiatives. Astute Putin-watchers, like Dmitri Trenin of the Carnegie Moscow Center, say that although Mr. Putin may still have the democratic instincts of a former K.G.B. spymaster, he knows he has no real choice but to cast Russia's lot with the West. 
But just because we can is no reason to treat Russia as little more than a speed bump. This is not just about Saddam Hussein, or just about Russia. It is about what kind of superpower we want to be -- one that wins over potential friends, or one that simply bulldozes them. The view from Russia, shared in many other places around the globe, is that we are wearing our might with more than a little childish arrogance.
A few days after that TV debate I visited Mr. Kozyrev, the former foreign minister, in the McMansionland suburb where he now lives the life of a prosperous businessman. One of his ventures is public relations, and so I had the odd experience of being gently lectured on the basics of salesmanship by a former official of the former anti-capitalist empire. "You're like a big business that decided it doesn't need a P.R. department," he told me. "But every business needs P.R. Even a monopoly needs P.R." 
That's an argument our marketing-minded White House understands when it comes to domestic public opinion. It should consider applying it to the rest of the world. Our imperial bluster feeds our enemies and isolates our friends. We've just seen that resentment of America wins elections in Germany, and it would be a shame if it cost us the good will of a Russia that, most of the time, wants to be with us.
To be fair, the Bush administration has handled Russia with more skill than anyone had a right to expect. The relationship shows signs of a maturity that the tempestuous love affair between Bill Clinton and Boris Yeltsin rarely achieved, and that is not just because Mr. Putin shows up sober. But even discounting for the excesses of Russian pride, it still often feels we're taking the place for granted.
If we wanted Russia to be a willing partner rather than just a grudging partner, there are several things we could do. We could treat the United Nations as more than a distraction. The place may be an infuriating tunnel of winds, but for a lot of countries it is the closest thing to feeling enfranchised in world affairs. First we refused to accept that the U.N. had a part to play, and now, after it dawned on us that the organization can be useful, we are treating it with undisguised petulance.
We could acknowledge that other counties have legitimate interests. In Russia, trade with countries America doesn't like is not just a luxury; it sustains a slow progress toward economic normalcy. It would not kill us to offer some public assurances that Russia's genuine economic stake in Iraq will be protected if Saddam is overthrown. We could also make clear that we will not use conquered Iraq to drive down the price of oil in a way that would threaten other suppliers, including Russia. (This week's Russian-American oil conference in Houston, little noticed in our country, was a good first step and has made a large and favorable impression here.)
Elsewhere along the axis, we could stop scolding Russia for the sale of nuclear power plants to Iran, and look harder for a collaborative way to make sure that these deals do not end up delivering nuclear weaponry to the ayatollahs. Russia is no more eager than we are to give Iran the ingredients of a nuclear weapon, but the Russian nuclear power industry is a very large and hungry constituency. We co-opted Russia's space industry by cooking up joint launch ventures; we could at least try to co-opt its nuclear industry.
An easier way to win a bit of good will here and in many other countries is to streamline the new post-9/11 rules for visas. There is now a backlog of 25,000 visitor applications stalled, not because they are at all suspicious but because the vetting operations are overwhelmed. Among the applicants are hundreds of Russian scientists and graduate students in sensitive subjects like biological and nuclear technology, whom we invited to the U.S. because we'd rather they not go to, say, Syria. 
And then down at the level of pure, pointless insult there is that durable relic of the cold war, the Jackson-Vanik law. This is American legislation that denies Russia the normal courtesies of international commerce because, many years ago, the Soviets prevented Jews from emigrating. Emigration is now so relaxed that much of Israel speaks with a Russian accent, and everyone from the White House on down agrees the law should have been repealed years ago -- except for a small-minded poultry-state congressman who is blocking repeal because the Russians limited the import of American chicken parts. 
A decent regard for the opinion of places like Russia would make it easier for leaders like Mr. Putin to be with us. Arrogance and pettiness isolate our friends, build resentment and ultimately undermine our campaign against terror. It is possible to get Iraq right and get the rest of the world wrong.

HEADLINE: North Korea's Turning Point 

BYLINE:  By Bradley O. Babson; Bradley O. Babson, a former World Bank representative in Vietnam, is a consultant on Asian matters for the bank and the United Nations.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Today a first set of talks will conclude between James Kelly, assistant secretary of state for East Asia, and the government of North Korea. Although Chairman Kim Jong Il and his Communist regime are part of President Bush's axis of evil, Washington has opted to pursue regime transformation rather than regime change. This engagement has been a long time in coming. But North Korea has been trying for years, in its own awkward and eccentric way, to get closer to the outside world, and Washington, together with Tokyo, has finally chosen to respond.
 The challenge facing Mr. Kelly is how to pitch dialogue in ways that will result in North Korean commitments that are congruent with American aims. Fundamentally, what is needed is to create an atmosphere of hope that is based on realism. Realism must acknowledge the many difficulties that North Korea's leaders face in redirecting their security, economy and society to join a world that operates on a very different basis than theirs. Realism means that North Korea cannot expect the world to subsidize its needs for food and energy indefinitely. Realism means being skeptical about grandiose schemes and not overreacting when they fail; and it means making sure that agreements with North Korea will meet a test of both political and economic rationality. 
 North Korea is undeniably at a crossroads. Hope for rapid change dimmed after the shock of a battle at sea between the two Koreas last June. But the fact that this incident did not derail cooperation on other fronts -- and was quickly resolved at the political level -- is an indication of how inter-Korean relations have matured since the summit of 2000. Now we have news from the North of homegrown economic reforms that will give money and profit incentives a much greater role. Price and wage increases and devaluation of the currency have reduced the large gap between the official and informal economies. Moves to revive industry include imposing firm budget constraints on state enterprises, decentralizing economic planning and allowing commercial transactions between firms.
While these reforms are only a beginning, they clearly indicate the North Korean government's decision to change the economic system. Legislation recently adopted by the Supreme People's Assembly in Pyongyang to establish a Hong Kong-style special administrative zone on North Korea's border with China also demonstrated North Korea's willingness to try bold initiatives, even grandiose ones. 
Chairman Kim has also surprised observers by admitting past wrongs in relations with Japan -- in exchange for a normalization that will bring political recognition, access to Japanese markets and an assistance package. Mr. Kim also decided, at last, to start work on the inter-Korean rail and road links that will breach the demilitarized zone. This is literally a breakthrough moment.
All of these moves by Kim Jong Il in the space of three months seem to point to the kind of major changes in behavior that President Bush is seeking. Economic pressures, the humiliation of seeing North Korean citizens fleeing over the border into China, and the changes in the international climate after Sept. 11, 2001, are factors that Kim Jong Il cannot ignore. However, the tasks that lie ahead of his regime are not easy: overcoming decades of isolation, bringing North Korean society into meaningful reconciliation with South Korea and Japan, being accepted into the international community and building an economy that works.
Neither the United States nor North Korea should expect sudden, extensive change. A patient and realistic step-by-step approach has been characteristic of the sunshine policy of South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung. It deserves to be given a chance in dialogue with the United States. As a way to meet President Bush's goal of removing North Korea from the axis of evil, it just might work.
