HEADLINE: Hip-ification 

BYLINE:  By Jim Nelson; Jim Nelson is an executive editor at GQ.

 BODY:
There are countless reasons that certain neighborhoods become hip -- why Fort Greene, say, or NoLIta suddenly buzzes with a new energy. And in the constant flux of the city, it's difficult to pinpoint the moment any newly revived neighborhood turns that vital corner. But something happened on Clinton Street three and a half years ago, something small and unexpected, that would transform that fusty old part of the Lower East Side for years to come. This is what happened: Dewey Dufresne went walking. 
 It was April 1999, and he was turning a corner himself, puttering up Clinton from Rivington, where he lived. Dufresne, a middle-aged man, sometime chef and general handyman ("I do odd jobs" is how he puts it) is a staple in the neighborhood, having moved there in 1993 when many considered it rough. He was walking that day with his old friend Janet Nelson, who used to work with him at a restaurant and who lived in his building. As they strolled up Clinton, they talked about opening a new restaurant. But the economy was booming; landlords in lowly Hell's Kitchen were asking upward of $10,000 in rent, and the East Village was even more expensive. That's when Dufresne saw it: the abandoned restaurant at 71 Clinton, a building he had passed a thousand times. It looked pathetic -- the greasy, gutted remains of Ray's Chirpin' Chicken. But the space was empty, a blank slate. 
 They looked into it. The rent was a bargain: $2,000 a month. When Dennis Cooleen, one of their eventual partners in the restaurant that would become 71 Clinton Fresh Food, heard about the deal, he couldn't get over the price. "It was cheaper than my apartment," he says. There was only one problem: nobody he knew had ever heard of Clinton Street. (Clinton sits on the eastern cusp of the Lower East Side, near the Williamsburg Bridge. It runs north from South Street to Houston, after which it turns into Avenue B.) But he, too, had searched unsuccessfully for affordable spaces, and he concluded, "The only way to go is down."
At the time, Clinton Street was a world apart from the East Village. The area, once a haven for Jews and other early American immigrants, had in recent decades been populated mostly by working-class Hispanics, first Puerto Ricans and then Dominicans. Until the fall of 1999, the businesses on Clinton all catered to them: Spanish-language video stores, salsa record shops, international telephone calling stations and food stands serving cuchifritos and comidas criollas. Chinese and Koreans had slipped in, bringing nail salons and $3 manicures. But rather than seeming like a vibrant oasis of local commerce and ethnic pride, the street had a down-and-out feel -- tamped down, cowed. Many of the shops were struggling to stay afloat against a relentless stream of drug traffic. During the Giuliani administration, the police chased away some of the crime. But in '99, heroin and crack dealers still worked the pay phones all along the street. Rent was cheap if you wanted it: some of the old businesses were paying less than $800 a month, residents about $1,000 for a two-bedroom apartment.
Yet there was change quietly brewing. A trickle of young people, many of them musicians and artists unable to find affordable downtown rents in the boom of the 90's, had begun to move in. (The cleanup of Tompkins Square Park in 1992, in particular, made the East Village more attractive and more expensive, pushing people south.) Some musicians and artists had been living in the Clinton Street area for years, but this was an uptick. The locals noticed it and started calling the new arrivals los blanquitos. The "little white ones" gravitated toward a lone coffee shop, Lotus Club, on the corner of Clinton and Stanton -- a drab but endearing bohemian hangout, with lattes and used books, which opened in 1997. Otherwise, the blanquitos tended to go west, to places like the Mercury Lounge up on Houston or the already settled streets of Orchard and Ludlow.
These latter streets -- particularly Ludlow -- had already undergone a quick evolution, seeming to get hip and then unhip in record time. The street raged hard in the early 90's with new bars and music venues, but the scene quickly became loud and overrun. Yet the Ludlow phenomenon had proved something: outsiders would venture to previously neglected corners of the East Side if they felt there was something abuzz.
The people who turn neighborhoods hip these days -- the more pioneering restaurateurs and boutique operators -- tend to smell change in the air simultaneously. They walk the same forgotten blocks of the city at the same time, sensing something actionable. Sure enough, just as the 71 Clinton crew were designing their space, many of the key players who would shape Clinton Street were already moving in and around the neighborhood.
These players -- you might call them early scouters -- were a relatively small lot. In the months before the fall of 1999, a handful or so of people were looking at the neighborhood in a unique way, appraising its potential, sometimes without even knowing they were doing so. The scouters had a few things in common: many had run a shop or restaurant before in other, once-forsaken parts of the city. They liked being on the edge of things, being the first on the block and having others follow them. And, on a more subtle level, they were able to sense something -- an emergent energy. It was almost subarticulate. "If you'd heard about the Lower East Side, you might think: Oh, no, not there," says Juan Carlos Rodriguez, a Spaniard who began construction on his tapas bar, 1492 Food, just as the people across the street were building 71 Clinton. "But as soon as you went walking, you felt something. The street was very particular."
Buket Hasman, a young Turkish woman, felt the same way, and she opened a women's clothing boutique, Mina, a month after 71 Clinton opened. She and the other new merchants who wound up moving to Clinton mention the same small but significant draws: the appeal of the trees when they first saw them -- the Callery pear trees that were planted on the north end in the 1990's and explode each spring like cherry blossoms. And, curiously, absolutely everyone mentions the gentle pace the street had in the morning and afternoon, before the drug runners came out at night. The light traffic made the street a pleasant place to be.
This might seem a trifling matter, but until 1994, the direction of traffic on Clinton moved north. This meant that the street was used as a bustling pathway for motorists getting off the Williamsburg Bridge and connecting, via Houston, to the F.D.R. Drive. The constant stream of commuters gave the street the sense that it was always under siege. But in 1994, because of construction on the bridge, the Department of Transportation reordered things. Traffic on Clinton, between Houston and Delancey, started moving south. The pace instantly slackened, giving the street that "feeling" newcomers talk about. It also opened up Clinton Street to taxis and bike-riders, encouraging a downtown flow from the East Village and elsewhere. Some say it also helped to stanch, or at least redirect, the drug traffic that was coming off the Williamsburg Bridge and looping back around into Brooklyn.
But it wasn't until 71 Clinton Fresh Food made its debut in October 1999 that the changes on the street became visible. "We didn't go into it with the idea that we would start a scene," Janet Nelson says. "We thought we would be opening a restaurant that would be moderately priced, have a nice, local atmosphere." But in the end, there was nothing local about it -- certainly not the design, which was sleek and aggressively modern (exposed brick, vinyl banquettes, tangerine and green walls). The cool exterior, with its wall of aluminum and glass fronting on Clinton, acted as a kind of signifier of a new way of being on the street.
It was the food, however, that spoke most loudly. Originally, Dewey Dufresne was supposed to be the cook, but then he had the bright idea of bringing his chef-son, Wylie, out from Las Vegas, where he had earned a reputation as a rising star at Jean-Georges Vongerichten's Prime. The extravagant menu he devised took everyone by surprise. These were dishes the Lower East Side had never seen: edamame-and- rye-bread-crusted sea bass, duck with a bok- choy-and-confit baton. And though most of the people who lived in the neighborhood could not afford $20 entrees, the prices were markedly lower than those of uptown restaurants.
The critics swooned, and soon the house was packed every night with destination diners. They'd line up outside, hoping to nab one of the 30 seats, chattering on their cellphones and hanging out near the bodega next door, looking at first a little lost and scared. 
Witnessing the scene at 71 Clinton -- the line of cars; the willingness of people to "go slumming" in the Lower East Side -- others swung into action. Within months, local real-estate agents were sending out commercial flyers advertising available spaces in the neighborhood and encouraging new businesses to piggyback on the success of 71 Clinton. 
"The place became an adventure area to trek to from other areas," says Dewey Dufresne, whose kindly voice seems incapable of relaying the sarcasm he sometimes intends. Uptowners found the place a little edgy. "They saw homeboys on the street and thought they might be dangerous." And so, he says, "a little mystique was born."
Is it mystique that made Clinton Street hip? Partly. But it is also true that what we think of as hip has changed over the years. Hipness, as a concept, grew out of the Beats and later the hippies, artists and intellectuals of the 60's. Back then, hipness was closely attached to bohemia. To be hip was to lead a free, creative and open life. People who were hip to things were politically engaged, knew art, knew culture. But cultural values have moved on, become more consumerist. Today, bohemia is seen as unproductive. What is hipness? Hipness means keeping up with music and fashion, going to the newest shops, restaurants and wine bars, knowing the menu deeply or the chef personally. Media matters in this regard, and the food Web sites and travel guides were a crucial factor in sealing Clinton Street's fate as a hip destination. And while 71 Clinton began as a destination, it wound up reacting with its local elements and, unexpectedly, shaped the neighborhood to come. 
These days, Dewey Dufresne wears a tool belt most of the time -- he and his son have left 71 Clinton to build WD-50, a new restaurant at 50 Clinton. But to watch him interact with the other business owners and residents on the streets is to see a true believer subtly infecting others. Almost every new store on Clinton has a story about how Dewey helped it get started. "The father, he helped me from the beginning," says Rodriguez of 1492. It wasn't just that Dufresne would dispatch his overflow customers to 1492. He also loved to go over and talk shop with the owner, parsing the subtleties of restaurants, how the size of your window or the pitch of your door could affect business, almost tutoring Rodriguez.
Neil Kleinberg had a similar experience. He pounced on the space that would become Clinton Street Baking Company in April 2001, after carefully watching the block, witnessing the rise of 71 Clinton and the new businesses that followed. By then, landlords had started to pine for the big money they felt they could be making. Some were now asking $4,000 and $5,000 for commercial spaces. Kleinberg found a space for $3,200, cheap by some standards but significantly more than 71 Clinton's rent. Soon after, Dewey persuaded him to expand his operations from breakfast-only. "He told me, 'You guys should start doing soups in the wintertime.' They've been really successful. And that segued into lunch crowds."
But what you really see in Dewey Dufresne is the walking reality that some people think deeply about neighborhoods -- about every aspect of how, say, a street or a corner or light or pavement might interact with human commerce. He can talk, almost romantically, about how some streets have soul and some don't but then dismiss as sentimental claptrap the notion that the revival of Clinton was inevitable. ("People think this is the magic street -- until they fail.") He does believe that the northern two blocks of Clinton are charmed, but that third block? No soul. There are no trees; the sidewalks are more cramped; it's too close to Delancey -- a huge beast of a street with bridge traffic. "You need a block to get over Delancey." But he also explains that the guiding principle of the neighborhood was a determined opposition: "Everyone was driven by the idea that this should not be another Ludlow." 
Clinton Street would never have become hip if there weren't a collision of some sorts -- one world brushing up against another, conjuring issues of race and class, of what came before and what may come. Many of the new arrivals in the neighborhood and even some of the older residents say that they love the multiethnic vibe right now, the infusion of young people, and that this feels hip and exciting. But it also feels as if it may threaten the neighborhood. Hipness thrives off the energy of change, and that change often ends, ineluctably, in gentrification. (Meanwhile, hipness moves on: to be hip is to ride the wave before it.) Gentrification brings tensions, as the new neighbors see the place differently from their predecessors. 
Take that "multiethnic vibe." Dennis Cooleen of 71 Clinton says he has seen "a 25 percent increase in 30-something white people" in the neighborhood in the last few years. His landlord at Alias, the 71 Clinton offshoot on the corner of Rivington, is Henry Hallivis, a Cuban-American who has been living in the area since 1960. Hallivis says that until recently the neighborhood was "maybe 80 percent Spanish, 5 or 10 percent black and the rest, white Americans." Now, he says, "it's 80 percent white." Huh? The figure seems too high. "Well, I'm talking about walking on the streets. Maybe living around here, it's still the same percentage." In effect, this is the new neighborhood: a mix of long-term locals and new arrivals, usually white, who have money to drop and who drop it on different things from the old residents.
Restaurants hold a special sway. When the 71 Clinton team expanded to Alias (they kept the facade of the old Dominican restaurant they replaced), they managed to secure a rent lower than those of other new businesses, because of their track record on the street. Yet Hallivis charges residents upstairs higher rents than he charges the restaurant. "I'll tell you why," he says. "You need the new restaurants, and you need them to survive. You charge too much, they're going to flee, and then where is the neighborhood?" Hallivis also owns and runs the faded old jewelry store next door to Alias, with its foreboding walls of bulletproof glass -- relics from the bad drug days, when his mother was shot in there (she survived). He says the era of his sort of business is over. "Me, I'm a jeweler," he says. "I'm outdated." A few months ago, he asked the owners of 71 Clinton if they wanted to come in here and revamp the place, make it into another restaurant. "They said they'd think about it," he says. "That would be nice."
Yes, Clinton is hip for the moment, but it is as if two parallel worlds were co-existing. If you stand in the Z-Speed shoe store run by Josie Alvarez and her dad, Orlando, who are Dominicans, all the foot traffic sauntering slowly into the store is Hispanic. Shoes sell for $19.99 to $29.99. "I think maybe I should upgrade my merchandise," she says uncertainly.
Even the issue of traffic is a loaded one. When the direction changed in '94, many of the old shops protested. They felt the "quiet" imposed on them decimated their businesses. They were used to a different type of traffic, not the Town Cars from Manhattan but the buses from Brooklyn, and they lobbied for a change. In June, after bridge construction was finished, the traffic returned to its old pattern. Most of the Dominican merchants say that, though it is too early to tell, they haven't felt a difference, but everyone agrees the street is louder again.
To some degree, the changes on Clinton simply follow a larger narrative -- the historical flow of Manhattan's restless energy. Neighborhoods become hip for a while, then the energy moves on. And historically, that flow has drifted ever south and east. The path isn't unwavering -- the meatpacking district didn't revive until recently, and there are always various neighborhoods throughout the city undergoing rebirths (Smith Street, Williamsburg and so on) -- but Clinton was perfectly situated to meet the southern flow from the East Village and the eastward flow from SoHo. Still, that doesn't explain the full extent of Clinton Street's "discovery." Some of the new faces on the street are tourists who have read about the scene on Clinton -- the modern ritual of neighborhoods as tourist destinations. Dennis Cooleen sees a lot of them eating at 71 Clinton. He says it makes him feel that "New York has become almost like a resort town."
And if the Lower East Side has become a tourist destination, how long will Clinton Street last? Will it burn out like Ludlow? There are signs it may be on its way. There is talk that a W Hotel may be built on Rivington, just blocks from 71 Clinton. (Bring in the tourists!) Lotus Club has transformed in five years from a boho coffee shop to a loud bar/nightclub, replete with D.J.'s. Or, more subtly, consider the case of the buzzer: when Buket Hasman opened Mina in November 1999, she installed a buzzer to let customers in, she says, "for security reasons." The neighborhood was still a little scary, and she was often working alone. In September 2001, when Alife Rivington Club, a discreet designer sneaker store, opened a block and a half away, it installed a buzzer to instill an air of exclusivity. "We wanted it to be a destination store," says Sara Fisher, an associate. "And a lot of that is word of mouth. And the buzzer says that." Here you have the cycle of hipness: less than two years for a security device to become a fetish object.
But there are contrary signs that Clinton Street will continue to flourish. Mitchell Moss, a professor of urban planning at N.Y.U., says he thinks Clinton Street and the rest of the Lower East Side "is going to continue for a very long time." He contrasts it to the model of SoHo, which he says is a victim of its own successes. "SoHo is the real tourist destination because they don't sell anything unique. It's a showcase for products that are available everywhere." Clinton, he says, will keep its edge "because of one thing: the character of the buildings. Since the buildings are all small, the businesses are always going to be driven by individual entrepreneurs. People will always seek that out." 
You can always ask the unofficial professor of the street, Dewey Dufresne. He notes that the activity on Clinton is bouncing toward Ludlow, starting on the side streets of Stanton and Rivington and moving west. "Yes, the revival is drifting back, making corrective measures," he says -- bringing more than just loud bars Ludlow's way. "Soon it'll all connect and be one great neighborhood."
So you listen to him when he tells you what he thinks the next new neighborhood might be. "The revival will move further south," he says, "making the great leap over Delancey Street that has always seemed impossible." And then he picks a winner. "I like Allen Street. South of Delancey, it's really got soul. These great old, underutilized buildings, open spaces. Allen's like a European street, with that great, green divider down the middle. You watch: people are going to start opening up new places down there. It's Chinatown, but it's not really," he says. "It's a blank slate."

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 91

LENGTH: 3911 words

HEADLINE: The Kid And His Council 

BYLINE:  By John Colapinto; John Colapinto, a contributing editor to Rolling Stone, is the author of "As Nature Made Him" and the novel "About the Author."

 BODY:
It's easy to underestimate Gifford Miller, the 32-year-old speaker of the New York City Council. Riding the elevator on a visit to Con Ed headquarters on Irving Place, Miller stands dwarfed between the two security agents who escort him everywhere. On the short side, with a baby face framed by jug ears, he looks like a boy on a school field trip -- an impression hardly softened by his account of an Abba concert he attended the night before on Coney Island. "It was, like, not really Abba," he says. "It was some of the original supporting band members and then, like, look-alikes -- which was better actually."
 The elevator doors open, and Miller is led to a boardroom with windows looking onto a large chamber known, since Sept. 11, when it became the focus of efforts to restore power to Lower Manhattan, as the War Room. Technicians tap at keyboards beneath large blinking maps and computer screens. 
 "Wow," Miller says. "Cool." 
As he is shaking hands with Lou Rana, vice president of Manhattan Electric Operations, the Con Ed department that oversees electricity distribution to the borough, something catches his attention in the War Room. 
"That's my district," Miller says, gesturing toward a map of the Upper East Side. "Something just happened on Roosevelt Island."
There's a sudden edge in his voice, an authority that erases all trace of the kid in him. Rana studies the map, then turns back to Miller. 
"They lost power for a second," Rana says. "Probably an overload in a circuit. Another one picked up the slack. That was totally transparent." 
Miller decodes the jargon instantly. "Meaning customers didn't notice?" 
"Exactly."
For the next hour, Miller repeatedly interrupts Rana's carefully taught Power Grid 101 seminar, peppering him with questions. He wants to know how quickly electricity moves through wires and how transformers step down 138,000 volts of electricity to the 120 volts that power a clock radio. You can see Miller's mind working to identify any wastefulness in the system. By the time he saunters back to the elevator with his security detail, you have the feeling that he has managed, in 60 minutes, to master the entire network that brings power to every home and business in the City of New York. 
But then, an understanding of the dynamics of power -- specifically political power -- has long been a special gift of Miller's. It's one factor in his amazingly swift rise to Council speaker, where as leader of the government's legislative branch, he is widely regarded as the second-most powerful elected official in New York, just below the mayor. The other factor has been Miller's singular talent for never appearing too hungry, too ambitious or too driven. Five years ago, as a rookie Democratic council member, he tended to be portrayed as an affable, if ineffectual, son of privilege -- basically a joke," in Miller's own phrase. But today, his colleagues in government are beginning to reassess practically everything about him. 
"I think he's keenly savvy politically," says James S. Oddo, a Republican councilman from Staten Island and the Council's minority leader. "I think he's relentless. And I think many an opponent will meet his or her Waterloo by underestimating Gifford Miller." Asked if the speaker is aware of the political advantage to being underestimated, Oddo chuckles. "He's too smart not to be aware of it."
That Miller has ambitions beyond the speakership is clear, given that he has already amassed more than $400,000 toward an "unspecified" political campaign he plans to undertake in 2005 -- which just happens to be when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg comes up for re-election. At first, Miller plays coy when asked about his desire to become mayor. "I'm a laid-back guy," he insists. But when pressed on the point, Miller finally drops his perennial boyishness and shows a little of the steeliness that lies beneath. "Look," he says, impatiently. "I believe in being prepared. I'm 32 years old. This is not the end of my career. I certainly intend to find exciting ways to contribute to a city I love. It's tough to go up from speaker. But I guess it's doable."
Miller grew up on Fifth Avenue and 98th Street, where the Upper East Side blends into East Harlem. The Miller family was steeped in politics. His father, Leigh, was a state department official in the Kennedy and Johnson administrations. His mother, Lynden, is a widely respected designer of public gardens, having spearheaded an early-1980's restoration of the Conservatory Garden on Fifth Avenue and then gone on to design Wagner Park, Bryant Park and parts of the New York Botanical Garden. Both his parents served on Community Board 11 in East Harlem when Miller was growing up, and he credits his parents' intense community involvement with having instilled in him a spirit of enthusiasm about public service and a deep love for New York City. 
But if Miller harbored an early yen for elected office, he kept it well hidden. At his prep school, St. Bernard's, on the Upper East Side, he evinced little interest in current events. "I didn't read the paper cover to cover as a kid," he says. "I read the sports pages." He did, however, make a foray into politics at Middlesex, the elite boarding school that he attended in Concord, Mass., with his younger brother, Marshall, who is now an assistant United States attorney. "He did run for president of the school," Marshall says. "But he lost miserably."
Miller studied political science at Princeton, but by all accounts he was not drawn to student government. In his senior year, he began dating Pamela Addison (who would later become his wife and the mother of their two children, Addison, who is 22 months old, and Marshall, who is 5 months old). She says that at Princeton, Miller had no clear plans beyond graduation -- and certainly none for elected office. "There are always those people in college who you're pretty sure are already running for president of the United States," she says. "That absolutely wasn't Gifford." 
Indeed, upon his graduation in 1992, Miller demonstrated every symptom of a young man adrift. He traveled briefly, then his mother helped get him a job with the Parks Department. But that fall, Bill Clinton was elected president, ending the Republican reign that had begun with Ronald Reagan's election 12 years earlier. Miller's leanings were always liberal, and coming of age in the 1980's had been, Miller says, frustrating. "I was no fan of Ronald Reagan," he says. "There is a certain politics of greed that I reject." Miller was galvanized by Clinton's victory. "One of the things I admire about him was that he made a real effort to try to lift people up with things like the earned-income tax credit. And when he won, I thought I'd go to Washington and try to work for him, get a job doing whatever." 
He drove down to Washington to hunt up a job. He failed to find one, but shortly after his return to New York, Miller was hired as an aide to Carolyn Maloney, a Democrat newly elected to Congress. Formerly a city councilwoman from the Millers' district, Maloney was close with Miller's parents: she had appointed them to the local community board, and they had contributed money to her Congressional campaign. Hired to answer mail and phones for Maloney, he rose swiftly to become her chief of staff. 
"As soon as he got involved in politics," his wife says, "he quickly became enamored with it. Gifford got me so excited about Clinton's first budget reconciliation that I just assumed it was national news, that everyone in the country was sitting on the edge of their seats wondering what would happen. We stayed up until 3 in the morning watching the vote, and I called my mother the next day and she had no idea what I was talking about. So he was very infectious even at that stage." 
Miller served for three years with Maloney, then decided to make his own first foray into electoral politics. Charles Millard, the Republican city councilman for an Upper East Side district, had left in the middle of his term to take a job in the Giuliani administration, thus opening up his seat for a special midterm election. Miller decided to try for it. It was 1995, and he was just 26. 
Miller threw himself into his first election campaign like a man on a tight deadline to succeed. That December, despite record snowfalls that paralyzed the city, Miller and a small army of volunteers campaigned in the streets for 12 straight days, collecting some 7,000 signatures, more than seven times the number necessary to get on the ballot. "He'd get up at 7 a.m. and work till midnight," says Eva Moskowitz, a former college professor who acted as Miller's field coordinator for that election and who is today a councilwoman and Miller's appointee as chairwoman of the Education Committee. Pamela Miller saw a side of her husband that she never suspected existed. "Here's this guy whom most people at Princeton might describe as kind of shy, certainly somewhat insular, who turns out to be literally the most effective street campaigner," she says. "It's the strangest thing. He absolutely loves it, will spend 12 hours a day on the street. It was just weird." 
Miller's combination of brains, relentless campaigning and easy charm paid off: he beat his Republican opponent, Judith Marcus (a veteran of East Side politics), thus becoming the youngest member of the city's Legislature elected up to that time. Ten months later he handily defended his Council seat in a November 1996 election. 
If Miller owes his meteoric rise, in part, to tireless hard work, he has also had generous doses of pure luck. In 1993, a citywide referendum established term limits for council members, holding them to two consecutive four-year terms. As a result of this, 38 of Miller's fellow council members were slated to be swept from office in 2001 -- including Speaker Peter F. Vallone. Improbable as it seemed, this would leave Miller, at 32 and with only six years of experience in the Council, as the legislature's senior elected official and its most seasoned member, and thus a not wholly unlikely front-running candidate for speaker in 2002. 
Typically, many council members and pundits didn't give Miller much of a chance. "Gifford works extremely hard, but he's got a lot to learn," one council member told the Times in 1997. "I can't quite imagine him as speaker." For his own part, Miller treated the talk of his becoming speaker as a joke. "Believe it or not," he said at the time, "I have a strong sense of my own irrelevance." Privately, however, he was hatching a strategy to seize his once-in-a-lifetime chance to snag the Council's top spot. Today, he admits that his eyes were on the speakership all along. "Why would you run for City Council and not want to be the speaker?" he says. 
Recognizing that the leader of the city's legislative body should have some legal training, Miller quickly enrolled in Fordham University's night law school. Then he got to work trying to minimize the biggest perceived liability he faced in his plan to become speaker: his background of privilege on Manhattan's Upper East Side. The Council speaker is elected not by the public but by fellow council members -- many of whom hail from districts with a healthy skepticism toward Ivy League prepsters from the Silk Stocking district. 
"Everybody was saying, 'A white guy from Manhattan can never win,"' recalls Moskowitz, who also worked on Miller's speakership bid. "It's not going to happen."' But Miller had a plan. He would, he decided, in the two years leading up to the vote, travel to all of the other 50 districts. He would meet and get to know the Council candidates in each district; he would decide which one looked like a winner; and then he would offer his services as a campaigner, money-raiser and supporter to get that person elected. Nothing like it had ever been tried before. "For every one person who said, 'This is a great idea,"' recalls Christine Quinn, a councilwoman from Manhattan and one of Miller's closest allies, "25 said: 'This is a terrible idea. It's unorthodox; you're going to make people mad by going into their district. For however many winners you support, you'll support losers."' But Miller stuck to the plan, and in 1999 he embarked on two years of ceaseless campaigning in every corner of the city, in all weather, at all times of day. The strategy proved almost diabolical in its multileveled effectiveness: Miller got to know the whole city; he proved that he was not a politician confined, geographically and ideologically, to the Upper East Side; and he also made those council members whom he helped elect subtly indebted to him. In early 2002, the newly elected Council voted for a new speaker. Several members initially ran for the job but ultimately wound up supporting Miller, who won in a unanimous vote, 51 to 0. 
Little wonder that today, when you ask Miller's fellow council members for their chief impression of him, their answers invariably echo that of Charles Barron, the former Black Panther who is today a councilman from Brooklyn and one of those for whom Miller campaigned. "He is a very clever politician," Barron says. 
As speaker, Gifford Miller's first duty is to lead the 51-member Council, each member of which represents the interests of constituents spread out over the city's five unruly boroughs. "New York City is a jungle of interest groups," says Hank Sheinkopf, a political consultant who is working on H. Carl McCall's gubernatorial campaign. "Miller has to mediate all this. How does he do it? Well, you need a psychoanalytically healthy guy and an iron-willed political leader." So far, Sheinkopf says, Miller has shown himself to be up to the task on both counts. "He's somebody who understands power, and he has exercised it well." 
Albert Vann, a councilman from Brooklyn who ran against Miller for the speakership, says: "I get the impression that he tries to lead with as much consensus as is possible. I think members have an opportunity on the major, critical, controversial issues to be heard and to shape what the Council position will be in large measure. The speaker always has power and discretion, but this speaker, in comparison to Vallone before him, is much more open and responsive to the concerns and positions of the members." Councilman Bill Perkins, who represents a district in Central Harlem, also ran against Miller for speaker, and he has made no secret of his wish that the speakership be held by a person of color; he has nevertheless become a supporter of Miller. "Reaching out to people, speaking to them, assuring them that you're the kind of person that can fulfill their needs: he did that," Perkins says. That Miller has been so effective at winning the loyalty and support of members who differ so markedly in background from him has made for Miller an unexpectedly frictionless ride in his first eight months as speaker. But charming and cajoling council members is not Miller's sole challenge as speaker. He also has to deal with the mayor, and there things have been running a little less smoothly. 
As leader of the Legislature, the speaker heads the body that counterbalances the mayor's powers. It's the Council, not the mayor, that passes new laws; it's the Council, not the mayor, that has final say over the city budget. Even mayoral vetoes of Council initiatives can be overridden by the Council if the speaker can muster a two-thirds majority. It's a structure that virtually guarantees that the speaker and mayor will eventually find themselves at loggerheads. Tensions have already begun to show up in Miller and Bloomberg's relationship -- largely because of what some perceive as the mayor's tendency to discount Miller's importance in the governing of the city. In the annual Inner Circle press lampoon of city politics, Miller was played onstage by the prepubescent son of one of the mayor's staff members -- a joke that some saw as a true dis. "He's not the little kid prancing around the stage as portrayed by the mayor," the veteran political consultant George Arzt says. "His pleasant exterior belies the fact that he's a tenacious campaigner and a real fighter."
More concrete evidence of the mayor's apparent lack of respect for Miller occurred in August when Bloomberg, usurping the Council's role as lawmaker, announced his own antismoking bill that would outlaw tobacco use in any public place, including bars. Bloomberg deeply discomforted Miller when he later told reporters that he had extracted a private promise from the speaker to pass the legislation without delay -- a characterization that made Miller sound like little more than the mayor's puppet; it was a gambit all the more galling for Miller, since he insists that no such private deal was ever struck. 
Just days after the smoking fracas, the strain between Miller and Bloomberg was ratcheted up when Bloomberg vetoed the Council's proposed fix to the term-limits law -- an adjustment that does not change the underlying law but rather addresses a quirk that holds some members (Miller among them) to only six years in office instead of the mandated eight. Even those inclined to see the new legislation as a self-serving initiative have conceded that the existing law was flawed. Nevertheless, the mayor vetoed the bill, despite Miller's having the necessary two-thirds majority of council members needed to override it. Many saw the mayor's act as a needless provocation of Miller and the Council. "By doing that," Ed Koch, the former mayor, says, "Bloomberg risks losing the close cooperation that he's had from the Council to date. It's in a mayor's interest to work with the speaker. I went out of my way to work with Speaker Peter Vallone and, before him, Tom Cuite, to include them and give them credit for my initiatives."
For his part, Miller, ever the savvy politician, refuses to stoke the fires of controversy over the mayor's actions, insisting in the mildest of tones that he gets along well with "Mike" and that a continued spirit of cooperation is crucial to solving the many crises faced by the city. Inherent, however, in Miller's unruffled response is the sense that with his finely tuned political instincts, Miller had sussed out that churning anti-Bloomberg sentiment was unnecessary. Sure enough, within days, newspapers were announcing that Bloomberg's political "honeymoon" was over, citing the frictions he created with the City Council. Miller contented himself with just one small comment, an observation about Bloomberg that is artful not only in its understatement but also in its turning of the tables. Saying that he forgives Bloomberg his gaffes on the smoking bill and term-limits veto, Miller adds: "He's just not that experienced yet. He's not a pro."
Yet despite the strain between them, Miller and Bloomberg display far greater affinities with each other than they do differences. Both are classic technocrats: Bloomberg is a man who changed political parties in order to win the mayoralty; Miller is a man who describes himself ideologically as smack-dab in the acceptable middle. Miller has consistently championed such progressive causes as gay and lesbian rights. (He recently introduced a bill requiring the city to recognize out-of-state same-sex unions as domestic partnerships.) At the same time, he has done nothing to frighten or disenfranchise the all-important business elite. Times were that an ambitious New York City politician could not get away with quite so Clintonian a political triangulation and hope to prosper. But Miller says that the days of fierce left- and right-wing struggles for the hearts of New Yorkers are gone. "In New York City these days," he says, "a lot of the old debates are not as useful in breaking down the current situation." 
When Miller set out on his campaign for the speakership in 1999, it was during a period of unprecedented economic growth, and one that conferred on New York City an extraordinary period of stability and prosperity. In the wake of the World Trade Center attack, and with the ongoing national recession tipping New York's economy into a crisis reminiscent of the 1970's, the city's outlook has changed drastically. Having run for one job, Miller has ended up with quite another. 
"I thought I'd be going to more ribbon-cuttings than I'll be going to," as he dryly puts it. "It's a different challenge, but for me it's a greater challenge. You go into public service because you want to make a contribution. At least, I did. And I think the opportunity to make a contribution now is greater than ever. Think back to Felix Rohatyn and some of the architects who got us through the last crisis. Governor Carey. I'm going to have a chance to be remembered as somebody who helped, or" -- he laughs -- "somebody who hurt." The joke is typical of Miller, who relies on self-deprecation and irony as favorite tactics for not sounding like a wooden politician. But beneath the constant good cheer, Miller does his share of worrying about piloting the Council through such perilous times. "I know he's churning underneath," says his wife, Pamela. "He's gone down two waist sizes since taking on the job."
Miller admits: "In the middle of the night, when I think about the fact that we have a $5billion budget gap and that we're going to have to raise taxes and cut spending in ways that I really don't think people have gotten their minds around yet, it seems really frightening." By all accounts, Miller has every reason to be frightened. In the increasingly Darwinian, survival-of-the-fittest climate that many (including Miller) are predicting for New York, his job as speaker can only grow more difficult. The current collegial mood within the City Council could grow frayed as members fight to protect funds and services for their respective districts. "It's going to be tough," Hank Sheinkopf says. "His job is to protect his council members who provide services to people -- and those will be cut." Sheinkopf further predicts that in such an event, the already strained relationship between Miller and Bloomberg could sharply deteriorate as speaker and mayor use each other as political scapegoats. "They have to have an enemy to explain why the services aren't there." 
Given these looming problems, it's far too early to handicap Miller's chances for becoming mayor in 2005. Nevertheless, Miller seems to have a good shot at becoming, at 36, the second-youngest mayor in the city's history. "The people who dismiss him and think that that's not a reality," Councilman Oddo says, "I think they're playing into the man's hands." But others remain skeptical that Miller can negotiate the difficult journey from the Council speaker's office in the East Wing of City Hall to the mayor's office in the West Wing. Councilman Barron points out that that trip, though short physically, is strewn with booby traps and land mines -- even for as skilled a politician as Gifford Miller. 
"He's moving real fast," Barron says. "But in New York City politics, there are so many forces that pull on you. You've got county leaders, you've got a mayor, you've got real-estate interests, you've got the banking interests. I think up till now he has been playing it fairly well, but at some point, he's going to reach a critical juncture where it's not going to be about playing all the sides. It's going to be about taking some tough stances. And then we'll see what Gifford Miller is really made of."

PUB-DATE: October 6, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 65

LENGTH: 3641 words

HEADLINE: The De Facto Capital 

BYLINE:  By Frank Rich; Frank Rich is a Times columnist and a senior writer for the magazine.

 BODY:
They got it right the first time. New York was the capital of the nation at its birth. The first presidential inauguration, in 1789, wasn't far from ground zero, and the first presidential residence, at 3 Cherry Street, was on a spot now occupied by one of the supports for the Brooklyn Bridge. George Washington slept there, but not for long. In a political deal purportedly made on a downtown sidewalk, Alexander Hamilton traded away the location of the capital to Thomas Jefferson to entice the South to give the federal government power to assume state debts. A year later, Congress and the president decamped to Philadelphia, and a decade after that, they settled into a new federal city next to which the City of Brotherly Love seems like Shangri-La. As Jack Lait and Lee Mortimer, two New York tabloid reporters of a later day, would assess the fateful final choice of a national capital in their 1951 best seller, "Washington Confidential": "The founding fathers, whose infinite wisdom gave us a Constitution and form of government well nigh perfect, located the seat of that government in a stinking, steaming swamp." 
 The country's seat may still be mired in that swamp, but its heart, soul and brains are more evident than ever in its first capital, 200 miles to the north. While New York has long been the nation's center of culture, finance, fashion and media, the city in the aftermath of Sept. 11 cohered into something more than the sum of its perennially celebrated parts. After its highest towers were taken down, New York rose from its initial shock to illustrate in real time what America actually is, a huge and resilient democracy animated by citizens of every conceivable stripe, pursuit and ethic (from those who gave their lives for others at the World Trade Center to those who looted its shopping mall). Instead of seeming, as it often had, like an eccentric island adrift from the rest of the country, the city found itself valued instead as a concentrated representation of the whole. That outsiders would regard it as the true American capital was proof that Americans now define themselves far more by their cultural choices, most of which are tweaked and marketed by the information factories of Manhattan, than by their choice (if any) of political party. Not that New York is shy about offering political leadership if it spots a vacuum. When the White House's occupant was nowhere to be found on the day the country needed him most, New York went so far as to offer up its own chief executive as the nation's paterfamilias. America is still grateful. 
 Even at the literal level, New York is more representative of American political values than the official capital. Washington, where I grew up and where my family has lived since the Civil War, is still a colony where the voters are denied the full rights of self-determination. Its citizens and public officials alike remain in thrall to a federal government over which they have virtually no say, in the shadow of a president who serves as the de facto prince regent of the tourist precincts, the only part of the city most Americans see. Washington is less an exemplar of democracy than an agglomeration of marble facades paying unctuous tribute to that aspiration. George W. Bush, and he is hardly the first president to do so, treats it as a politically obligatory diorama that he can flee any and every chance he gets.
New York doesn't think of itself as competing with Washington -- the same cannot be said of the reverse -- but periodically it does so, if only to let the world know who's really boss. After World War II, suburban Virginia tried to lure the fledgling United Nations to metropolitan Washington, until someone belatedly realized that an international citizenry would not take kindly to segregated schools. In 1959, the Washington Board of Trade mounted an elaborate campaign to make the "Capital of the Free World" the site of the 1964 World's Fair. According to one account, the D.C. advocates' hard sell leaned heavily on the annual cherry-blossom festivals, the "colorful parades constantly held when distinguished foreign guests visit the city" and "the elaborate and dignified presidential inauguration celebrations." That was all it took to persuade the World's Fair Commission to reach unanimity in awarding the plum to Robert Moses's posse from New York. 
This year brought the Olympics bake-off. To increase its odds as a site for the 2012 summer games, Washington entered into a shotgun marriage with the more plausibly urban Baltimore. The capital's confidence was such that it took for granted a Washington Post report in July that D.C. and San Francisco were "the apparent front-runners," beating out New York and Houston. The next month brought the shocking news that it was Washington that had been eliminated along with Houston (the only other city that can match both its toxic summer weather and complement of former Enron executives). After this defeat, there was much local muttering that "politics" was the culprit and that Washington might have been punished because of the unpopularity abroad of the incipient war on Iraq. 
How much easier for Washingtonians to blame Saddam than to take a hard look at their own city. D.C. may have talked a good game about sports to the U.S. Olympic Committee, but for three decades it has lacked a major-league team in the most American sport of them all. It purports to be as up to date as the new economy, but the signature digital-era companies to put down roots there, AOL and MicroStrategy, are synonymous with the dot-com bust. The capital's Maryland and Virginia suburban enclaves are famous for having some of the country's most over-the-top houses as measured by square footage but none of the most imaginative architecture.
Such is Washington's appeal to tourists that it did not make the list of the Top 10 North American cities in this year's Travel and Leisure magazine readers' poll. (New York came in first.) The capital's restaurants can't compete with those of Vegas, let alone New York, Chicago and the Seattle-to-Los Angeles culinary axis of the West. Its taxicabs have a suspect fee structure as gerrymandered as the map of Congressional voting districts. While New York has contributed to the American language such joyous words as "whoopee" and "hot dog," Washington has coined "inside the Beltway" and "Department of Homeland Security." America's songwriters and poets have repeatedly celebrated Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island too -- not to mention San Francisco, Chicago and St. Louis -- but where is that romantic lyric about the capital? "Hail to the Redskins" will have to do. 
First appearances can be deceptive to new visitors to D.C. Edmund Wilson once observed that Washington, "after other American cities, seems at first such a relief, so agreeable," but "turns out, when one has stayed there any length of time, to have little personality of its own and to come to taste rather flat." Or as Cindy Adams wrote this year: "Even folks who live in Washington don't want to be there. The high point for a visitor? Catching a glimpse of Trent Lott in Person? I mean, please."
By contrast, you have to pry people away from New York. The gaping wound only deepened the citizenry's already intimate connection to their city. In the poignant opening episode of the post-9/11 season of "Sex and the City," Carrie went so far as to choose the city over sex, spurning the advances of a Fleet Week sailor after he committed the sin of knocking her town. It was the patriotic thing to do. 
New Yorkers who were out of town on 9/11 felt desperate to return. Since then, we seem inexorably drawn to the watering holes and restaurants and merchants downtown, as if to fill in the shadow of death with the lubricious glow and laughter of irrepressible life. We are more aware of our neighbors than before: not just the firemen and the cops and the family that lost someone, but the guy who lost his business in the undertow, the guy who is trying to rebuild, the all-American Sikh cabbie who bedecks his windshield with flags lest he be victimized (as in New York he has generally not been) by guilt-by-turban. The fate of ground zero is, inevitably, a noisy political and aesthetic debate, but whatever acrimony may attend it, it is also a classic American project: a battle between money and values, between commerce and art, between powerful interests and upstart citizenry, between past and future, all staged on an open 16-acre expanse that is urban America's largest frontier. 
Not only were the dire predictions of a mass exodus wrong, but the reverse may be happening. A New York Times/CBS News poll in August found that the number of inhabitants who think that New York will be a better place to live in 10 or 15 years is the same as it was the month before the attack. Manhattan's residential real-estate values were clocked this summer at 15 percent higher than they had been pre-Sept. 11; signed contracts on apartments were up this July over last, too, reflecting the possibility that more people are arriving than leaving, even during an economic downturn. Neighborhoods reinvent themselves faster than anyone can keep count, from Harlem to the Lower East Side. Queens, generally an also-ran in any five-borough hipness sweepstakes, shows signs of becoming the new Brooklyn (though it still lacks its own Zagat). The Museum of Modern Art lives in Queens now, and so do a disproportionate number of artists, writers, dancers and musicians -- including the novelist Jonathan Safran Foer, who is only the latest in a long list of Washington-spawned talents (from Duke Ellington to Paul Taylor) who fled the capital's culturally parched environment to reach full bloom in the enriching concrete of New York.
In Washington, there is far more culture than there used to be, but spectacle, in keeping with the town's own bombastic aesthetics, tends to be the hottest ticket -- blockbuster shows at the National Gallery, Disney musicals and the Bolshoi on tour. Cities as small as Minneapolis and Seattle have a more lively indigenous arts scene than Washington. The plight of culture in the capital is symbolized by the Kennedy Center, an afterthought not even deemed worthy of its own stop on the city's part-time Metro system. A world-class impresario, Michael Kaiser, has at last been imported to revive the place, and this summer he performed a Heimlich maneuver in the form of the well-received Sondheim Celebration. But half the weekend audience was New Yorkers, to whom Kaiser may have to continue to cater. The low-slung performing arts barn on the Potomac has for so long been isolated from the best American culture, high, middle and pop, that its annual low-rated televised honors have of late been reduced to bestowing some of their medallions on Brits rather than native genius. (This year's Kennedy Center knight, Paul McCartney, has taken a rain check.) Such is President Bush's respect for the capital's temple of culture that among his first appointments to its board was Bo Derek. 
With the exception of the B-list Hollywood names who get all dressed up (once, anyway) for the White House Correspondents' Dinner, artists turn up in the city en masse only when Congress is posturing about the arts and humanities endowments. As for what American pop culture thinks of Washington as a city, as opposed to a government, one need only look at "Minority Report," in which the capital's defining trait, even years in the future, is its historically high crime rate. The movie's point seems to be that nothing short of the ability to arrest suspects before they commit a crime would have enabled D.C.'s benighted police force to crack a case like Chandra Levy's. 
New York is hardly without crime, but it also has the positive side of urban friction: the manifest humanity that results when millions of people of all kinds are packed together to make a go of it. The fundamental DNA of the city has never changed. It has always been a gateway for immigrants as well as an arena for big money. Its crowds have been large and raucous from the start. That "culture of congestion," in the phrase of the architect Rem Koolhaas, leads to a nonstop chain reaction of serendipitous human fusion, creative and sexual and economic, that is as American as you can get. The byproducts include hyphenated talents, melting-pot families, a constant, bubbling hands-on laboratory for social, political and cultural change in which the experiments alternately succeed big and fail catastrophically, in full public view. 
At some point, Washington had its own dreams of being a sizzling capital. In "Political Terrain," Carl Abbott writes of how in the late 19th century it was still hoped that D.C. "could aspire to be the Rome of America in the arts, the Berlin of America in education and the Paris of America as a city of beauty and pleasure." But the city stood still while those roles were respectively claimed by New York, Boston and San Francisco. (Though George Washington had offered to help endow a major university for the new capital, few of its grandees seconded his enthusiasm.) Despite early hopes that the federal district might be an economic hub, it was as hard for capitalism to take root as culture. As Edwin G. Burrows and Mike Wallace write in "Gotham," it became apparent early in the 19th century that the United States "would have two centers, one governmental, the other economic." It was a "separation of powers as emphatic as anything in the Constitution" with "no parallel in the Western world." The American capital that emerged was, in John Kennedy's famous formulation, a city of "southern efficiency and northern charm" -- a rare point of agreement between him and Richard Nixon, who pronounced Washington "a city without identity" and voted with his feet to spend most of his political exile in New York prior to his 1968 comeback. 
If Washington has an indistinct identity, it does have its own DNA -- that of a town of transients. When legislative sessions were far briefer than they are now, Congress and the Supreme Court took residence in temporary quarters, then fled to better climes (as they still do when in recess). "The greatest and most respectable business that is done in Washington is keeping boarding houses," said an 1829 handbook for new arrivals. It wasn't until well into the 20th century, as the federal government expanded during the New Deal (with its hefty infusion of F.D.R. New Yorkers) and World War II, that the city's population did as well. By then it had long since missed out on the great wave of turn-of-the-century immigration that gave New York and every other East Coast metropolis their human and cultural variety. Even now, the capital lacks the ethnic spectrum of other major American cities. In the 2000 census, the Asian population of New York -- almost 10 percent of the city's eight million inhabitants -- was substantially larger than the entire population of D.C., where the Asian population is only 2.6 percent. Though the number of Hispanics is rising in Washington as elsewhere, in 2000 they still made up, at most, 9 percent of the city, as opposed to a quarter of New York. 
When the W.P.A. assembled its guidebook to the capital during the Depression, the authors seemed almost desperate to imbue their subject with distinction. One wistful accolade paid tribute to the city's "profusion of shade trees." When the book was revised in 1942, the district's most distinctive aspect was played down -- the references to the second-class citizenship of its black residents, who like all Washingtonians had no right to vote, even in presidential elections, but who also continued to suffer many of the deprivations of slavery, from discrimination to poor public health and schools. In a 1983 reissue, a new editor set the record straight, but noted as compensation that "it is easier to find one's bearings in Washington than in other American cities." (So true, and so what?)
Though opponents of full home rule for the District then and now can give all sorts of highfalutin constitutional arguments for their position, the perennial sub rosa reason for its substatus remains the same as it was before anyone had heard of Marion Barry's coke bust or of the hapless current mayor, Anthony Williams, whose fraudulent nominating petitions contained "signatures" from New York celebrities like Martha Stewart and Billy Joel. In 1965, Washington became the first major American city in which blacks outnumbered whites by more than 10 percent. Given the Republican Party's inability to attract large numbers of black voters, it has hardly been in any rush to empower more of them at the price of likely handing the Democrats two voting seats in the Senate and one in the House.
The only time the capital's residents had true self-rule was during a short-lived biracial governance experiment during Reconstruction, soon ended by white resistance. Though Washingtonians can now vote for president (since 1961), they have but a single nonvoting member of Congress. Under their limited form of home rule, in place only since the early 1970's, the City Council, the mayor, the budget and even citizen-passed ballot initiatives can all be overruled by congressmen from states whose constituents' firsthand knowledge of the capital may be limited to the compulsory school trip. It could be argued that nowhere in the country is the plantation mentality still more embedded in civic life than in an African-American city whose citizens lack the full rights of citizenship, even as their Army National Guard units are called on active duty for the war on terrorism. This antediluvian, or at least antebellum, state of affairs makes D.C. a strikingly anachronistic capital of America in the 21st century, whatever its validity as a capital before the passage of the 13th Amendment. Indeed, America's capital has less democratic autonomy than President Bush this year demanded of the Palestinians.
Whatever Washington lacks in actual democracy, it makes up, of course, in monuments. But what represents the spirit of modern America more than the Statue of Liberty? The view of Lait and Mortimer, Washington's churlish chroniclers of the 1950's, still holds. They likened the city's tourist appeal to that of Hollywood's Forest Lawn cemetery, where busloads of Americans come to visit the movie stars' graves. "Its gleaming public buildings of white marble are like so many mausoleums," they wrote. "Where it doesn't look like a cemetery it resembles a movie set. It has a feel of unreality." But if politics is show business for ugly people, as the old joke has it, you can't push the Hollywood analogy too far. "Washington is dominated by elected and appointed functionaries who are schooled to believe they must never be caught having fun," Lait and Mortimer wrote. "Therefore, after dark, it is more like Paducah than Paris." Unlike New York, which has winked at mayoral girlfriends from Jimmy Walker's to Rudolph Giuliani's (and doesn't care where its current bachelor mayor spends his weekends), Washington was the last to discover John Kennedy's sex life and is still as open-mouthed as an Edvard Munch screamer when contemplating Bill Clinton's. 
Washington's idea of a Hollywood sex symbol is a cast member in "The West Wing" -- no matter whom -- because what could be more erotic than a powerful government bureaucrat? The city's idea of an intellectual is a Sunday-morning talking head; its literary apotheosis is the trade journal. Its loudest academic posturing emanates from the so-called university without students, the think tank, invented by the Brookings Institution in 1927 and a major Washington growth industry since the 1970's. The think tanks' tenured "professors," with grandiose titles that might have been lifted from the Marx Brothers' "Duck Soup," are often out-of-office ideologues with more position papers than books to their credit. Only in this heady environment could William Bennett be mistaken for Harold Bloom and CNN's "Capital Gang" for the Algonquin Round Table. Unlike decision makers in other capitals, Washington's power elite don't routinely commingle with top-rung scholars, scientists, novelists, artists and musicians who might broaden their thinking beyond the parameters set by the city's army of lobbyists and single-issue advocates. 
Though Washington suffered its own grievous wound on Sept. 11, it remains as insular as it was before the attack. As the country's official capital, it is to New York as Ankara is to Istanbul, Canberra is to Sydney, Brasilia is to Rio. Strolling through downtown and past the alabaster public buildings on a beautiful afternoon, you find that the sparse pedestrian traffic is often limited to government workers in cookie-cutter garb and cadres of tourists hoping to find some semblance of urban brio after having had their fill of the National Air and Space Museum. (They'd be better advised to hightail it to the city's black or gay enclaves or even the suburbs.) 
Take a similar walk through the central commercial districts of New York, whatever the borough, and you'll find not just animated sidewalks packed with locals but also signs of a city in perpetual renewal, pursuing creation and demolition with equal abandon, always testing the limits. That hope, that drive, that hunger to keep moving no matter what, is America at its highest throttle. Should the Olympians come to the true capital, they won't automatically own the town, as they would if they had landed in Washington. In New York, they'll find that no sooner do the games begin than they are locked into the even tougher competition of winning the city's favor, just like every other newcomer who has ever come here with dreams of going for the gold.

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 71
