HEADLINE: ART; 
Unveiling Hidden Gems, Courtesy of Collectors

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM ZIMMER 

 BODY:
GREENWICH is known for displaying its prosperity rather conspicuously, so the first half of "Pleasures of Collecting" at the Bruce Museum confirms that there is a rarer aspect to its reputation. It is an exhibition mostly made up of work from private collections in town that has not been exhibited before.
 Much of the art is unbelievably good, and important. The pleasure referred to in the show's title is not just that of the collectors but also that of the viewers. 
 This pleasure is increased by the realization that the show is work only from the Renaissance to the Impressionist period. A second part, in January, will focus on the modern and contemporary periods.
The show was chosen and sometimes persuaded off a collector's wall by Peter Sutton, the Bruce's director. He is also an art historian whose specialty is Dutch painting of the 17th century and he found several weighty works from this time and place. 
Another notable early work is "The Adoration of the Magi" by Giorgio Vasari, a 16th-century Italian who is best known as a writer. His exhaustive "Lives of the Artists" is a a chronicle that begins in the late middle ages. Vasari's 1566 painting is crowded and busy, a characteristic more associated with Mannerism, the style that was a pendulum swing away from more orderly and logical High Renaissance notions.
Since the show was drawn from diverse sources it is surprising to find instances where works are in clear relation. Especially nice is a threesome of portraits of fresh-faced young women. An undated "Head of a Young Girl" in a tondo or round format by the Dutch painter Judith Leyster who lived in Holland from 1609 to 1660 has a near twin in "Miss Rich" also known as "The Charity Girl" by William Hogarth.
Jumping far ahead, the American part of the exhibition includes Willard Metcalf's "The Violets" from 1903. The flowers are an oval-shaped bouquet that echoes the head of a young girl dressed in black who is posed from the waist up against a deep red background. She has a wistful expression, but she is also very sparely and directly presented.
The real show stoppers are French from the latter half of the 19th century. They begin to announce themselves at the entrance to the exhibition with a Manet from 1878. It might almost be the show's mascot because the self-portrait, listed as "bust length," shows a dual aspect to the man. He is known as a pleasure-seeker, a clothes horse and a dandy and here he wears what is obviously a good jacket and cravat, while holding a palette, used in the often messy business of painting. 
Another singular piece, the exhibition's lone sculpture, comes from the same time period as the self-portrait. It is a young girl cast in bronze who stands over three feet tall. At the time it was made, probably between 1879 and 1881, the "Little Fourteen-Year-Old Dancer" by Edgar Degas was considered shocking for its realism. Degas certainly abetted that perception by outfitting her in a ballet costume of real muslin and satin. 
A famous masterpiece of Pointillism, a style that can be regarded as a sort of firming up of Impressionism, is the figure-filled "A Sunday on the Grande-Jatte" by Georges Seurat. Like Impressionism, Seurat's innovation is rooted in a scientific perception of color but his subject matter is quiet, dignified pleasure. The exhibition includes a study for that painting that is practically unpopulated. Part of the pleasure of looking at it is anticipation, the knowledge crowds will come to that ample green park.
There is a strong example of Impressionism here: "The Cliffs Near Fecamps" by Claude Monet. It was painted in 1881, a couple of decades after the development of Impressionism. It shows the artist taking liberties with the style, such as varying the side and direction of the brush marks to give a sense of the recession of the cliffs in space. An interesting very late Impressionist work is "Landscape in Crozant in the Creuse Valley" by Armand Guillaumin. It was probably painted in 1905 and the dazzling autumn colors anticipate Fauvism. 
The room devoted to American works has sturdy portraits from the Colonial era and some Hudson River School works that include "Sunlight on Newbury Marshes," painted between 1865 and 1875 by Martin Johnson Heade. 
The Bruce's own backyard is included. Childe Hassam was a major member of the Cos Cob Art Colony as was Elmer Livingston MacRae. One of the earliest paintings acquired by the fledgling Bruce Museum was "August Morning," a 1919 painting of cows by Matilda Browne, that is hanging alongside other early acquisitions in the museum's foyer while her robust flower painting "Laurel" (1913) is in the exhibition.
"Pleasures of Collecting; Part 1, Renaissance to Impressionist Masterpieces" is at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich through Jan. 5. Information: (201) 869-0376 or www.brucemuseum.org.

GRAPHIC: Photos: From left: "The Charity Girl" by William Hogarth; "Girl With a Butterfly" by Adolphe William Bouguereau; "Little Fourteen-Year-Old Dancer" by Edgar Degas; and a self-portrait by Manet are part of an exhibition in Greenwich.

HEADLINE: From Tickets to Souvenirs, Arts-Related Spending Rises in County 

BYLINE:  By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS 

 BODY:
THE role of the arts in Westchester County's economy increased by 71 percent between 1995 and 2000, according to a study conducted by the Westchester Arts Council in cooperation with the county's Office of Tourism. 
 The study's results were announced as many county arts groups continue to struggle with the economic fallout of Sept. 11 and the recession, and as county budget discussions, with potential cuts to the arts, were about to begin. 
 Janet T. Langsam, executive director of the council, said that spending by the county's nonprofit arts organizations and their audiences amounted to $92.8 million in 2000, compared with $54.2 million in 1995. The figure included spending on nonticket items like restaurants, souvenirs, parking and baby sitters. 
In addition, the study reported that the number of full-time jobs supported by arts-related activities in Westchester -- including jobs in industries like construction, banking and food -- rose to 2,859 from 2,047 over the five-year period. The number of full-time jobs in arts organizations alone increased to 1,697 from 939.
The county study was part of a larger survey conducted by Americans for the Arts, a Washington-based group that collected data from 91 localities nationwide. The goal was to provide an economic profile of the country's nonprofit arts industry. 
The study included data collected from 82 Westchester arts organizations and 750 randomly selected audience members at events like concerts and films. Although the data was collected before the events of Sept. 11 and the weakened economy caused spending on the arts to drop significantly in the county, Ms. Langsam said the information was still relevant. 
"The growth has been so enormous that Sept. 11 could not possibly have wiped it out," she said. "You need to look at it as a trend, and the trend is that the arts are growing in Westchester County. When we do our next survey in 2005, our hope is that Sept. 11 will be a blip."
The Westchester data also showed that local municipalities, and the county and state, benefited from an increase in tax revenues and fees collected from arts organizations and their audiences between 1995 and 2000. Revenues collected by local governments rose to $6 million from $4.5 million, while revenues collected by the state increased to $8 million from $5 million. "We're really giving back to the state and the county much more than they're investing in the arts," Ms. Langsam said. 
Westchester County contributed $766,200 to the arts council's budget in 2000 and $952,500 this year. County Executive Andrew J. Spano, speaking at a news conference held at the council's headquarters here, said that the county might not be able to sustain its current level of support for the arts. Because of state-mandated spending programs, he said, "We're facing the ugliest budget in the history of Westchester." He said that the arts had to compete with other discretionary budget items like domestic violence programs and emergency services, and that the Board of Legislators would "cut the arts" before food programs.
Arts leaders countered that the arts provided far more than revenue-yielding entertainment. Stephen Apkon, executive director of the Jacob Burns Film Center in Pleasantville, said that the arts helped companies attract new employees to the county, while Michael Botwinick, director of the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, said that the "real bonus of the arts lies beyond jobs and tax revenues in the interest and activity that makes Westchester more than a bedroom community." 
Lisa Deutsch, executive director of the Music Conservatory of Westchester in White Plains, said the county's arts organizations should be counted as human service, as well as cultural, organizations.
"We're involved in special education and mental health," she said. "The arts don't exist in a little bubble all unto themselves. They're part of everything this county is all about."

HEADLINE: Last Call for a Smoke 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
JOHN RYERSON, the owner of McGuire's Restaurant and Comedy Club in Bohemia, said he went $250,000 into hock two years ago to create a separate room for smokers.
 There was no other choice, Mr. Ryerson said last week, if he were to comply with a 1995 Suffolk County law that sought to protect non-smoking patrons from secondhand smoke. "It was that or go smoke-free and find another job," said Mr. Ryerson, adding that, for his business, smoking is the difference between profit and loss. 
 Now he and other restaurant and bar-restaurant owners in Suffolk and Nassau are complaining bitterly that local officials are about to change the rules again, negating some owners' expensive compliance efforts with outright bans on smoking in virtually all public indoor places. 
Almost nothing would be spared, not even special rooms like Mr. Ryerson's and other dwindling public domains for indoor smokers, including beery multiscreen sports bars and smoky pubs and taverns where cigarettes and drinks go hand in hand.
"Now I won't even have the income to pay for my investment," said Mr. Ryerson, who is the chairman of the Suffolk County Restaurant and Tavern Association, which has about 200 members. 
But this week, when proposals to ban smoking in bars and restaurants move forward on a broad front as Nassau, Suffolk, New York City and Westchester take up the issue more or less simultaneously, economic arguments are colliding with increasing concerns about the health risks to workers exposed to secondhand smoke for long periods.
Supporters of the new restrictions said those risks are too great to ignore any longer.
Officials supporting the new restrictions said they would close what Brian Muellers, a Nassau County legislator, called "one enormous loophole."
"We have to protect the employees who work in these places," said Mr. Muellers, a Democrat from Locust Valley. "Secondhand smoke has been classified as a Class A carcinogen. There is no other workplace where workers are allowed to be exposed to that."
Estimates vary, but government and industry officials said that as many as 50,000 Long Islanders toil in smoke-filled workplaces, the foot soldiers in a hospitality industry that accounts for a large slice of the Island's leading service sector.
Supporters of the new restrictions, backed by the American Cancer Society, the American Heart Association and the American Lung Association, say recent research has unearthed mounting evidence that the effects of secondhand smoke are even more pernicious than previously believed. When bartenders and bar workers run triple the average risk of lung cancer and inhale the equivalent of a half a pack of cigarettes on every eight-hour shift, they said, the need to act is obvious and immediate.
"The science is what is really pushing this issue," said Will Stoner, the regional advocacy director for the American Cancer Society. But the groups have been pushing too, pinning their hopes on the city and the three counties after the State Senate failed to vote on a ban during its last session. The measure passed in the Assembly.
Bans in the city and counties, proponents point out, would create smoke-free bars and restaurants for two-thirds of the state's residents and set the stage for future state action.
At the behest of Judy Jacobs, the Democratic majority leader of the Nassau Legislature, officials from the city and the three counties have met twice in Nassau to coordinate their efforts. "We felt that uniformity was a key to success for this effort," Ms. Jacobs said. "We need to create a level playing field for all the restaurants, bars and workplaces."
The Nassau ban would take effect in March, matching the effective date of the proposed New York City ban. Bingo halls would have until January 2004 to comply. The Suffolk law would take effect in January 2004.
Nassau gets the legislative ball rolling on Monday, when the Legislature holds a public hearing, and possibly a vote, on the issue. The body's 10 Democrats appeared to be united last week behind the ban, but the 9 Republicans question the rush and the economic impact, and will seek a delay. With the Democratic county executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, leaning toward support of the ban, the one-vote Democratic margin could be all that is needed.
On the same day, Westchester county legislators will meet on three competing measures, including one that matches the Nassau and Suffolk initiatives.
The Suffolk Legislature, home of the country's first substantial ban on smoking in public places in 1984, holds a hearing on its bill on Tuesday, but probably won't vote until next month.
The measure is sponsored by a Democrat, Brian X. Foley of Blue Point, and co-sponsored by the Republican presiding officer, Paul Tonna of West Hills. But opposition is also bipartisan.
Some legislators are sensitive to health arguments but still troubled that the county would be changing requirements so soon after the 1995 law. "We forced a great many restaurants to make a significant investment in separately ventilated rooms," said David Bishop, a Democrat from West Babylon. "This law would render that worthless."
The New York City Council follows on Thursday with a hearing on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposal to ban smoking in bars, restaurants, offices, pool halls, bingo parlors, bowling alleys and private clubs.
While Nassau appeared to be in the lead in what opponents of the bans saw as a race to enact, Mr. Bloomberg's initiative, which he launched in August, attracted national and even international attention. "They all jumped on Bloomberg's wagon, he started it," said William Leudemann, who owns a catering business in Farmingville and is president of the Suffolk County Restaurant and Tavern Association and also of the Empire State Restaurant and Tavern Association.
Backers of the anti-smoking campaign argue that the bans will be an economic benefit to bars and bar-restaurants. Mr. Stoner said a smokeless environment would increase patronage by the 80 percent of Long Island residents who don't smoke. He and others said studies showed that restaurants and bars in California actually fared better after the state banned smoking in those establishments. 
Smoking bans in bars and restaurants are also in force in Delaware, a number of Texas municipalities, and in towns and cities scattered across the country.
Mr. Ryerson said the California ban hurt some businesses. "Overall there was a small increase for restaurants," he said. "But if you look at the taverns and bars, they had a decline."
But Thomas Valenti said business increased after he banned smoking at his Piccolo Ristorante in Bellmore in 1998. "We had to put up with complaints from customers who didn't like the smoke and we didn't like it ourselves," he said. "It's just not good for your health."
He predicted that a ban on smoking in bars and restaurants would quickly gain acceptance. "It's not going to hurt anybody," he said. "You might have a temporary thing where some people get upset, but in two weeks or a month everybody will forget about it."
Mr. Ryerson said his employees chose to work where smoking was permitted. "There is no shortage of jobs in nonsmoking restaurants," he said, "so if a waitress or waiter chooses to work in a bar where smoking is allowed, they do so because it's more lucrative."
Dawn Marie, a bartender at McGuire's who declined to give her last name, said she had worked eight-hour shifts in the smoking area for more than a year, felt no ill effects and opposed a smoking ban.
"I am a nonsmoker, I'm very into health, I work out on a daily basis, and I would definitely feel a difference," she said. "And I don't." She said that ventilating equipment cleared the air. 
Roger H. Corbin, a Democrat from Westbury and the deputy presiding officer of the Nassau Legislature, said he wished he could speak to Dawn Marie. "Feeling the effects of secondhand smoke can take a long time," said Mr. Corbin, a sponsor of the proposed smoking ban. "I would like to talk to her 20 years from now and ask her how she feels about the risk then. And if she doesn't feel she's at risk, what about her coworkers?"
"For some people, maybe that's the only place they can work," Mr. Corbin said. "But you don't have to kill them. You don't have to make them work in a poisoned atmosphere." 
He cited a national estimate from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta that as many as 65,000 nonsmokers die each year from exposure to secondhand smoke.
Peter J. Schmitt, a Republican from Massapequa and the minority leader of the Nassau Legislature, said Republicans were "not unsympathetic to the goals" of the proposed ban. But he said they wanted to address the plight of owners who paid for equipment to comply with current county law.
"This government told business owners in 1999, only three years ago, that if you spend the money for a separate ventilation system and a separate room it would be O.K. for you to have smoking on the premises," he said. "The proposed legislation makes no provision for these expenses business owners made in good faith."
Ms. Jacobs, the Democratic majority leader, said the percentage of owners who undertook the work was "extremely small." But she said supporters of the smoking ban were willing to listen to any reasonable argument. "If there is something they bring up that seems legitimate, we're not closing the door," she said. "But we are certainly very intent on the health reasons for doing this." 
Mr. Schmitt said that "the rush here to get this done" was part of a broader agenda advanced by groups that "want cigarettes gone."
"This is moving in a very intrusive direction," he said. "Soon they are going to move into the home." 
Mr. Schmitt and others who have not endorsed the bans said concern over employee health in the workplace properly belonged to other government agencies. "If you are approaching this from health and safety of workers that really belongs with the state and federal governments," Mr. Schmitt said. "If they are saying there is not an emergency, then why is Nassau County, with all its troubles, doing something that could impact on our revenue streams or businesses in this county?" 
Mr. Muellers, the Democratic legislator from Locust Valley, said the county was acting appropriately. "The federal and state governments are both abdicating their responsibility to protect these workers, and so the county is stepping in," he said.
Carl Marcellino, a Republican state senator from Oyster Bay and a cosponsor of a measure that would have imposed a ban statewide, said the bill never reached the floor of the Republican-controlled Senate after it was opposed by upstate small business interests including bar and tavern owners. Press reports said Governor Pataki brought pressure to keep the Senate bill from coming to a vote.
"I am a supporter of the concept and would have voted for it," Mr. Marcellino said.
Some opponents of the county measures said local officials risked lawsuits charging they overstepped their authority. Paul Sabatino, the counsel to the Suffolk legislature, said such challenges had already lost in the federal courts.
"It's no longer an open question as to the legal authority of a municipality acting through its legislative body to place prohibitions or restrictions on public places," Mr. Sabatino said. "The law in this area has been decided."

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
Norwalk Hands Baton to a Symphony Builder

BYLINE:  By VALERIE CRUICE 

 BODY:
WHEN the Norwalk Symphony put the word out that it was looking for a new music director in 1968, there were 12 responses. Last year, the symphony's search committee was inundated with 185 applications, many of them from overseas.
 Pretty impressive for a 62-year old community orchestra. Not bad for a group that started out with all volunteer musicians and still has a few in its ranks. Noteworthy because the Norwalk Symphony is one of seven orchestras vying for audiences and contributions in southwestern Connecticut. 
 Add to that the overall economic uncertainty in the arts world, and the challenges -- never mind the music-making -- are daunting.
Diane Wittry, who will be the symphony's new music director, the first woman in the post in Connecticut, said she was up to the challenge of strengthening the group's identity as a community orchestra.
Ms. Wittry's most recent work has been with the Allentown Symphony in Pennsylvania, where she has been music director and conductor since 1995. She will continue to hold those posts concurrently with her Norwalk Symphony appointment, which became effective in May.
"She did marvels with the Allentown Symphony," said Dr. Richard Epstein, president of the board of governors of the Norwalk Symphony Society and a bassoonist with the orchestra for 25 years.
Mr. Epstein, who is also a dentist, said that Ms. Wittry improved the quality of the Allentown orchestra, increased the number of concerts and made the organization financially secure. The Allentown Symphony has a $900,000 annual budget, he said, while Norwalk has a budget of $360,000.
Known as an orchestra builder, Ms. Wittry was recently cited as a conductor to watch in Symphony Magazine, the publication of the American Symphony Orchestra League. She is a sought-after guest conductor and has worked with the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the San Diego Symphony, the Houston Symphony, the Florida Philharmonic and the Osaka Symphoniker Orchestra in Japan.
In addition to her commitment to Allentown, Ms. Wittry remains the artistic adviser of the Symphony of Southeast Texas, after serving as its music director from 1991 to 2000.
Ms. Wittry, who declines to give her age except to say that she is in her 40's, received a bachelor of music degree in violin performance from the University of Southern California in 1983, where she also earned a masters of music in instrumental conducting in 1985.
Her teachers and mentors have included Sir Peter Maxwell Davis, Michael Tilson Thomas, Daniel Lewis and Gustav Meier. Her predecessor, Jesse Levine, resigned from the Norwalk Symphony in December 2000, ending a 20-year tenure. Mr. Epstein said it was a mutual separation.
Ms. Wittry will make her debut Oct. 19 at the Norwalk Concert Hall. The program will feature excerpts from Mozart, Beethoven, Offenbach, Berlioz and more.
During Tchaikovsky's 1812 Overture, the mayor of Norwalk, Alex Knopp, will be pressing the key on a synthesizer that simulates the sound of a cannon.
Ms. Wittry blew into Norwalk for a few days in mid-September from her home in New Jersey, meeting local politicians, educators and corporate executives, giving interviews and brainstorming with her board.
"As a music director you learn to do great things on a limited budget," she said, seated in the symphony's offices between appointments. "I feel strongly that a music director's job is to help with fund-raising. I love going out into the communities."
Mr. Epstein said the Norwalk Symphony has had its share of difficulties. Audience attendance has slipped and subscriptions are down.
Ms. Wittry wants to offer more programs -- there are now four classical and two family concerts -- and occasionally take the orchestra outside the concert hall, perhaps with a summer series on the waterfront. She said she loves to put unexpected things into the programs, such as special lighting, videos and dancers.
"I pick my music very carefully, pieces that are technically well-crafted," she said. 
For live performances, Ms. Wittry said that "much of the music written in the 20th century is vital and fresh and seems to relate to our life more; Stravinsky, Copeland, the jazz influences."
"At the same time to temper this with the Three Bs is a balance," she said, referring to Bach, Beethoven and Brahms.
For tickets, call (203) 847-8844 or visit www.norwalksymphony.org.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Commercial Realty Firms Broaden Their Nets

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN 

 BODY:
RESPONDING to a paucity of deals to broker during the economic slowdown, some commercial real estate firms in New Jersey are cutting fees, but many others are looking to generate new revenues with new lines of service.
 "Most real estate providers are moving in one of the two directions," said William Cariste, a managing principal at Newmark Real Estate. "In times like these, it's traditional to see extreme competitiveness with fees and incentives offered to customers -- and that is happening now. 
 "But in lieu of doing that some real estate firms are adding a lot of services."
Jeffrey M. Schotz of GVA Williams, observed, "Everything used to be focused on the transaction, on getting the deal done." But now, Mr. Schotz said, brokers are moving to provide services that cover a client from "shopping to occupancy." 
This means that a company wanting to lease or buy office space in New Jersey to suit its particular needs might hire a brokerage to handle everything from finding the best existing space for the price to doing the renovations. A group of investors wanting to buy commercial property could hire a broker not only to make the deal but also to put together creative financing and manage the property after the sale, providing such special services as computerized lease monitoring, back-up data service, building security and energy-efficiency analysis.
Some firms are adding new divisions. Others are broadening their reach through "strategic alliances" -- partnerships with other companies that provide specialized service. GVA Williams partnered with S.O.S. Security of Parsippany last year after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11.
"Security became more important to both landlords and tenants," Mr. Schotz said, "and customers began to ask us about it. If you own a building 20 years old, or you are moving into one, there may be no security measures other than locks on the doors.
"Now we have a consultant we can recommend to you that will determine what is needed. Building alarms? A secure room? Based on your business and what you want to integrate, we can analyze costs and then do the work."
Adding such specialized services strengthens relationships with customers, Mr. Schotz said, besides "creating profit centers." GVA Williams sometimes includes the cost of security service in the overall fee for a project, or it might charge a separate fee.
Expertise in negotiating fees can itself be considered a service. The Staubach Company, a national firm with regional headquarters in Murray Hill, recently added fee negotiation to its line.
"When a construction job is involved," said Tom Stanton, a managing principal of Staubach in Murray Hill, "there are supervisory fees, profit and overhead fees, etc., which are best negotiated by people who really understand the market, and people who have a feel for market conditions. We are providing an in-house salaried individual to do this."
Staubach has offered interior design and construction services to brokerage customers since it began operating in New Jersey almost four years ago. It has expanded into construction and development work, Mr. Stanton said.
Frank Cotillo, an experienced construction manager, was hired 18 months ago to head a new construction division. Mr. Cotillo's group has completed various kinds of projects for Staubach clients, including construction of new offices for a Newark company that sells beepers and renovation of a Morristown office building for a securities trading firm and an office-lab in Parsippany for a biotechnology company.
Currently, Staubach's construction team is at work on renovating a building on lower Broadway in Manhattan to suit the United States Securities and Exchange Commission. The S.E.C. hired Staubach to find new space for its Northeast regional office after its offices were destroyed in the World Trade Center attack. About 500 S.E.C. employees were hastily moved to the Broadway building as soon as a lease was negotiated -- and they are to remain in place while construction work goes on, increasing the difficulty of the project. 
Mr. Cotillo said another challenge lay in designing ceiling lighting that would enhance the natural light and not disturb the historic window line. But that has worked out well, he said, because now expertise in lighting design is evolving into a specialized service that Staubach can offer. 
Staubach is also creating two new advisory services, for educational institutions and municipalities. "The skills we are always selling to corporate clients are highly applicable to the public world: cost control, time milestones, construction and delivery of property," Mr. Stanton said. "There is a very complicated procurement process for governmental and educational entities, and we provide the ability to handle the stringencies of that process."
STAUBACH did the feasibility study for Montclair State University, which is constructing a new parking deck for its performing arts complex. That project required consulting experts in civil engineering, parking structure design, parking lot operation, institutional architecture and other fields, Mr. Stanton said, "and basically delivering a team that could handle the entire project."
As part of its government service initiative, Mr. Stanton said, the firm is developing expertise on federal Urban Enterprise Zone requirements, procedures and benefits.
Newmark Real Estate, a national firm that has offices in East Rutherford, is "moving heavily into transaction management," according to Mr. Cariste.
The economic downturn has provided an opportunity to hire experienced professionals who have been laid off, Mr. Cariste said, which in turn has helped to generate expanded service lines. Newmark is offering commercial property customers a large number of added services for extra fees -- including preliminary analysis of space to determine if it meets a particular industry's standards for square feet, energy efficiency and special features.
In a time of downsizing because of economic setbacks and uncertainty, Mr. Cariste said, providing an analysis that points out how industry standards may be changing and where a property stands in the flux is reassuring to clients. "They may be adopting a measure of austerity," he said, "and putting that in context can be a comfort."
"We also are now managing tenants through the move to new space," he said. "We provide construction, computer wiring and acquisition, furniture and installation, decorating and moving services."
"The trick in managing all those things," Mr. Cariste added, "is in taking profits where they can be taken without stripping a transaction of its value to the customer."
Meanwhile, a relatively new company, the Schultz Group, is finding success in a downturn through continuing emphasis on its motto: "Niches mean riches."
While Mr. Schotz of GVA William contends that the globalization of corporate business is one reason there is increased demand for extensive broker services, Jonathan B. Schultz, president and chief executive of the 12-year-old Schultz Group, said smaller companies and investors have complex needs, too.
Over the past five years, Schultz has made a specialty of managing distressed property -- for example, commercial buildings that fall into the hands of mortgage banks through foreclosure. "We can rescue and reposition the properties, providing all the technological and construction expertise and local knowledge and contacts, that are needed," he asserted.
Currently, Mr. Schultz said, his company is developing a line of service to small institutions, pension and investment funds and private investors, who buy or hold New Jersey retail properties. The retail market has remained quite healthy throughout the current downturn, he noted.
"We saw several years ago that as retail brokerage goes, there are not many that can do leasing, management and asset management under one roof," Mr. Schultz said. "We've raised the level of intelligent service and technical support to institutional and private investors, who need the same sophistication as larger firms."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester; 
New Life for Rundown Site on Yonkers Waterfront

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: YONKERS 

 BODY:
The $53 million Larkin Center the new home of the Yonkers Public Library and the city's Board of Education -- opened late last month, offering hope for the long-awaited rebirth of this city's downtown waterfront.
 The imposing concrete and glass structure on the site of the former Otis Elevator headquarters looks out on a formerly decaying industrial neighborhood, a 4.5 mile strip along the river, that these days is in a state of busy activity. 
 The 200,000-square-foot, four-story building -- its first two stories are double height -- is the first of a number of new waterfront buildings to be completed here. These projects include the $35 million renovation of the Metro-North Station across River Street from Larkin Center; it is scheduled to be finished next fall. A $10 million six-story municipal parking garage for 600 cars is nearing completion a block away. A $60 million, 266-apartment complex called Hudson Park, being built by Collins Enterprises of Stamford, Conn., next to the waterfront, is scheduled to be finished next summer. And work on the $13 million Esplanade Park, a 1.5-mile-long public promenade along the shoreline, has already been completed. 
For more than 40 years, city leaders have proffered grand plans for revitalizing the waterfront, but until recently few projects actually moved ahead. In 1987, a proposed 1,850-unit condominium project fell victim to a construction moratorium imposed in connection with a federal housing desegregation order. A year later, the city converted a power plant into a 136-unit condo called the Scrimshaw House. Although it is now fully occupied, Scrimshaw House was slow to fill up and stood alone on the desolate waterfront until last fall, when construction along the river began in earnest.
Considered a linchpin to the downtown's revitalization, Larkin Center is the city's largest investment in the waterfront district. The Yonkers Industrial Development Agency purchased the building from the city with $800,000 raised by selling revenue bonds. The city had purchased it from the Port Authority of New York, which bought it from Otis in the early 1980's and occupied until the late 1990's. The Industrial Development Agency then retained the Manhattan-based National Development Council -- a nonprofit organization that provides financial consulting to municipalities and other nonprofits -- to manage the project.
From that point on, financing and construction were overseen by the National Development Council's Housing and Economic Development Corporation -- which has built, among other things, 4,000 units of below-market-rate housing for various communities, residential buildings for the University of Washington in Seattle and parking garages in Syracuse. In Westchester, the council is building housing for a $6 million artists' community in Peekskill. 
Daniel Marsh III, president of the Housing and Economic Development Corporation, said the Yonkers project involved gutting, refacing and expanding by 40,000 square feet the original 160,000-square-foot, 77-year-old building, which Otis Elevator had occupied until 1983. (Elisha Otis began manufacturing elevators in Yonkers a few years after the railroad came to the city in 1849, spurring its development as an industrial center. Otis Elevator is now a subsidiary of the United Technologies Corporation, based in Hartford, and no longer has a presence in Yonkers.)
The first order of business when construction began two years ago was ridding the abandoned interior of the building of asbestos and a thick coating of bacteria-laden pigeon droppings -- "a particularly terrible combination," Mr. Marsh said. 
Edward A. Sheeran, a special assistant to Mayor John D. Spencer, said: "The building at that point was horrible to look at, but we all closed our eyes and visualized what it could be. We realized it had so much potential."
By the time the cleanup had been finished, only the frame, the floors and the roof of the older red building were retained. On the back side of the building, the original brick facade can still be seen. 
The National Development Council and the city commissioned Highland Associates of Clarks Summit, Pa., to be the architects for the project, providing them with a number of design objectives. Joseph G. Rominski, the project designer, said, "Our charge was to give the new building a strong civic presence and at the same time have it blend in to the existing context and character of the downtown waterfront." He noted that besides the industrial sites nearby, a Federal-style United States Post Office is to the south of the new Larkin Center.
The proximity of the Hudson River also influenced both the exterior and interior design. Outside, for energy conservation -- in particular as a shield against the harshest rays of the afternoon sun over the river -- Larkin Center's massive glass windows are tinted blue, in sharp contrast to its white concrete walls.
The plans for the interior evolved over two years in meetings held two and three times a month, said Stephen E. Force, director of the Yonkers Public Library. Most of the rooms -- including a number of public meeting rooms and the children's and teens' sections -- look out over the river and the Palisades on its west bank. Also in the new children's sections, the architecture incorporates images and shapes related to navigation, like sailboats and lighthouses. Since the city demolished its former Carnegie Library in 1982, the branch serving this neighborhood had been housed in temporary quarters, a former department store called Genung's, where the children's room was in the windowless basement.
With 1,800 library visitors expected daily, materials -- like the carpet tiles on the floors -- were chosen to withstand heavy use. Other materials include granite and stonelike porcelain tile in the public lobbies, wood veneers with contrasting tones on end panels and service desks and limestone panels on many interior walls, said Ronda Beemer, another architect on the project.
Meanwhile, in response to the new construction, some of the buildings in an existing 700,000-square-foot industrial park next to Larkin Center have been upgraded. In particular, Joseph Cotter, president of Hudson View Associates, which owns ipark, as it is called, said his company had recently spent $10 million to upgrade another Otis Elevator complex dating back to 1892.
The streetscapes in the industrial park, whose tenants include Kawasaki Rail Car and an extension of Mercy College, were also changed to blend with the street designs around the new construction. "The library has added a whole element of dynamism to the neighborhood," said Mr. Cotter, whose company also owns a 1.5-million-square-foot industrial park in Lake Success on Long Island.
The council is leasing 97,500 square feet of office space in Larkin Center to the Board of Education and 75,000 square feet to the public library. The remaining space -- the main entrance, a 43-foot-high atrium and a 464-seat auditorium -- will be used for a number of public and private purposes, including municipal functions and receptions. The floor of the entrance welcomes visitors with an elaborate design of the city's seal rendered in granite and tile.
At the ribbon cutting on Sept. 18, Gov. George E. Pataki described Larkin Center as "magnificent transformation of an abandoned industrial building" and said it had sent a signal that Yonkers's waterfront was finally being reborn.

HEADLINE: IN PERSON; 
Treating Health Care

BYLINE:  By SANDRA SALMANS 

DATELINE: PRINCETON 

 BODY:
RISA LAVIZZO-MOUREY was in middle school when she had her first lesson in the economics of health care. The Boeing Company was laying off workers, leaving them without health insurance. Her parents, both doctors practicing in a fairly poor Seattle neighborhood, had to decide each month which patients to bill.
 "I asked, 'What does insurance have to do with medical care?' " Ms. Lavizzo-Mourey recalled recently. 
 The answer, she learned, was "everything." 
At age 48, a doctor specializing in geriatrics, Dr. Lavizzo-Mourey (pronounced la-VEE-zo MOOR-ay) is still exploring the connection and -- like her parents, but on a national stage -- juggling the needs of health care providers and the uninsured. In December she will become chief executive of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation here, the nation's largest philanthropy devoted to health and health care. She will be the first woman and the first African-American to head the foundation, which has an endowment of about $8 billion and distributes more than $400 million a year.
Precisely where Dr. Lavizzo-Mourey will leave her mark is unclear. She has already been at Robert Wood Johnson for 18 months as a senior vice president, overseeing grant-making in the foundation's two health care areas -- improving access to health care and supporting people with such chronic illnesses as diabetes and asthma. The foundation's two other goals are reducing substance abuse and promoting healthy lifestyles -- the last goal, added last year, was partly inspired by the obesity epidemic. 
As Dr. Lavizzo-Mourey noted, grant-making occurs in three-year cycles, and she does not plan to micromanage operations. She does talk enthusiastically about increasing the role of information technology to reduce hospital errors and measure results, and about working in partnership with other foundations to have a greater effect.
"She's not one to slash and burn," noted Judith Rodin, president of the University of Pennsylvania, who is a longtime colleague. "She'll respect programs that have succeeded."
Her strength, said Dr. Rodin, lies in thinking creatively, in finding "nonobvious solutions."
Soft-spoken and low-key, Dr. Lavizzo-Mourey grew up with the expectation that she would become a doctor. She left the State University of New York at Stony Brook after her junior year to enter Harvard Medical School, then trained in geriatrics at the University of Pennsylvania. The constellation of chronic illnesses in elderly patients made the cases more intellectually challenging, she said, and she felt she could made a difference. Another factor was that with Medicare in place, "policy issues were front and center."
"I wanted to be a part of that." she said.
To complement her clinical skills, Dr. Lavizzo-Mourey next acquired an M.B.A. in health care administration from the Wharton School at Penn. In 1992 Dr. Louis Sullivan, then the secretary of Health and Human Services, recruited her to work in the first Bush administration. She stayed on as a member of the White House Task Force of Health Care Reform, the Clintons' ill-fated attempt to create a national health care system.
A signed photograph from Hillary Rodham Clinton hangs on her office wall at the foundation, but Dr. Lavizzo-Mourey diplomatically sidesteps any comments about Senator Clinton. She is at pains to avoid partisan politics, quickly pointing out that she was a Republican appointee. In seeking health care reform, the Clintons made the mistake of trying "to divorce policy and politics," she said.
"What I took away is that health care is an intensely political issue," she added, and that the American public is not ready for radical change. She still harbors some optimism that Medicare benefits will be extended to prescription drugs, but noted that change must be incremental.
"She'll still be committed to universal coverage, but in more imaginative ways," predicted Donna Shalala, who ran the Department of Health and Human Services in the Clinton administration. "She's been a player in health care policy for a while."
In the White House, added Dr. Shalala, who is now president of the University of Miami, "I had 250 people in health care policy, and she was one of the brightest."
When Congress resoundingly rejected health care reform in 1994, Dr. Lavizzo-Mourey returned to the University of Pennsylvania, where she headed the Institute on Aging. It was a period when hospitals, which had historically never given much thought to their bottom line, began to feel the financial pressures of managed care. 
"What was so impressive to me was that, on a number of occasions, we had to revise the budget and she'd come up with a plan to deal with the new reality," said William Kelly, who headed the university's health system at the time and persuaded her to come back to Penn. "It was a very difficult time and Risa was in the middle of it. She knows the real world of health care and the difficulties of trying to deliver the best possible health care in an environment where it's not rewarded."
At Penn, Dr. Lavizzo-Mourey made headlines by urging doctors to resume the largely abandoned practice of house calls. Her nurse practitioner made most of the calls, but every week Dr. Lavizzo-Mourey dropped in on new patients and a handful of others to check on their treatment. House calls show practitioners how patients actually live and the practical barriers to good health care, she noted, and can also save costs by preventing emergency room visits. 
At the same time, she kept a foot firmly planted in policy. Last spring she presented a report on racial and ethnic disparities in the delivery of health care. The report, issued by the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences, found that minorities had higher death rates, owing partly to different treatments for heart disease and cancer. But the disparities occurred even when racial groups had similar incomes and insurance coverage. A crucial factor, Dr. Lavizzo-Mourey said, was that neither doctors nor patients could get around racial and ethnic stereotypes.
The health care system is manipulated more effectively by people who are well educated, middle class, white and assertive, she said.
"Some people who feel they're being disrespected become passive," she said.
It is a situation she has seen with elderly patients as well as members of minority groups. She recalled times when a young relative of a geriatric patient "is hammering me with questions, and the patient is looking on in horror and pulls me aside and says, 'She's usually a nice person.' "
Dr. Lavizzo-Mourey understands first-hand how being a minority can affect the quality of health care. Soon after she moved to the Philadelphia area two decades ago, her daughter became ill and she rushed the toddler to a hospital. "What do any mother and child look like at 3 in the morning?" Dr. Lavizzo-Mourey asked. "Haggard, sleep-deprived."
The health care providers were "dismissive," she said, even when she used medical terms. "It wasn't until I said, 'Wait, I don't agree with that diagnosis; we have to get someone else in here' " that the hospital staff scrambled to help -- and found that the girl had pneumonia.
Now her daughter, a recent Princeton graduate, is working in Washington, her son has just graduated from high school, and Dr. Lavizzo-Mourey is an empty-nester. She and her husband, Robert, who has a doctorate in sociology but currently manages investments, are planning to move to Princeton. For the past year and a half, she has been commuting from a suburb of Philadelphia, getting on the road at 5:45 a.m. when "it's just me and the truckers," she said. 
Once she moves, she plans to resume a geriatric practice part-time -- including house calls -- through a faculty appointment at a medical school.
"In a job like this, it's easy to get out of touch," she observed. 
For the same reason, she has hung in her office a large photograph of her late mother, a pediatrician, examining a young boy. "It keeps me grounded," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Risa Lavizzo-Mourey, a specialist in geriatrics, will become chief executive of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, the nation's largest philanthropy devoted to health and health care, in December. (Christopher Barth for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The View From/Newtown; 
Over the Guardrail, The Other Side of Paradise

BYLINE:  By NANCY DONIGER 

 BODY:
WHEN Peggy and Gary Fillion moved into the Riverside section of Newtown last June, they thought they had just purchased a small piece of paradise. Nestled along the shore of the Housatonic River, they enjoy the river as their backyard. A pine forest where eagles roost frames the background. 
 "It's so nice sitting out back," Ms. Fillion said on a recent Sunday. "I can count 16 swans on the lake." 
 The Fillions paid only passing attention to the Interstate 84 guardrail at the top of a rising slope just 40 feet from their front lawn. When they were house hunting, they had always visited during midday when traffic flow was smoother and less noticeable than during rush hours. And, they were totally unprepared for the roar of cars and trucks that thunder past every night and into the morning. 
"I heard the tires screech the first night after we moved in and thought a truck had come over the guardrail," Ms. Fillion said.
The Fillions' neighbors have been complaining about traffic noise for almost 30 years to no avail. But truck and automobile debris flying off the highway, which threatens their safety, exceeds their displeasure with the noise pollution. Tires, mufflers and a leaf spring -- a piece of vehicle suspension -- are among the objects that have ejected over the guardrail into residential streets and yards where children play along Underhill Road and Waterview Drive.
One neighbor recounted several years ago when a buck was struck on the highway and catapulted off the overpass, landing near the place where Riverside children wait for the school bus each day. Before that, a truck carrying aluminum siding dumped its load over the same guardrail onto Riverside Road.
"If a car flipped over, it could come into my house," said Cheryl McGrath, who lives next door to the Fillions with her husband and two children. A tire landed on the Fillions' roof before they bought their house, Ms. McGrath said.
Reinvigorated by Ms. Fillion's lead, they are demanding action by the State Department of Transportation to keep their families safe. They want the D.O.T. to erect safety barriers and are no longer willing to accept the explanation that the state has no money for the job.
The neighbors also want protection from the air pollution caused by the unrelenting traffic because there is nothing to muffle either the din or the dust. Randall Pineau, who has lived with his wife and three sons on Waterview Drive for eight years, said the windows in his dining room shake and resonate from the traffic vibration. Douglas Ross, who also has lived in Riverside for eight years, said the vibration has caused nails to pop out of the sheet rock at his house. 
Mr. Ross said he believed it is only a matter of time before an accident happens. "It's not a question of if, but when," he said.
Ms. Fillion and the other neighbors said they knew they were moving to houses near the highway, but they never imagined the magnitude of the problem. None of them had spent the night with the roar of traffic, much of it from tractor trailers, until they moved in. 
"We absolutely loved the waterfront," Ms. Fillion said. "Where else are you going to find this kind of pristine, rural site within 60 miles of New York? When we looked at the house it was midday, and the traffic wasn't running that much. We moved here from Michigan where there were barriers everywhere along the highway. We assumed the noise wasn't that bad since there were no barriers. We were rudely awakened by the sound of construction and trucks during the evening and early morning."
Before the neighbors moved in, they said they were unaware of the falling debris and did not think, once they settled, the state would permit such a dangerous condition to persist.
Desmond P. Dickey, D.O.T. transportation planner, said the earliest complaint his department has on record from Riverside was logged in August 1981. The D.O.T. has received 40 or 50 complaints over the years, he said. The neighbors' activism has gotten them to 36th place on a list of 145 neighborhoods waiting for wooden noise walls, otherwise known as Type II retrofit barriers. 
Mr. Dickey said that the barriers are in high demand, but "they are not specifically engineered for safety. They do provide extra safety beyond the parapet, or guardrail, that acts as a crash protection system." 
Mr. Dickey also said the barriers are funded solely through the state, "which is always looking for ways to trim fat. The State Legislature stopped funding the barriers during the recession in 1990 and never restored any money."
A moratorium has been in effect since then, he said.
Not satisfied with that answer and worried about their safety, the neighbors have brought their grievance to the attention of Representative James Maloney, who in turn contacted First Selectman Herb Rosenthal and requested his assistance.
Mr. Maloney said the United States Federal Highway Administration provides funding for protective barriers to the state to use at its discretion. Although Connecticut already has a priority list for barriers for noise abatement, Mr. Maloney said safety has to take priority over sound.
"Kids could be hurt waiting at the bus stop," Mr. Maloney said. "We have to start with the notion that this is a legitimate safety concern that requires moving Riverside to the top of the priority list."
Mr. Dickey said he would move the bus stop to a site deemed safer than directly under a bridge. "That would be my decision," he said. "Common sense would dictate that any object coming off the highway could fall there. People sometimes throw things from moving vehicles. We have no control over that."
But Ms. Fillion said moving the bus stop would be difficult because the highway is so omnipresent along the road throughout the Riverside lake community. 
Mary Kelly, the Newtown Public Schools transportation director, said no one has ever requested moving the bus stop to a safer location. "This is the first I'm hearing about discontent with the bus stop," Ms. Kelly said. "We have never had any problem at the stop nor any request to move it."
The traffic has worsened over the years, a trend D.O.T. officials expect to continue. When the Newtown section of the I-84 expressway opened in 1973, it carried 27,000 vehicles daily. As of Dec. 31, 2001, the traffic volume has more than doubled to 70,000 vehicles daily. Truck traffic also has risen, although the D.O.T. does not keep a specific count of truck volume in this section of highway, according to Cliff Jones, a state traffic control planner for the D.O.T.
Big rigs are the worst offenders when it comes to noise and falling debris, according to the neighbors. Truck drivers regularly apply their "Jake Brakes" as they approach the curve before the nearby Rochambeau Bridge, the neighbors said. This term refers to a kind of engine-compression braking system manufactured by the Jacob Brake Company of Windsor that save wear and tear on tires but emit a loud, screeching sound. To make matters worse, the D.O.T. temporarily has lowered the speed limit from 65 to 55 miles per hour during ongoing road construction estimated to continue at least until the first of the year. This causes trucks to apply their brakes even more than usual, the neighbors said.
Mr. Rosenthal is arranging a meeting between the neighbors, D.O.T. officials, Mr. Maloney and Newtown's state delegation. 
"If they can demonstrate this is a safety issue, clearly we want to help them," Mr. Rosenthal said. "We have to protect their houses from tires flying off trucks."
State Representative Julia Wasserman said she tried unsuccessfully five years ago to get sound barriers in Riverside. "If there is a concern about safety, we have to take care of that," Ms. Wasserman said. 
State Senator John McKinney said he believed the neighbors have good reason to demand a solution. "The D.O.T. has a responsibility to make sure people are safe on and under the highways," he said. "That's a much higher public policy issue than getting sound barriers."

Ms. Fillion and her neighbors have asked the D.O.T. to erect noise barriers, which would also provide a barrier to the falling debris. (Photographs by Debbi Morello for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: At Madison Avenue and 128th Street; 
First Permanent Office For Legal Aid Society

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
While a couple of high-profile developments in Harlem have been canceled or shelved recently, foundations were being poured at Madison Avenue and 128th Street for the Legal Aid Society's new five-story, $18 million neighborhood office.
 Former Mayor David N. Dinkins said he was overjoyed that the society had "chosen this location for their first permanent home," referring to the organization's decision -- after 126 years of being a tenant -- to develop its own property. 
 The design of the building, by the Phillips Group, is meant to be anything but proprietary. From the broad, two-story entry arch to the red bricks and double-hung windows like those on nearby row houses, the building is intended to signal "our integration into the life of this neighborhood," said Daniel L. Greenberg, the society's president. 
At a time of concern about gentrification, the symbolism and reality of the Legal Aid Society's expansion in Harlem is an enormously positive statement, said Deborah C. Wright, the president and chief executive of Carver Bancorp.
Today, the society's Harlem office occupies about 10,000 square feet on the eighth and ninth floors of the former Hotel Theresa at Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard and 125th Street. Its new building is to have 29,000 square feet.
Having determined that it would be as economical to build as to lease, the society bought the vacant lot on Madison Avenue for $300,000 in 2000.
In order to construct an office that filled the full lot without setbacks, the society obtained a zoning variance from the Board of Standards and Appeals on the ground that it is a community facility.
Construction began in July and is so far along that "we had to truck the dirt in" for the groundbreaking last Monday, said Dan Kessler, the general services director. Completion is anticipated in the fall of 2003. The contractor, the Pavarini-McGovern Construction Corporation, was chosen in part because of its commitment to involve minority subcontractors, said Theresa de Leon, the chief operating officer of the society. Financing will come from the sale of $18 million in Industrial Development Agency bonds.
The Harlem office is one of seven neighborhood units of the civil division. The eighth, in Lower Manhattan, was housed with the headquarters at 90 Church Street, which is still closed after being filled with contaminants from the collapse of the World Trade Center. Headquarters are now at 1 Battery Park Plaza. The Lower Manhattan office will soon reopen at 199 Water Street. DAVID W. DUNLAP

HEADLINE: Antidotes to Sprawl Taking Many Forms 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
OF the 62 acres purchased two years ago by a developer in the town of Greenburgh, five miles north of New York City in Westchester County, only 10 are being developed -- creating 86 attached homes while preserving the rest as wooded open space.
In Willingboro, N.J., 20 miles south of Trenton, a bankrupt and abandoned 1950's-style open-air shopping mall surrounded by what were once the cookie-cutter tracts of the third Levittown development is being resuscitated as a mixed-use community. The new Willingboro Town Center will have 210 three-story town houses concentrated in 30-unit enclaves, a library, a college building, an amphitheater overlooking a computerized 16-jet fountain, a supermarket, small retail stores and a pharmaceutical company's vast mail-order distribution plant, all in walking distance of bus and light-rail connections to Trenton, Camden and beyond.
To the roll call of often-conflicting parties engaged in the development process, both regionally and locally, the Greenburgh and Willingboro projects are prime examples of "smart growth."
It is a phrase and a movement and a cause for some contention -- if only over what truly constitutes "smart growth" -- that in recent years has permeated the dialogue among planners, politicians, environmentalists and public health advocates, not to mention developers. 
It is everybody's remedy, although with varying doses and ingredients, for sprawl. 
In essence, smart growth calls for the creation of higher-density communities within walking distance of transportation, shopping, schools and, where possible, jobs; or the redevelopment of underutilized and sometimes environmentally tainted sites, often in an urban core. All of which is intended to reduce automobile congestion -- both to and from the suburbs, as well as within a city -- promote walking, save open space and lower tax burdens by reducing the need for new infrastructure.
And while, like apple pie, it is hard to find anyone who opposes smart growth, some developers do raise questions: about the looseness of the definition -- a legitimate concern given government support for some projects -- about the balance between calls for land preservation and the incessant need for more housing, and about land-use restrictions lowering property values, even if they curtail sprawl.
"Sprawl's been criticized for decades, from social critics dating back to the 1920's to the 1950's when suburban development really took off," said Don Chen, director of Smart Growth America, a nonprofit advocacy group. "But even though the problem has been around for a while, it really has only taken off as an important political issue and market issue in the last 5 to 10 years."
In 1998, at a meeting of a group called the Smart Growth Network in Washington, advocates, planners and developers adopted a 10-point protocol calling for, among other things, "walkable neighborhoods," a variety of transportation choices, development directed toward existing communities, compact building design, mixed-use development and preservation of open space. Soon after, the National Governors Association adopted the principles.
In recent years, polls conducted by the Federal Highway Administration and the National Association of Realtors documented mounting public frustration with automobile congestion. 
At the same time, researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta have conducted studies linking sprawl and traffic congestion to health problems among Americans, particularly obesity and cardiovascular disease due to lack of physical activity and fuel particulates in the air. "Basically, there are concerns that many health and environmental problems that we face are generated by the inefficient land-use patterns that market-driven, speculative sprawl has imprinted on the countryside," said Dr. Elliott Sclar, a professor of urban planning at Columbia University. "If your kid gets driven to school every day or if you go through the McDonald's drive-through for your Big Mac and a milk shake, you're going to have a hard time keeping the weight off."
For more than a decade, activists say, the New York State-chartered Empire State Development Corporation and the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection have promoted projects incorporating smart-growth principles -- largely through planning grants and tax incentives -- a strategy more recently adopted by the Connecticut Development Authority.
State and local initiatives are currently supporting projects as varied as the reconfiguring of a fishing village on Long Island, the conversion of an 1856 lock factory in a rundown section of Norwalk, Conn., into office space -- with new housing on adjacent lots -- and, on a broader scale, the transfer of development rights from tracts of privately owned wilderness to parcels already zoned for construction.
Population trends are an impelling reason that smart growth has increasingly seeped into the development debate. "If you see demographics as destiny," said Mr. Chen, "it makes sense that there was an enormous suburban housing boom in the 50's to accommodate G.I.'s returning from the war front, and after that baby boomers, to address overcrowding in cities."
"Now," Mr. Chen continued, "as our demographic profile changes, there's increasing interest in in-town living, not only among young people, but also baby boomers as they become empty-nesters and start to retire. They see advantages to living in places with greater sense of community, more convenience. And that trend will be more pronounced over the next two decades."
THE transformation of the old mall in Willingboro seems an indicator of the trend.
"It's being converted to a mixed-use town center where people can live, work, shop, study and walk," said Robert Stang, managing member of Renewal Realty, the developer of the Willingboro center.
What the developers found when they first surveyed the site in 1998 was nearly 600,000 square feet of retail space in abandoned buildings -- including a Woolworth's, a Sears and an Acme supermarket -- at the core of 56 acres and surrounded by "a sea of parking lots," Mr. Stang said. Surrounding that were 11,500 single-family homes.
"It was the third Levittown, built in the late 50's," Mr. Stang said. "It's name was changed because it was too close to the second Levittown, in Pennsylvania."
The mall had been a retail hub along Route 130 -- until Interstate 295 came through town in the mid-70's. The interstate, with big-box stores like Home Depot off its exit ramps, "sucked the retail out of the Route 130 corridor," Mr. Stang said.
His company, Mr. Stang said, paid the previous owner, who had long tried to attract a brand-name anchor store, $185,000 for all 56 acres. "I figured I could never get hurt," he said. "It would always be worth more than that."
With backing from the town, which took temporary title to the land, Renewal Realty received a $2 million low-interest loan to clean up the property. "The town had title, but we could acquire it for a dollar after we cleaned it up," Mr. Stang said. 
Soon after, a master plan was drawn up very much in line with what Mr. Chen of Smart Growth America says is a growing trend toward replacing old malls "with entire P.U.D.'s -- planned unit developments -- meaning instead of building one house here, one house there, you build a community with residential, commercial, civic uses."
Willingboro's mayor, Paul Stephenson, is enthusiastic about what has arrived and soon will come. Merck-Medco, a subsidiary of the pharmaceutical company, took over a 100,000-square-foot existing building, added another 100,000 square feet and after opening its mail-order center "brought nearly 1,000 jobs into our community," Mayor Stephenson said. Burlington County College leased 19,000 square feet of existing space for a satellite classroom building. A supermarket and smaller retail stores have opened.
"The next piece," the mayor said, "is about 200 housing units that will primarily serve folks who have already raised their children, looking for transition from a big house to something more manageable." The first homes, for rental and later for sale, will be completed in about a year.
"Now," Mayor Stephenson said, "we take that mix and add our own investment -- a library-media center, an amphitheater and a magnificent fountain."
"With the advent of the national trend toward people seeking gathering places within their communities," he said, "this is smart growth right on time."
The advent has actually been a long time coming.
"Smart growth is certainly a new term," said Dr. Sclar at Columbia, "but the concern with sprawl -- meaning that the metropolitan area was growing in an unplanned pattern -- goes back to the turn of the last century."
Professor Sclar cited Forest Hills Gardens in central Queens, built in 1909, as "basically what the smart-growth people are hoping to recreate in the 21st century."
Designed by Frederick Law Olmsted Jr., son of the landscape architect of Central Park, Forest Hills Gardens is a 142-acre community of large homes and row houses -- many bearing the red-tile roofs, turrets and dormers in the English Tudor style -- lining winding, tree-arched streets and spacious greenways.
"When you go from Station Square," Dr. Sclar said -- referring to the Olde English town plaza where the Long Island Rail Road stops -- "you walk under an archway into the greenway and there's smaller attached houses, one apartment building and the elementary school, P.S. 101. Then as you go further into the Gardens, the lot sizes and houses get bigger." One block north of the train station is Austin Street, lined with almost every conceivable sort of store, and Continental Avenue, where the subway to Manhattan stops.
"What the smart-growth people are talking about these days is basically to expand the supply of Forest Hills Gardenses," Dr. Sclar said. "The problem is the regionalists of the last century were never able to make this the standard, so you ended up with highways, strip malls, social isolation."
In 1929, an influential nonprofit group, the Regional Plan Association, asked Charles Dyer Norton, a famous planner, to help draft a development strategy for New York City. "When Norton came to New York, he realized such a movement here would have to be regional," said Thomas Wright, the current executive vice president of the association. "You couldn't plan for the city alone and address the fundamental issues because New York already was starting to function as a metropolitan region; people were already starting to commute."
The committee eventually created a comprehensive regional plan, calling for major investments in infrastructure, open-space preservation and new communities similar to Forest Hills Gardens. It included ambitious proposals for highways and railroads.
"The point is that the highways were built much more quickly than the railroads," Mr. Wright said. "Therefore, we developed in a more automobile-dependent manner."
And after World War II, the nation experienced the suburban boom, fueled by federal policies encouraging home ownership -- the tax deduction for mortgages and the Interstate Highway Act -- "which provided enormous funding for building the Interstates," he said, "while, at the same time, mass transit was essentially going bankrupt."
"How do you undo that?" Mr. Wright asked. "How do you retrofit sprawl to create communities that have the benefits of open space, diversity, opportunity."
Some developers have some ideas.
Martin Ginsburg is president of GDC, which has built about 3,000 homes, most of them town houses, in Westchester, Rockland and Fairfield Counties. In Greenburgh, N.Y., the company bought 62 acres of green space for $5 million and named it -- appropriately -- Wyldwood.
"There was a strong movement in the community to keep it open space," Mr. Ginsburg said, "but they couldn't raise the money to buy all 62 acres, so we came up with a compromise." With financing assistance from the state, Westchester County and the nonprofit Open Space Institute, the town bought 42 of the acres to be preserved as open space.
"We ended up developing 86 units on 10 of the remaining 20 acres," Mr. Ginsburg said. "The result was less development, but some development, on only 10 of the 62 acres."
In a more urban setting -- along a rundown riverfront stretch in Norwalk, Conn. -- Kim Morque's company, Spinnaker Development, has converted an old lock factory into 104,000 square feet of "nontraditional office space."
"It's open; exposed-beam ceilings, brick walls," Mr. Morque said. "Tenants devise their space according to their needs."
From 1856 to the mid-1950's, the three-story building was the Norwalk Lock Company. In recent decades, until Spinnaker bought it for $3.25 million in March 2000, it housed "small manufacturers, carpenters, artists, even a sailmaker," Mr. Morque said.
"This is smart growth because we are recycling land, taking industrial sites and brownfields and creating new projects," he said. "And because we're using an existing building, we're utilizing existing utilities -- water, electrical, sewage -- and not building new infrastructure."
The building is five blocks from the South Norwalk train station. "About 250 people work there," Mr. Morque said. "They can walk to lunch, shop on nearby Washington Street. Many of them live in the area."
Across the street, Mr. Morque said, plans call for construction of 10 condominiums, 3,000 square feet of commercial and 5,000 square feet of street-level retail space. "Then we have plans for 200 apartments and a hotel on the site to the east," he said.
For Jim Tripp and Eric Kulleseid, two prominent land-preservation activists in the New York area, Mr. Morque's downtown Norwalk redevelopment and even Mr. Ginsburg's limited development on 62 acres in Greenburgh are significant examples of smart growth. But their sights are set on far more ambitious efforts to limit sprawl and protect vast tracts of open space.
"It may be smart growth on a microscale to cluster development on a fraction of the parcel and set aside the remainder for open space," said Mr. Tripp, general counsel for Environmental Defense, a national nonprofit organization. "But you can take that notion and look at the whole metropolitan area, much more macroscale, and ask yourself: what large pieces of land do we want to protect that are in private ownership, where we could redirect development to other more appropriate places?"
Mr. Tripp and Mr. Kulleseid, who is the New York State director of the nonprofit Trust for Public Land, believe it is vital to preserve, among other swaths of wilderness, up to 500,000 privately owned acres of forest in the undulating highlands that stretch through northern New Jersey, across the Hudson and into Connecticut, as well as 100,000 acres in Suffolk County called the Long Island Pine Barrens.
Mr. Kulleseid's group is one of a network of organizations that specialize in finding funds to compensate landowners who sign easements agreeing never to allow development on their property. "We need forests and wetlands because they give us clean water, places to be physical and not just denizens of the local mall," Mr. Kulleseid said. And, viewing forests as akin to lungs, he said, "They soak up greenhouse gases and give back oxygen."
Mr. Tripp of Environmental Defense is also chairman of the Pine Barrens Credit Clearinghouse, an arm of the Long Island Pine Barrens Commission. The commission was created by state legislation to preserve about 100,000 acres of pitch pine and oak forest in the sandy soil that forms a sort of spine through the Suffolk County towns of Brookhaven, Riverhead and Southhampton.
Under the plan, two tools are used to protect privately owned land. One is outright acquisition, for which the county and state have spent about $100 million. The other is the transfer of development rights.
UNDER the transfer program, private landowners in the core of the Pine Barrens can be allocated development rights based on the amount of land they own and the applicable zoning. If, for example, the zoning is one house per acre, the landowner is entitled to one credit, which can be sold to any developer who owns land where the three towns have designated a receiving area for higher-density development.
"The developer knows that rather than building one house for every two acres, for example, he or she could build a house on every acre," Mr. Tripp said. "What the landowner in the Pine Barrens must do to obtain this right is record a conservation easement on the property. They retain the title, but they can't develop it." 
"And this does not cost the public a cent," he said. "The saving of that land, in effect, has been paid for by developers who find it economically worthwhile to build higher-density development."
A bit farther east, at the tip of Long Island's South Shore, local officials and developers hope to devise a smart-growth plan for the tiny fishing village of Montauk in the town of East Hampton.
"Growth has been constrained by outdated zoning and by a single loop road in and out of the dock area," said Jonathan F. P. Rose, president of the Jonathan Rose Companies. Mr. Rose's firm has been asked to draft a plan "that allows businesses to grow, creates housing and rationalizes traffic."
Rather than allowing development to spread, the key might be the renovation of a half-dozen ramshackle hotels, said Town Supervisor Jay Schneiderman. "There's the fishing pier, and right across from it you have this blighted area, all these boarded-up buildings," he said.
"The community is facing a challenge to provide adequate housing for workers," Mr. Schneiderman continued, "and one thought is to create employee housing in this area, and, at the same time, some new shops and offices. Of course, there would be pedestrian areas, open space. And there might be apartments over the shops." 
Whatever plan is adopted should retain, said Mr. Rose, the developer, "the funky nautical character of the place, and not make it a sanitized touristy resort."
 Supervisor Schneiderman said, "All ideas are on the table."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 6
