HEADLINE: EDUCATION; 
University Merger Closes In on Reality

BYLINE:  By JOHN SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
DESPITE vehement opposition from politicians and some quarters of the medical establishment, sources close to Governor McGreevey said last week that a commission was poised to recommend a merger between Rutgers University, the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and the New Jersey Institute of Technology.
 Under the controversial plan, each of three university campuses -- in Newark, New Brunswick and Camden -- would operate independently under separate chancellors, with a statewide board of trustees providing general guidance. 
 The panel of 15 business leaders and health care administrators -- formally known as the Commission on Health Science, Education and Technology -- was scheduled to make its recommendations public last week, sources said, but the turmoil over Robert Torricelli's withdrawal from the Senate race derailed those plans.
If three days of contentious hearings last month were any indication, the merger, which would require the approval of the State Legislature, presents the governor with what could be his fiercest political battle since taking office, particularly because much opposition has come from within his own Democratic Party.
"My goal right now is to develop a good blueprint," Governor McGreevey said in an interview last week. "This is critically important to our competitiveness." 
But blistering criticism from several sources, particularly legislators in Essex County, where U.M.D.N.J. is situated, imperil the initiative. For now, it is difficult to sort out where the questions over the quality of education end and political issues begin.
Politicians in Essex County are worried that any such overhaul will mean a shift in power and resources from Newark to New Brunswick. They believe that the presence of U.M.D.N.J. has been a lure and a steadying influence in Newark, helping the city recover from the desolation and the diaspora in the aftermath of the 1967 riots.
Assemblyman Eric Munoz, a Republican from Summit who is a trauma surgeon and a professor at the New Jersey Medical School, said, "U.M.D.N.J. and the hospital in Newark serve a tremendous need for the people in northern New Jersey." 
State Senator Ronald Rice, a Democrat from Essex County, was more blunt.
At a hearing last month, Mr. Rice said that any proposal to merge Rutgers, with 50,000 students spread over three campuses, with U.M.D.N.J., overseeing 4,500 students, and the Institute of Technology, with 9,000 students, would be "dead upon arrival in the State Legislature."
"This is not about education and health care -- maybe you think it is," Mr. Rice told members of the panel, who were said to favor merging the schools into one enormous university system like the University of California. "This is about money, contract awards, power and control of jobs."
One crucial Essex County legislator, Richard J. Codey, the Democratic co-president of the Senate from West Orange, tried to lay the groundwork for compromise last week when he said he could not support any proposal that did not allow local control over the medical school and the hospital. 
"We are not going to give up local governance," Mr. Codey said. "There will be continuing dialogue, and we will see if something can be worked out to improve the local university and the hospital, but to keep local governance."
But politicians were not the only people opposed to the merger.
At last month's hearings, many in the medical community were equally concerned about reinventing the university system. For instance, U.M.N.D.J. brought consultants from Boston, Education Alliance, who testified that putting the medical and dental school under Rutgers would "stunt growth and development plans" and "disenfranchise U.M.D.N.J.'s significant community investment."
A vice president of the Oregon Health and Science University, James Samels offered the commission a report that a merger would "stunt" the university.
Albert Talone, president of the New Jersey Association of Osteopathic Physicians and Surgeons, testified that U.M.D.N.J. should remain independent. "The thought of changing this is just unthinkable, " he said.
Lester Lieberman, chairman of the Health Care Foundation of New Jersey, citing the growing research revenue coming into U.M.D.N.J., said a merger would slow the university's momentum. And George Pruitt, president of Thomas Edison State College, spoke against the merger, saying: "Rutgers does not suffer from a lack of complexity. It suffers from a lack of focus."
Still, there were those who spoke in favor of the merger over the three days of hearings in Stratford, Camden County, and New Brunswick as well as Newark. They insisted that the plan did not call for a unified system under one large bureaucracy. Rather, they said, the plan envisioned three smaller, better-coordinated schools to replace the sometimes confusing array institutions that now exist.
Dr. Norman Edelman, a member of the commission and former dean of the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School, said that his group had heard much testimony in closed meetings in favor of changes at U.M.D.N.J., noting, "Among the problems we identified is a large, bureaucratic and controlling central administration."
Dorothy DeMaio, a former dean of the Rutgers School of Nursing, said that she favored a merger because Rutgers and U.M.D.N.J. wasted money by duplicating services and that "the drive to control the education of all health care providers has been a wild, costly and divisive ride."
Though the hearings highlighted the opposition to a merger, that was neither unusual nor unexpected. And it apparently did not deter Mr. McGreevey and the commission -- headed by P. Roy Vagelos, a former chairman of Merck & Company -- from moving forward. In a recent interview, Governor McGreevey said he was committed to changing the structure of the university system to improve research and education, particularly in medicine and biotechnology.
Yet many people have commented that the timing could be better, since all three of the state's major public universities are in flux. Rutgers is searching for a new president and an appointment is imminent, the New Jersey Institute of Technology recently appointed a new president, and the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey lost three top officials after a new board chairman was appointed.
In an interview after the first public hearing, Dr. Vagelos said the governor asked him to map a course by which New Jersey -- which has several good schools and a strong research presence from pharmaceutical companies -- could develop a great medical school to compete with the universities and research hospitals in New York and Philadelphia.
"New Jersey is one of the states which should have one of the great health education centers in the United States," Dr. Vagelos said. "We have the infrastructure. It is a matter of putting it together."
Supporters of the commission's proposal contend that the creation of independent schools will allow for better coordination, and will produce more compelling grant applications, the lifeblood of prestigious medical schools. Although New Jersey currently ranks among the top five states in terms of private biomedical research, it is 24th when it comes to receiving federal funds for that purpose.
To that end, Governor McGreevey said improving the universities was crucial to the state's economy, particularly when it came to retaining jobs in the pharmaceutical industry. 
"We have more patent development in the private sector than in the public sector," he said. "We have Merck, Johnson & Johnson, but there is no university partner."
As for the concerns about Newark's future, supporters of a merger insist there will be no less of in commitment to any communities served by state medical schools and affiliated hospitals.
Former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, who is president of Drew University and advises Governor McGreevey on education, said he felt certain that the governor would not support a proposal that diminished the state's support for the medical school or the hospital in Newark.
"I am personally convinced that if this happens, Newark will be a better place," said Mr. Kean. "There will be more independence, not less, in Newark."
For that reason, Mr. Kean said, it was in the interest of Newark, and the entire state, to improve the universities.
"Rutgers is a good place, but it is not a great place," he said. "And we all want to make it a great place."

HEADLINE: F.Y.I. 

BYLINE:  By ED BOLAND Jr.; E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com

 BODY:
The Phantom Mailbox

Q. I have to walk for blocks before I can find a mailbox. I don't remember them being so scarce. Are their numbers declining?

A. The Postal Service is indeed scaling back the number of street mailboxes in New York, according to a spokeswoman, Pat McGovern. The main reasons, she said, are security and economy.
 To save money, the post office has begun removing boxes that average fewer than 25 pieces of mail per day. Ms. McGovern says many people are now putting on postage themselves but mailing items from work (although the occasional personal letter has been known to slip out on the company dime). 
 The post office has also been removing mailboxes for security since 9/11. It has taken boxes from high-profile spots like airports and the sites of government buildings. 
There are still close to 8,000 mailboxes throughout the city and, as Ms. McGovern points out, postal carriers also pick up stamped mail in any personal mailboxes.

Lincoln, Coast to Coast

Q. The western end of the Lincoln Highway, America's first one to go coast to coast, was honored with a new marker last month in San Francisco. Are any still left in New York?

A. No. It seems that at some unknown point New York lost the markers that indicated its inclusion.
Opened in 1913, the Lincoln Highway was the first paved highway to stretch from the Atlantic to the Pacific. It began in Times Square and headed west on 42nd Street to the New York Central Ferry Terminal. In New Jersey, cars could continue through Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Iowa, Nebraska, Wyoming, Utah and Nevada, all the way to Lincoln Park in San Francisco.
The route was chosen for directness; it's about as straight as a 3,000-mile highway can be, although when the Holland Tunnel was opened in 1927, the Lincoln Highway was rerouted through the tunnel.
In 1925 the American Association of State Highway Officials decided to end the confusing system of named highways and use numbered routes. By the time the Lincoln Highway was rerouted through the Holland Tunnel, it was better known as Route 9. The highway still exists under different names; from Philadelphia to Wyoming, it is Route 30.
On Sept. 1, 1928, thousands of Boy Scouts spread out along the highway and installed concrete markers, about one per mile, each of which carried a small bust of Lincoln and the inscription, "This Highway dedicated to Abraham Lincoln." It was just such a marker that was recently reinstalled in California.
"The New York City area had such an established transportation system in place -- subways, trolleys, interurban rails -- the Lincoln Highway was no big thing," said Frank Curcio, a Lincoln Highway Association officer. "West of Philadelphia, but especially in the Midwest and mountain states, the Lincoln Highway was the biggest thing since the transcontinental railroad."
The Lincoln Highway marker closest to New York is in Princeton Township, N.J., on State Highway 27.

Pistol-Packing Police

Q. When did New York police officers begin carrying guns?

A. While the Police Department officially began in 1845, it was not until 1887 that its officers were required to carry a firearm. In 1887 the New York City Police Manual of Rules and Regulations added Rule 503, which read: "In addition to the ordinary baton of the patrolman each member of the Police Force shall be armed while on duty with a revolving pistol of pattern and caliber approved by the board." Since then, New York cops have carried guns.
In 1896 the police adopted a .32-caliber revolver as the department standard; that was changed to .38-caliber in 1901. In 1993 the standard service weapon was changed to a 9-millimeter semiautomatic pistol, which remains the norm today. ED BOLAND Jr.

HEADLINE: Fighting to Save a Doo-Wop Diner 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: WILDWOOD CREST 

 BODY:
THE Surfside Restaurant sits like a hearty smile on the Doo-Wop stretch of Ocean Avenue here. It is all aqua and orange and melon and bubble gum pink, with an angular roof and hexagonal body, a wonder of mid-20th-century commercial architecture.
 But time is running out for the Surfside. The owners of the Waters Edge, a hulking motel behind, have bought the 39-year-old restaurant and have scheduled it for demolition by the end of the month to pave the way for expansion. 
 Local preservationists are about as angry over the restaurant's plight as Dion was over Runaround Sue. And the leader of the group is Jack Morey, the leader of the group whose family owns most of the amusement piers on the storied boardwalk here as well as several other major properties on the island -- including the new StarLux Motel, with its kidney-shaped pool, Art Deco furniture and a lava lamp in every room.
"Obviously, I am an advocate of this type of architecture," Mr. Morey said. "But what we want to make sure of is that Wildwood has a distinctive feel and can capitalize financially on it."
What Mr. Morey and his group want to do is raise enough money to have the Surfside dismantled instead of demolished, as the owners of the Waters Edge had planned. Then the preservationists would put the pieces in storage, with the notion of reconstructing it either as an information booth at an entrance to town or a beach gazebo -- or maybe even resurrected as a restaurant on another site. Officials in Wildwood Crest have even said that they might like to use it as a visitors' center.
To that end, Mr. Morey said, the group needed $20,000 in pledges by Oct. 15. To date, about $6,000 has been collected.
The owners of the Waters Edge declined to comment, other than to insist that that the last thing they wanted to do was make an addition, not waves.
"They told us they were willing to do it, but they can't wait forever," said Dan MacElrevey, the president of the Greater Wildwood Hotel-Motel Association. "This is only one issue, but it is symbolic and we have to understand that."
Mr. MacElrevey said that he was concerned there had been 13 demolition permit applications filed this year for what the association felt were landmark buildings. Some are classics of the 1950's and 60's like the Ala Kai Motel, the Catalina Motel and the Ebb Tide Motel.
Oddly enough, he blamed the good economy, saying that some long-term owners felt they would get a good price for their motel.
"It seems to be a question of whether you want to sell out now and move to Miami or make some renovations and get the money back over time," Mr. MacElrevey said. "I assure you, there is money to be made running a motel here, and many of us feel the way to keep that going is to preserve what we have."
Some people call the plethora of mid-20th century motels in the Wildwoods Jetsonian or Googie architecture, but the Doo-Wop Preservation League likes their term, since it evokes the music and spirit of the post-World War II era in which Wildwood burgeoned as a middle-class resort. In fact, the Greater Wildwood Hotel Motel Association met recently to decide how to have the motel strip declared a national historic district.
"It was overwhelming," said Mr. MacElrevey. "I think it was 31 to 1 to do our best to preserve the motels the way they are. This doesn't mean not to make improvements. A lot of us have put up new neon, made rooms into suites, used open space better. But we want to have a resort that has some distinction."
For his part, Michael John is fixing his last few breakfasts at the Surfside. His father, Tomi, a Greek immigrant, came down here from Camden, in the early 1960's.
"The story is that he came to America on July Fourth, started this restaurant on July Fourth, 1963, and died on July Fourth, 1994," said Mr. John, who now has a catering business here.
Still, he would like to see the preservationists succeed in saving the Surfside. Though Mr. John declined to say how much he was paid for restaurant, a comparable location in town would sell for $500,000 to $1 million.
The last scheduled meal at the restaurant is a Lions Club benefit -- the Tomi John Pancake Breakfast -- on Oct. 13. "It will be a good thing to end on," said Mr. John. "I think everyone likes this place, and I hope it gets a new life somewhere else."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The owners of a motel behind the Surfside Restaurant on Ocean Avenue want to demolish it and expand.; Michael John, whose father built the Surfside in 1963, recently sold it to the adjacent motel. (Photographs by Michael Sypniewski for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES; 
In Millburn, The Accent Is Russian

BYLINE:  By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: MILLBURN 

 BODY:
ON a third-floor window of a corner building, high above the thrum of Audis and Jaguars cruising the length of Millburn Avenue, is a painted silhouette of a couple and the words Royal Ballroom.
 Yet Alex and Tanya Koulik, Russian immigrants who opened the studio here four years ago -- one of four that they own -- are among a large influx of Russians who have immigrated to this affluent pocket of Essex County over the last 20 years. 
 That surge has given this township of 19,765 the distinction -- along with Fair Lawn in Bergen County -- of having the highest percentage of residents of Russian descent in the state at 11.7 percent. By comparison, only 2.3 percent of New Jersey's 8.4 million residents are Russian. 
Just why so many new -- and not particularly wealthy -- immigrants would feel comfortable in one of the most exclusive towns in North Jersey, where the median household income is $130,848 and housing prices often begin at a half-million dollars, has to do with more than just the tango.
"I don't know what most Russians will tell you why they live in this community," said Mr. Koulik, a lithe man of 44, "but I believe the major reason is the schools."
The Kouliks say they moved to an apartment in Short Hills in 1997, five years after coming to this country, because they wanted their son, Vitali, now 21 and a four-time ballroom dancing champion, to attend Millburn High School, ranked among the top public schools in the country. So did the families of two of the Kouliks' students, Michael Lubavin and Yelena Vaynshteyn.
"For us, the main attraction was the school system, especially the Millburn High School," said Mr. Lubavin, a 19-year-old sophomore at Columbia University.
As for Ms. Vaynshteyn, 24, a dental student at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, she said her mother moved to Short Hills 11 years ago from Brooklyn because of the school system.
Keith Neigel, the principal at the high school, said in an interview that while the number of Russian students reached a peak in the mid-1990's, 27 of the school's 1,073 students still spoke Russian at home.
"Many Russians are highly educated and left good jobs, Mr. Neigel said, "and although it took time for them to get similar positions in the United States, they have moved up the economic ladder quickly." 
For instance, Mr. Lubavin's father eventually found work as an engineer in Springfield. Ms. Vaynshteyn's father and mother, dentists in Russia, now practice in Brooklyn.
And while the Kouliks were always light on their feet, dancing was not always their day job. In Moscow, Mr. Koulik was a neurosurgeon and his wife a university English teacher, professions they could not practice when they first arrived in America. Dance champions in Europe, they turned to ballroom dancing, first as instructors in Verona and later opening their own.
The first wave of Russian immigrants came in the early 1980's after the Soviet Union began easing Jewish immigration, the second in 1989 as it dissolved.
In northern New Jersey, the first stop for Soviet Jews was often Newark, said Rabbi Mendel Bogomilsky of the Chai Center for Living Judaism, an Orthodox congregation here. Many settled in a sprawling apartment complex in the Ivy Hill section, where his father, Samuel, the spiritual leader of Mount Sinai Temple, helped get them services, Rabbi Bogomilsky said. 
In addition, the Jewish Counseling and Service Agency, now known as the Jewish Family Service of Metro West, helped resettle many Soviet immigrants in the early 1980's, and one of its busiest offices was in Millburn. In the second wave, the agency resettled nearly 3,000, said Sheila Muster, the agency's director of operations.
"Those first people that came started working and as they prospered they moved to places like Springfield, West Orange, and Millburn-Short Hills," Ms. Muster said. As a result, the surrounding towns also have large percentages of Russians: West Orange, (5.8 percent) Livingston (9.8 percent) and Springfield (10.3 percent.) 
Rabbi Steven Bayar of Congregation B'nai Israel, a Conservative congregation here and one of many in the area that offered a support network for the newcomers, said many Russian families rented apartments in Millburn before they had enough saved to buy a house.
"We know families would move out of Millburn as soon as the kids were old enough, Rabbi Bayar said, "because they didn't need the high school anymore" -- nor the high cost of living.
Mr. Lubavin said when his family arrived in America nine years ago, an uncle in Livingston helped them to settle in a garden apartment complex across from the high school here along with many other Russians. To help make ends meet, his mother earned a degree from Kean University and found work as an accountant. Soon the family was able to buy a house in neighboring Springfield as Michael was finishing middle school here.
"The housing in Springfield was cheaper, and we wanted to buy a house," said Mr. Lubavin. 
Like the Lubavins, the Kouliks also found it more expedient to leave their small apartment in Short Hills for larger quarters in Springfield. "Vitali already graduated and we needed a little bigger place," Mr. Koulik explained.
These days, Ms. Vaynshteyn and her fiance can be seen gliding across the blond wooden floor of the Royal Ballroom as they try to master dance steps for their wedding reception in six months.
"We wanted a nice first dance," said Ms. Vaynshteyn. "Tanya is a great instructor, and she's very smiley and she's very encouraging. We need a lot of encouragement."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report; 
Upholding Both Islam And a Good Portfolio

BYLINE:  By ERIC BAUM 

 BODY:
IN many respects, the Amana Growth fund resembles scores of mutual funds that buy shares of fast-growing companies.
 But Amana Growth is different in at least one key respect. Introduced in 1986, it is the largest mutual fund in the United States that says it abides by Islamic principles of investing. 
 It avoids direct investments in banks, brokerage firms and insurance companies, for example, because lending money and the payment of interest are prohibited by the Koran, said Nicholas Kaiser, president of the Saturna Capital Corporation, the fund's adviser. "You don't want to be a borrower or a lender," Mr. Kaiser said. 
Islamic funds are a variation on socially responsible mutual funds, which screen out companies that engage in practices that their shareholders find objectionable, like harming the environment or producing alcohol or tobacco products or pornography. 
For the 12 months through Sept. 30, the fund, which has $22 million in assets, lost 18.6 percent. That was 1.5 percentage points better than the S.& P. 500. Over the last five years, the fund gained 1.5 percent, annualized, or 3.1 percentage points better than the index. Amana Growth is classifed by Morningstar as a large-cap growth fund.
Saturna Capital, based in Bellingham, Wash., also manages the Amana Income fund, which has $16 million in assets and was started in 1986, making it the country's oldest Islamic mutual fund. For the 12 months, it lost 19 percent, one point better than the S.& P. 500. Over the last five years, the fund lost 1.7 percent, annualized, one-tenth of a point better than the index. Mr. Kaiser said returns had been hurt by the prohibition against investments in financial services stocks, which have performed better than some other sectors.
Allied Asset Advisors in Burr Ridge, Ill., manages the Dow Jones Islamic Index fund, the second-biggest Islamic fund, with $18 million of assets. Weighted toward large-cap shares, it uses the trading symbol IMANX. "Iman means faith in Arabic, which is something we all need in the market right now," said Youshaa Patel, director for business development at Allied. The fund was down 30.4 percent this year through September.
The fund's top holdings, Exxon Mobil, Microsoft and Pfizer, are leading choices among large-cap funds generally. "When you look at some of our top 10 holdings, like Merck or Cisco, you may see some of the bellwethers that are driving our economy," Mr. Patel said. "One major goal is that you can still hold onto your beliefs and still be a prudent investor."
Most modern companies rely on debt financing, and Islamic scholars advising the Dow Jones Islamic Index and Amana have decided that a modest degree of debt is acceptable. The Dow Jones Islamic Indexes -- a series of 33 indexes containing at least 1,400 stocks -- filter out companies with debt-to-market capitalization ratios exceeding 33 percent during a trailing 12-month period. The Dow Jones Islamic US Index, on which the Allied fund is based, was established in 1999 and tracks 594 stocks, including Microsoft, Johnson & Johnson and Pfizer.
Amana has received similar advice from its Islamic advisers, the Fiqh Council of North America, Mr. Kaiser said. "If we went to the extreme and said no debt whatsoever, we would be left with no companies," he said. 
Azzad Asset Management, a small firm in Falls Church, Va., that runs two funds with a combined value of less than $1 million, said it took a similar approach.
Jibril Amin, a market and business analyst at the Ford Motor Company in Dearborn, Mich., is investing in Amana's funds to finance the college education of his three young children. He said combining Western finance and Islamic law is less than a perfect science. "They've accepted some companies that have limited exposure to debt," he said. "It's not a pure Islamic environment. Modern capitalism is based on something that is not perfectly consistent with what our beliefs are."
ISLAMIC screening has had some advantages for investors. Technology companies that crashed when the Nasdaq technology bubble burst were screened out when their debt levels exceeded 32 percent of their market capitalization. "The Islamic investor got out at 40 or 50, unlike other investors who rode the debt to zero," said Rushdi Siddiqui, director of the Dow Jones Islamic Indexes. 
Religious scholars note that Islam rejects the notion of placing one investor ahead of another, as is the case with preferred bondholders of a company who receive payments before common stockholders do, Mr. Kaiser said. In theory, Islam promotes investing relationships in which all parties are equity shareholders on equal footing. Amana restricts its holdings to common shares. "As long as the fund buys the common stock we're looking at ourselves as equals with all the other shareholders in the company," Mr. Kaiser said. 
Dow Jones is still wrestling with the question, and its Islamic scholars have temporarily subtracted a company's preferred shares from its debt ratio until there is a definitive answer. 
Some Muslims say they put their money in real estate, because it appreciates without earning interest, and in interest-free checking accounts to comply with Islamic principles. They say they do not invest in Islamic mutual funds because they do not know enough about them. 
"A lot of people are not investing because they think they will make some money in this life but lose the life hereafter," said Syed Ilyas, a physical therapist and the owner of a private clinic in Dearborn Heights, Mich. "I would love to invest, and I know dozens of people who are ready to invest right now. It's just a matter of finding an institution that is being backed up by reliable scholars."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jibril Amin, center, and his family in Dearborn, Mich. He said combining Western finance and Islamic law is not a perfect science. "They've accepted some companies that have limited exposure to debt," he said. (Jeffrey Sauger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: AROUND THE BLOCK; 
This Mercedes Wears a Mask And Flaunts Its Rubber Floor

BYLINE:  By CHERYL JENSEN 

 BODY:
 TESTED: 2002 Freightliner Sprinter

WHAT IS IT? -- Full-size commercial van.

HOW MUCH? -- $27,024 for cargo van with 118-inch wheelbase and standard roof; $36,065 as tested for passenger van with 140-inch wheelbase and high roof, including comfort package ($1,580) and rear air-conditioning ($1,405).

POWERTRAIN -- Rear drive; 2.7-liter 5-cylinder turbo-diesel (154 horsepower, 243 pounds-feet of torque); 5-speed "manumatic" transmission.

HOW HEAVY? -- 4,857 to 5,539 pounds.

HOW THIRSTY? -- Estimated average of 22 m.p.g. (E.P.A. figures not available for such a heavy vehicle.)

ALTERNATIVES: Ford Econoline E-350, $27,315; Chevrolet Express, $28,000.
DO you haul around more passengers than a shuttle bus at O'Hare International? Do you hate minivans? Do you love industrial-chic design? Do you dare to be different?
Step right up. The Freightliner Sprinter practically guarantees that you won't see yourself coming and going (unless you are delivering parcels in Midtown Manhattan). The Sprinter is an antidote to the minivan, and it comes from DaimlerChrysler, half of which put suburbanites into minivans in the first place.
Like a royal heir who lives unrecognized among peasants, the Sprinter has gone incognito: it is actually a Mercedes-Benz truck, and in Europe it wears the three-pointed star. But American market research found that plumbers and florists feared to drive a Mercedes, lest customers think they were overcharging. In the United States, the van currently bears the name of Freightliner, DaimlerChrysler's big-truck subsidiary.
So, yes, the Sprinter was designed more for commercial use than for suburban progeny-schlepping, but it resembles the basic airport van and it shouts "I am different!" when driven as a people mover. Based on reactions in the suburban cul-de-sac where my brother lives, it is likely to appeal to soccer parents deep in minivan denial. One neighbor liked the Sprinter so much that he lamented his recent purchase of a minivan.
Starting in January, a Sprinter with a different grille will also be sold in the United States as a Dodge. DaimlerChrysler hopes to break the hold that Ford has on the full-size van market with its Econoline and Club Wagon.
The Sprinter comes in three wheelbase lengths, two basic body styles (a passenger van with side windows and rear seats, or a plain-box cargo version) and two roof heights. I tested a passenger van with the intermediate 140-inch wheelbase and the high roof. This version is not only ungarageable, it looks like a garage. The outside height is a towering 102 inches, and a 6-foot-1 adult can stand up inside.
Four rows of seats accommodate 10 people in mess-resistant comfort. There is ketchup-proof rubber flooring and Slurpee-averse fabric seats. (The short-wheelbase Sprinter carries eight people in three rows.)
The steering wheel is big and buslike, but that is where the feel of driving a bus ends, partly because of the power-assisted rack-and-pinion steering. More important, the turning radius is extremely tight, making it ridiculously easy to squeeze into cramped Euro-style parking spaces or to maneuver in heavy traffic.
The small diesel engine -- the same one that powers the M-Class sport utility in Europe -- does a good job moving the heavy vehicle. I didn't drive one fully loaded, however.
My test van also came with a noise-cancellation feature. The squeaks and rattles from the rear cargo doors were so deafening that they could mask the sound of squabbling children. Paul DiLisio, a company spokesman, said the squeaking stemmed from a door seal that dries out and requires lubrication with silicone spray. (The squeaking persisted after I sprayed the seal.)
The biggest problem with the Sprinter is its stiff, industrial ride. And whenever I passed an airport I got a sense that it wanted to turn in.
Though the Sprinter is intended for commercial buyers, another DaimlerChrysler van from Europe, the Vito, will be aimed more directly at consumers. Due here in 2004, the Vito will be a bit smaller than the Sprinter and a little bigger than a minivan -- about the size of a Chevy Astro. Until the Vito arrives, adventurous families may find happiness with the Sprinter, a Mercedes so understated that it travels in disguise. CHERYL JENSEN

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report; 
Bond Funds for the Ultra-Impatient

BYLINE:  By JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:
THE once-obscure category of ultrashort-term bond funds is attracting new money, and for two reasons: Mutual fund investors -- their long patience with the faltering stock market severely strained -- see them as havens. And more fund companies, including Fidelity and Dreyfus, have recently begun to market the investments.
 The Investment Company Institute, the fund industry trade organization, reported that bond funds, both taxable and municipal, had a record inflow of $28.14 billion in July followed by an inflow of $17.31 billion in August; of the August total, $4.69 billion went to domestic short-term bond funds, including ultrashort funds, more than double the $1.95 billion inflow in July 2001. The August inflow included $3.02 billion in domestic short-term funds, down from $4.48 billion in July. 
 Generally, the term "ultrashort" describes funds with portfolio durations of a year or less, compared with as long as five years for short-term funds. Morningstar classifies as ultrashort some funds that are called short term by their sponsors.
As a group, ultrashort bond funds have returned 2.55 percent over the 12 months through Sept. 30. That is a percentage point above money market funds.
"Investors are seeking an upgrade," while trying to protect their capital, said Peter Crane, vice president of iMoneyNet Inc. of Westborough, Mass., and the managing editor of its Money Fund Report. 
Investors who are interested in ultrashort funds need to look at far more than total returns. Scott Berry, an analyst at Morningstar Inc., said that while some ultrashort funds were good alternatives to money market funds, others took on considerably more interest-rate and credit risk. While some funds are no-load, others have front-end loads, back-end loads or transactions fees, and after those costs investors could end up with a loss, as they could if interest rates move higher, he said. 
He favors using a money-market fund if you know you will need the money within a few months or a year, say, for a tuition payment, and using an ultrashort bond fund for a "rainy day." But in case you must use it, he said, the investment is still "relatively stable, relatively liquid." 
There is considerable variety in ultra-short funds. The Scudder Preservation Plus Income fund, for example, has a goal of a constant $10 share price and uses agreements with financial institutions to achieve it. It has no front-end or deferred load but has a 2 percent redemption fee. The Dreyfus Yield Advantage fund is no-load but has a 0.25 percent redemption fee, and the Fidelity Ultra-Short Bond fund, which began on Aug. 29, has no load but will charge a 0.25 percent fee on sales of shares held for less than 60 days. The Goldman Sachs Ultra-Short Duration Government fund charges a 1.5 percent front-end load and invests only in government and agency issues, giving it a rating of AAA.
Mr. Crane says the move toward ultrashort funds has been fueled by the long spell of low interest rates. With rates at 35-year lows, investors fear that they will inevitably move up and do not want to risk being hurt when that happens. Because long-term bonds are more sensitive to changes in interest rates, he said, people who hold them "could see double-digit losses if rates move up."
M. John Sterba, chairman of Investment Management Advisors of New York, said long-term investors should keep balanced portfolios of stocks, bonds and cash equivalents, rather than rushing to perceived safety. Still, he likes the Pimco Short-Term fund, which Morningstar categorizes as ultrashort, for short-term uses like paying a child's tuition for next year. He said the fund was also good for investors who are "so nervous they just can't sleep at night."
Wendy W. Cupps, an executive vice president at the Pacific Investment Management Company and its director of stable-value and short-term services, described Pimco Short-Term as "basically an enhanced money market fund." According to Morningstar, the fund yielded 1.69 percent for the 12 months through September, about six-tenths of a percentage point more than money markets. While money market funds keep a constant $1 net asset value, most ultrashort funds fluctuate slightly; that is the offset for the enhanced yield.
Ms. Cupps said the risk of Pimco Short Term was "very measured." The fund invests in securities with an average rating of AA and an average duration of 0.6 years. It has had only two negative months in the last 10 years, so investors who hold the fund for three months to a year are unlikely to experience any loss if they hold institutional or administrative class shares, which do not carry loads. 
But an investor who bought Class A shares, which have a 2 percent load, on Sept. 30, 2001, would be down 0.35 percent, according to Morningstar, while those who bought Class B shares, which have a deferred 5 percent load, would be down 3.01 percent if they bought them that day and sold on Sept. 30 this year.
Money that will not be needed for a while -- retirement savings, for example -- could earn higher returns in a longer-term fund like Pimco Total Return, Ms. Cupps said.
INDEPENDENT money managers agree that investors should not stage a wholesale retreat to ultrashort funds. 
Kurt Brouwer, president of Brouwer & Janachowski in Tiburon, Calif., who assembles fund portfolios for clients, said, "We use ultrashort funds when personal circumstances warrant it." For example, an investor wants to buy a house in a year or two, and has the money now. The ultrashort fund protects the principal until he is ready to buy.
People near retirement may also want to use ultrashort funds, Mr. Brower said, to stash 401(k) holdings until they are rolled over into an I.R.A. At that point, the account holder and adviser can decide how to invest the money.
Many 401(k) plans do not offer ultrashort or short-term bond funds, Ms. Cupps said, so investors wishing to follow that strategy may instead want to consider money market or stable-value funds, which aim to keep constant net asset values.
"We may see more being offered in 401(k)'s going forward," she said of ultrashort funds, given investors' current interest in them.

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
Wall Street Suffers; New York Winces

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
IN Houston, you'd be hard pressed to find someone who doesn't know at least a little about the oil business. Ditto in Detroit with the auto industry. And in Washington, people are so informed about the federal government that they know the difference between a deputy assistant under secretary and an assistant deputy under secretary.
 New York, of course, is different. It is perfectly possible to live in and around the five boroughs without having a clue about what's going on in what is probably city's most important industry. Unless you drive a "black car" for hire, or sold stogies in a now-defunct cigar bar or are yourself an investment banker, you may not realize just how dire things are on Wall Street. 
 Or you may not care. When every day seems to bring an indictment or allegation about evil-doing on Wall Street, when half of American households own stock and wish they didn't, when your retirement savings seems to have gone up in smoke, it may be hard to feel any interest in (much less sympathy for) anyone who works in the securities business.
And you may well not know anyone who works on the Street, at least directly. The good news, perhaps, is that Wall Street jobs account for less than 5 percent of employment in New York City.
And a recent study by Barbara Byrne Denham, chief economist of the newsletter New York STAT, found that the city has more than its fair share of many national industries, including advertising, apparel, legal, real estate and broadcasting.
But the business that is really concentrated here, that makes New York different from the rest of the country and from other big cities, is Wall Street. (Ms. Denham found that New York has a higher concentration of the nation's securities business than Los Angeles does of the movie business.)
Even before Wall Street analysts became less admired than telemarketers and journalists, there was criticism of their lavish paychecks. Just how lavish is clear from new data released by the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. The data shows that in New York State, people in the finance business made an average of almost $137,000 in 2001. No other industry in any state paid even close to that amount. The average salary in the United States, by the way, was slightly over $36,000; in New York, the average (which includes all these Wall Street types) was about $46,700.
So a Wall Street job is nice work if you can get it -- but you can't. There are already 18,300 fewer jobs on Wall Street than there were a year ago August, which just happens to have been the peak for employment in the securities business in New York.
And the outlook is bleak. This year is almost certain to be the third in a row that the stock market has fallen, the first three-year decline since 1939-1941. Last week the Standard & Poor's 500 index hovered about where it did in the spring of 1997 -- meaning that five years of investors' gains have been basically wiped out. For the technology-heavy Nasdaq, it's six years. The Dow Jones Industrial Average just had its worst September in 65 years.
Americans continue to pull money out of the stock market. Commission revenues are down, and Wall Street's own trading profits have plunged.
Wall Street's most profitable business, investment banking, has imploded, according to a new report from the Securities Industry Association, the brokerage business's trade and lobbying group. Stock offerings in August were at the lowest level in more than a decade, bond deals seem to be drying up, and the urge to merge has pretty much evaporated from corporate boardrooms.
Bottom line, Wall Street's profits are likely to be the lowest in seven years, maybe in eight, according to the association. The compensation securities firms pay their employees has fallen by about 36 percent since the first quarter of 2000 -- but revenues have fallen by 40 percent. The Securities Industry Association says its members need to cut compensation costs from 55 percent of net revenues to 50 percent.
And that means more layoffs.
You may not feel like shedding a tear for the soon-to-be unemployed guys who raked it in during Wall Street's boom. 
But "each job on the street supports slightly more than two jobs in the local economy," says Frank A. Fernandez, chief economist for the association. And covers an awful lot of restaurant tabs, bar bills, co-op maintenance payments and private school tuitions. And, of course, city taxes.

Graph tracks the Nasdaq Composite Index since 1999. ...has resulted in waning revenues in the security industry and job losses on Wall Street. HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF; 
An Old-School Mind Not Fooled by the New Economy

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. HERSHEY JR. 

 BODY:
WALL STREET these days often seems a place of utter venality in the service of executive greed. So it is refreshing to read of a successful American financier whose interests range far beyond making money. What's more, the self-effacing manner of that financier, Leon Levy, makes you wonder how he could have succeeded. Characteristically, he muses about this himself.
 "My own meager achievements," writes Mr. Levy, no doubt baffle new acquaintances. 
 "I can even sense the question forming in the person's mind," he says. "How does a guy who can't find his pipe when smoke is coming out of his pocket manage to do so well?' After talking to me awhile, I'm sure people are even more mystified and leave the conversation convinced that it must be luck, that the heavy lifting has been done by my partners, or that I'm due for a fall."
This is a man who, though nominally retired, predicted the current market meltdown years before it happened, drawing heavily on conceptions inherited from his father, Jerome, of how the economy works. It is corporate profits, he contends, that govern not only stock prices but economic performance as well.
Mr. Levy, who joined Oppenheimer & Company in 1951 as partner and research director, was a pioneer in mutual funds and leveraged buyouts. He particularly favored spinoffs and bankruptcies as he bet heavily to unlock hidden value. His most spectacular success was in developing the strategy for the revival of the thrice-bankrupt Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad in the late 1970's.
This memoir, "The Mind of Wall Street" (Public Affairs, $26), written with Eugene Linden and appearing in bookstores next month, is more illuminating than the typical blow-by-blow recounting of a lifetime of deals. It combines tales of encounters with flamboyant promoters like Bernard Cornfeld, who paid salesmen bonuses in shares of his Investors Overseas Services fund in the 1960's, with wry observations about the nature of man and markets.
Mr. Levy argues that psychology -- one of "two loves" of his life, the other being the stock market -- is still underappreciated as an investing force despite the recent emergence of what is called behavioral analysis, which elevates emotions as a determinant of stock prices. The stock market is less rational than long supposed, Mr. Levy said, which is why it can't be mastered with a system or neat theory. 
He criticizes the argument, made mostly by academics, that markets are so highly efficient that no one can outperform them consistently.
"Markets may be inherently unpredictable -- the efficient-market theorists are right about that -- but there are always clues in the actions of government and in the behavior of major economic actors that offer guidance for the attentive about developments that offer opportunities," he writes.
For lessons in patient and visionary investing, he scrutinized monthly reports on stock trades by two of the canniest businessmen he'd ever come across: J. Paul Getty and the virtually unknown Sy Scheuer, a financier. Mr. Scheuer's grand strategy, executed over many years, produced a fortune from West Virginia Coal and Coke.
The bull market of the 1990's, Mr. Levy said, was "collective madness," floating "almost entirely on illusions" that included bookkeeping sleight of hand, the acceptance of stocks as the only securities worthy of the savvy and the notion that a new economy could grow forever. Similar views could be found in the 1960's as well, but Mr. Levy points out that the Dow Jones industrial average advanced just one point, to 875, from 1964 to 1981.
He places part of the blame for the 90's bubble on the shoulders of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, who chose not to make it harder to buy stock with borrowed money and who supported legislation that gave banks more leeway to do business in the stock market.
But Mr. Levy is particularly hard on those he calls "overreachers," whom the market typically rewards for a spell but then inevitably punishes. 
He's not afraid to zing establishment peers like Felix G. Rohatyn, then a senior partner at Lazard, the New York investment bank, who, Mr. Levy said, used his privileged position to try to lure away Oppenheimer employees when Oppenheimer hired Mr. Rohatyn to broker the sale of the firm to Mercantile House in the early 1980's. 
On another occasion, Goldman Sachs signed on to defend the Trans World Corporation from a breakup promoted by Mr. Levy. Goldman had previously advised clients to buy Trans World stock on the grounds that the company's nonairline assets alone were worth more than its market capitalization. Mr. Levy calls the turnabout a precursor of the 1990's, "when events revealed with brilliant clarity whom investment bankers really represent."
NOT all of Mr. Levy's anecdotes are as amusing or pointed as he seems to hope, and the book is slightly marred by inattentiveness to the spelling of some names. In addition, he does not distinguish between percent and percentage points, calling a climb to 6 percent from 3 percent in the savings rate an increase of 3 percent; it is, in fact, 100 percent. The investment tips are useful, mainly eternal verities but with a sprinkling of the unorthodox: sell losers rather than winners, but don't obsess about portfolio rebalancing; get on the same side of a trend as the government and develop outside interests like, in his case, archaeology to provide perspective and to exercise imagination.
But those seeking stock market comfort won't get much from Mr. Levy. "My instincts, refined by 50 years of experience in finance, tell me that we are in but the third act of a five-act Shakespearean drama that portends a bad ending." he says, "Stock prices may have plummeted from their dizzying heights, but neither consumers nor investors have yet realized the perils of the suffocating pall of debt hanging over the financial world."
He also points to intensifying global competition and sees danger to a consumer-oriented economy in the inevitable rebuilding of depleted savings.
"Count on it," he said. "When the savings rate rises, my father observed, corporate profits fall." Slimmer profits mean less investment, fewer new jobs, more layoffs, depressed stock prices and perhaps even a reversal in the soaring price of real estate. 
Lately, he's bought euros.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Health Plans Are Offering Fewer Choices and Higher Costs

BYLINE:  By BETH KOBLINER 

 BODY:
SHALIA WATTS, a government employee from Sacramento, received some upsetting news in June: the health maintenance organization to which she belongs, Health Net, will no longer be available through her employer next year. At the same time, she said, she found that the monthly premium for the Blue Shield H.M.O. she chose as a replacement would be $110, almost double what she pays now. Co-payments for her prescription-drug plan already rose this year, she said, from $5 to a scale ranging from $10 to $30.
 "I'm starting to feel the financial pressure; it really adds up," said Ms. Watts, 48, who earns about $48,000 a year as a disability insurance program representative for the California Employment Development Department. 
 In addition to covering herself, Ms. Watts has two daughters, one of whom suffers from lupus, a chronic autoimmune disorder. She said the girl, Autumn, 12, was admitted to the hospital four times in the last year and required about 15 prescription medications daily, costing about $150 a month. "For someone who is in a lesser financial position, how would they be able to afford what I have?" she asked. "People are going to have to choose between eating or buying medication for their kids." 
Last week, the Census Bureau reported that 14.6 percent of the American population, or 41.2 million people, were without medical coverage in 2001. That was 1.4 million more than in the previous year.
This month starts another open enrollment period for the estimated 80 million Americans who participate in employer-sponsored health insurance plans. During October and November, employers will present workers with the changes in their health insurance offerings for next year and ask them to choose among the options. "There have been increased costs and significant changes in the way plans operate, so it's particularly important for employees to pay attention," said Richard Ostuw, a senior consultant at Towers Perrin, the human resources consulting firm.
Many workers, like Ms. Watts, will find fewer choices and higher costs, along with new options that reflect employers' moves to reduce costs and shift more responsibility for health care to their employees. "In 2003 we will see higher premiums, co-pays and deductibles," said Blaine Bos, a principal at Mercer Human Resources Consulting. "In 2004, we're likely to see more employers considering different types of plans that employees are currently not used to."
Workers are still digesting the 2002 increases. Employees are paying $2,084, on average, for family coverage, nearly $300 more than last year, according to a study conducted last spring and released in September by the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation, a nonprofit health care research group in Menlo Park, Calif., and the Health Research and Educational Trust, a research group in Chicago. Those with single coverage paid $454, about $100 more.
Employers' cost of providing coverage has risen sharply in the last few years, after a brief reprieve in health care inflation in the mid-1990's. The employer-paid premiums rose 12.7 percent this year, the highest annual increase since 1990 and the second consecutive year of double-digit increases, according to the Kaiser study. The average employer-paid premium is now $7,954 a family.
A survey released last week by Towers Perrin found that employers' health benefit plan costs would climb 15 percent next year, the biggest increase since the firm began conducting the study 13 years ago. The poll involed 268 large employers.
"Health care costs have gotten totally out of control and it's become clear that employers have to be even more active in sharing the burden with employees," said Wendy Rhodes, a consultant at Hewitt Associates, the benefits consulting firm. "Employees will have to face the music."
The portion of total premium costs paid by employees for family coverage has held steady at 27 percent in recent years, but that doesn't include the higher deductibles and co-payments for prescription drugs and doctor visits that employers have established to offset rising costs.
Many employers do not publicly announce increases in health insurance costs. But the California Public Employees' Retirement System, known as Calpers, which provides health benefits to California state employees, including Ms. Watts, announced last summer that its premiums would increase by 24 percent next year.
At the Boeing Company, unionized workers recently accepted a new contract that will significantly increase many employees' health care costs in 2004. Employees' premiums for family coverage on the most popular plan, a preferred provider organization, will jump to an estimated $197 a month in 2004 from the current $30. P.P.O. plans allow participants to seek care outside of a network, though at a higher cost than in-network doctors, and to see specialists without approval from primary care physicians.
"They are trying to force workers into the H.M.O. by making it too expensive to stay in the P.P.O.," said Connie Kelliher, a spokeswoman for District Lodge 751 of the International Association of Machinists, which represents 25,000 Boeing workers.
But Ken Mercer, a Boeing spokesman, said that "there are three other lower cost options, and employees can choose the one that best fits their needs." He said Boeing picks up a larger share of employee health care costs -- about 90 percent for unionized machinist and aerospace workers -- than most other companies. 
Generally, employees may have fewer H.M.O. choices this year. For instance, even though overall enrollment in H.M.O.'s rose slightly last year, employers are scaling back the number of plans they offer. This year, 61 percent of employees had a choice of more than one H.M.O. plan, down from 81 percent in 1998, according to data from the Kaiser survey.
Employees should make sure that their doctors still participate in particular plans. "If your family doctor is no longer in your P.P.O. network, for instance, you could end up paying the out-of-plan deductible, which will be more expensive," said Erin Holve, a senior policy analyst at the Kaiser foundation.
Many large employers are also offering voluntary "disease management" or "health promotion" programs to contain costs by helping employees with chronic conditions to avoid complications and hospitalization.
Bobby Marks, 46, a manager at Western Machinery in Kapolei, Hawaii, found out that he had diabetes two years ago and suffered a heart attack five months later. After five days in the cardiac intensive care unit, Mr. Marks was contacted by a patient advocate from the Hawaii Medical Services Association, a branch of Blue Cross Blue Shield, and was enrolled in a disease management program that provided telephone consultation with nurses. They counseled him in layman's terms about his condition, advised him on nutrition and checked blood sugar levels monthly. "I didn't know the difference between a carbohydrate and a calorie," he said, adding that he has not had any medical problems since entering the program.
A study released last winter by Johnson & Johnson found that the company saved an estimated $8.5 million a year from 1995 to 1999 by reducing the need for doctor and hospital visits for employees who signed up for its wellness program. The company said 90 percent of the company's employees, who were offered a $500 annual discount on their premiums to sign up, participated in the program.
Tiered pricing is another way for employers to shift costs and responsibility to employees for health care decisions. More than half of all covered employees now have three-tiered prescription drug plans to encourage the purchase of less expensive generic drugs. Under a typical plan, an employee makes a co-payment of $9 when buying generic drugs, $17 for name-brand drugs if no generic is available and $26 for the name-brand drug if the generic substitute is available.
A SMALL but growing number of employers -- covering roughly 5 percent of insured workers this year -- have expanded tiered pricing to doctor and hospital visits, according to the Kaiser survey. "If you need a routine operation, for example, and you choose to go to a specialty hospital instead of a community hospital, you will pay a much higher co-pay," said Dr. Donald Young, president of the Health Insurance Association of America, a lobbying group based in Washington.
A few other employers are also turning to "health reimbursement accounts" or "consumer driven" health plans, which shift some of the responsibility for managing costs to employees. Employees get a set amount of money to put into a health reimbursement account each year and to spend as they choose on health care. Once those funds run out, employees must meet deductibles that are usually higher than in traditional plans. (The Internal Revenue Service issued guidelines this year that allow employees to carry over unused cash to the next year.) 
Employers like the University of Minnesota and Raytheon began offering these types of plans as an option to their workers this year. Textron provides a consumer-driven plan as the sole plan for many of its employees. Several employers offering consumer-driven plans report that many employees find them cost-effective and like the sense of the control they offer. Some analysts, however, worry that such plans may be more expensive for chronically ill patients who use more health care services. 
Most analysts agree they are too new to evaluate fully. "They can be beneficial in giving employees more choice if they are offered in conjunction with a comprehensive health plan," said Phyllis Borzi, a research professor at the School of Public Health and Health Services at George Washington University Medical Center. "But some employees are afraid that they are being adopted mainly to shift costs and may be in the long run the first step in eliminating the employer's role in offering health insurance."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
In Search of Better Odds in Retirement Planning

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH HARRIS 

 BODY:
BEFORE Walt Huckabee, a retired engineer, buys mutual fund shares, he likes to take a test drive using a computer-based statistical technique known as Monte Carlo simulation.
 He contends that crunching numbers online, using a service available through his account at Vanguard, gives him a better sense of the range of possible financial returns for his investments, in good and bad markets. "It's the difference between theory and practice," said Mr. Huckabee, 60, of Placerville, Calif. 
 The bear market has made people like him look for more precise methods of assessing whether their portfolios will provide enough retirement income. Companies seeking independent advice to help employees invest for retirement have made Monte Carlo simulation widely available. 
The developers of Monte Carlo simulation warn that the technique is imperfect at best, but they say it helps display the range of possible returns more accurately than do other methods. 
Traditional financial projections generally assume a fixed annual compounded return, and fixed interest and inflation rates. Monte Carlo simulations, which use random numbers to imitate behavior, run investments through thousands of situations to assess the probability of reaching a financial goal. Calculations assume variations in inflation, interest rates and market returns based in part on history's wide range of returns, going back to the 1920's. 
The largest companies that generate Monte Carlo simulations for investors include Financial Engines of Palo Alto, Calif., Morningstar of Chicago and Fidelity Investments, the biggest mutual fund company. 
Financial Engines supplies online simulations to 20 financial institutions, including Vanguard, which generally make the techniques available free to their investors. Financial Engines also provides number-crunching services to 800 companies, including McDonald's and Occidental Petroleum, for their employees. Together, these investors number more than three million. 
Fidelity has made its Monte Carlo simulations available to 15 million customers. Investors may also get the services directly from Morningstar and Financial Engines.
Mathematicians developed the statistical technique in the 1940's, and it was used in thousands of calculations to develop the first atomic bomb in the Manhattan Project during World War II, said Christopher Jones, executive vice president for financial research and strategy at Financial Engines. 
As computer power has become cheaper, many professions have adopted Monte Carlo simulation to describe the behavior of complex systems. It is used to manage traffic, search for oil and determine proper doses for radiation cancer therapy. 
"It's useful where the problem you are studying is so complex, it's analytically very hard to determine the overall behavior of the system," Mr. Jones said.
William F. Sharpe, the chairman of Financial Engines and a Nobel winner in economics in 1990, began applying Monte Carlo simulations to individual investors' portfolios later in the decade. With Mr. Jones, he created a software recipe that mixes thousands of pieces of data by tracking 15 types of investments, or asset classes, like long-term government bonds or large-cap value stocks, with financial and economic factors like interest rate shifts and their effects on capital markets. Information about 20,000 stocks and mutual funds contributes in forecasting performance.
Because Monte Carlo simulation takes into account the inherent uncertainty of financial markets, Dr. Sharpe regards it as superior to other ways of gauging future performance -- like calculating a linear, or fixed rate of return. One such linear calculator, found on Quicken.com, tallies investment performance by assuming an annual average rate of return, like 8 percent, and projecting it forward. Monte Carlo simulations use more varied assumptions. All presume differing rates of return over time, but Morningstar's ClearFuture projects returns for entire asset classes, while Financial Engines projects returns for individual mutual funds and equities. 
 WHEN using an online Monte Carlo program, an investor saving for retirement enters information about when he wishes to retire, how much he has saved and what investments he owns. The results show potential outcomes based on the best, worst and most likely results.
For example, using Financial Engines, a 48-year-old investor with a $300,000 portfolio of stock and bond mutual funds who saves an additional $6,500 annually has an 83 percent likelihood of retiring with at least a $50,000 income at age 65 (including about $20,000 in Social Security income). The results of the calculation would be a range of outcomes, the most likely being $64,700. The calculation also indicates a 5 percent likelihood of hitting $103,000 a year, and an equal probability of receiving $42,100 a year.
With the Quicken calculator, the same investor would get one outcome. Using fixed projections, the investor would retire at 65 with an average income of $71,240, based on an 8 percent expected return and a 3 percent inflation rate. (That includes the same Social Security income.) 
"In the past, people were happy to project a linear model, but the problem with that is, it's linear," said Ray Martin, president of CitiStreet Advisors. "If you're projecting a 10 percent return, the problem is it has to be 10 percent. I call it a perfect 10 and there's no investment that even grows at a perfect 3 -- there's always variability."
Understanding variable market returns helped Mr. Huckabee, the retired engineer, reshape his portfolio. When he retired in 1998 as a system engineer at Lockheed Martin, he began to understand the risks of his growth-heavy 401(k) portfolio. Financial Engines calculations suggested that adding more value stocks would lower his risk; he says his portfolio has been beating the market. "I've been treading water in this downturn," he said, "but it's better than the significant declines you would have if you were just taking the total market approach."
But the Monte Carlo method has its critics. David Nawrocki, a finance professor at Villanova University, challenges the simulations' reliance on normal distributions, or results that resemble bell curves, when those are not typical in financial markets. 
"The probability results from Monte Carlo simulation may look impressive to a client," said Dr. Nawrocki, a consultant to PIE Technologies, a company that developed MoneyGuidePro, financial planning software. "However, if that number is derived from assumptions that are not realistic, there is no value to the number." He said he is working on alternatives. 
Dr. Sharpe acknowledges that market returns do not always mirror the pattern of a bell curve. So, he said, Financial Engines makes more complex assumptions and mixes in asymmetric patterns to mimic real life. "I don't see how anyone can be a critic of trying to project that there is uncertainty," he said. "If you're going to project anything like the complexity of the market, you're almost doomed to Monte Carlo rather than using analytic projections."
Andrew Clark, a senior research analyst at Lipper, points out that the calculations are based on limited financial market history. "From my standpoint, it is more of a learning tool -- it may give you a bounce, the top and bottom, but please do not take it as gospel," Mr. Clark said.
Chris Cordaro, chief investment officer at RegentAtlantic Capital, a wealth management firm in Chatham, N.J., says that while the approach does not yield precise predictions, it gives investors a more sophisticated picture. "There's no perfect forecasting tool, but Monte Carlo simulations are the best ones we have," Mr. Cordaro said. "At least you're demonstrating there's a probability for different returns, and we're at least acknowledging it's not going to come out perfectly."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report; 
Wisdom in Betting Against the Bulls

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
THE stock market's continuing slide pulled the returns of all stock mutual fund categories into negative territory in the third quarter, including sector funds and those that invest in overseas markets or that combine stocks and bonds in one portfolio. 
 Over all, the diversified domestic equity funds gave up 16.1 percent of their value, according to Morningstar Inc., while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 17.6 percent. 
 The list of top performers was dominated by bear funds intended to thrive during declines in the market by using strategies like shorting stocks -- selling borrowed shares in the hope of replacing them at lower prices. 
Managers of some of the more successful diversified funds that were open to new investors talked about their results, and what they saw ahead in the stock market.

Funds for the Short Term
The $208 million ProFunds UltraBear fund, which rose 33.8 percent, took first place among all domestic diversified stock funds for the quarter. It uses short sales, futures, options and other financial instruments to provide double the inverse return of the S.& P. 500.
"UltraBear is designed to perform well when the market goes down, and the fund did what it was supposed to do in the third quarter," said Michael L. Sapir, chief executive of ProFunds Advisors in Bethesda, Md. ProFunds manages about $2.5 billion, including 45 index mutual funds.
UltraBear is one of six of the company's index-based short funds, which should climb when the market declines -- and fall when it rises, making them unsuitable long-term investments for most people. The company's Bear fund is intended to return the inverse of the S.& P. 500. The ShortOTC returns the inverse of the Nasdaq 100 index, while UltraShortOTC doubles that inverse. ShortSmall-Cap returns the inverse of the Russell 2000 index, and Rising Rates Opportunity, 125 percent of the inverse of the most recently issued 30-year Treasury bond.
The bear funds can be used in two ways, Mr. Sapir said. Investors can buy shares to profit from expected market declines; UltraBear, because of its leverage, is particularly risky. Or they can use the fund to hedge, or protect, their portfolios.
But they shouldn't plan to hold too long. "We view the funds as short-term investments because, over the long term, we believe that the markets increase in value," Mr. Sapir said. Some investors hold shares for a month or so, others for up to a year.
The company also offers 16 long funds -- based on the S.& P. 500, the Dow Jones 30 industrials and other market indexes -- that let investors profit from a climbing market. Not surprisingly, several of these funds top the list of the quarter's biggest losers. ProFunds UltraOTC, which doubles the Nasdaq 100, lost 42.1 percent, while its sibling, UltraSmall-Cap, which doubles the return of the Russell 2000, lost 40 percent.

Bearish Since 1996
The $515 million Prudent Bear fund, which rose 17.5 percent for the quarter, placed second among actively managed diversified equity funds and ninth over all. The fund mostly shorts individual stocks to make money in declining markets, David W. Tice, the manager, said.
The fund tends to perform poorly when the market rises. For example, it lost 22.1 percent in the fourth quarter last year, when the S.& P. 500 was rising 10.7 percent.
Currently, the fund holds about 125 short positions in stocks and 75 long positions, about two-thirds of which are invested in shares of gold companies. Investors tend to flock to gold stocks as protection against a declining stock market.
"We've been bearish since 1996, when Alan Greenspan made his 'irrational exuberance' speech," Mr. Tice said. "That looks terribly early now, but it's very clear today that he was right and that's why we're in for such a long bear market."
Mr. Tice predicted that the bear market would last three to five more years. In the short term, he expects the market to move much lower, with the Dow Jones industrial average hitting 3,000 or so over the next 12 to 18 months. It closed on Sept. 30 at 7,591.93
"We believe that the excesses have to be worked off, and that we have to pay the price for so much debt," Mr. Tice said. "Consumers have driven the economy largely by accumulating too much credit, and the economy today is very unbalanced."
Among the fund's best performers in the quarter was a short position in J. P. Morgan Chase. "We felt that the credit quality would erode," Mr. Tice said, "and it did." 
Another short position, in Juniper Networks in Sunnyvale, Calif., also did well. The stock fell from a high of about $15 in early March, to below $5 in September, primarily because of declining sales created by the technology slump, he said. He would not confirm whether either short position was still open.
Among the fund's long positions, a big driver of its recent performance was Harmony Gold Mining of South Africa. The shares are traded on five international exchanges, including the Nasdaq, where they trade as American depository receipts. Mr. Tice paid $6, a share, on average; the stock closed the third quarter at $15.65.
"It's a very well managed company," Mr. Tice said. "And the stock went up in the quarter with the rest of the gold stocks.

Guarantees for Pessimists
 A series of four "target maturity" funds managed by Scudder Investments landed among the top 20 performers. Target maturity funds typically guarantee the return of capital to investors who reinvest all dividends and hold their shares to maturity. Scudder Target 2012, up 2.5 percent in the quarter, is the only one of the Scudder series on the top-performers' list that is open to new investors.
Over the five years through Sept. 30, the fund has had a gain of 3.3 percent, annualized. 
Some principal-protected funds use insurance to guarantee return of investors' principal. Scudder 2012, however, buys enough zero-coupon Treasury bonds to provide the guarantee, the company said. Zero-coupon bonds don't make interest payments; instead, investors buy the bonds at discounts to their face value and then redeem them at face value when they mature. The bonds account for about 65 percent of the fund's assets.
The balance of the fund typically is invested in large-company growth stocks, overseen by Kathleen Millard, the fund's lead portfolio manager. During the third quarter, however, the fund's return was driven by its bond holdings, overseen by Scott E. Dolan.
Over all, the zero coupons rose about 12 percent in the quarter, said Mr. Dolan, 36, because of declining interest rates. The five-year Treasury bond fell about 150 basis points, and the 10-year Treasury about 120 basis points since the end of June. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
"Because we don't rely on insurance, we used more fixed income, which benefited shareholders in the third quarter," Mr. Dolan said. "Fixed income has been a safe haven during this market environment. It clearly highlights the need for diversification among asset classes, not just in your stock portfolio."
