HEADLINE: MEDIA; 
Alternative Weeklies DivideTurf

BYLINE:  By DAVID CARR 

 BODY:
Stung by brutal competition and an even tougher economy, the raging rock throwers of alternative media are behaving like civilized monopolists, dividing up markets and cutting their losses.
 This became clear last week, when what had been a bare-knuckle fight to the finish by the nation's two largest chains of alternative weeklies -- New Times Inc. and Village Voice Media -- suddenly became a much more collaborative affair. 
 New Times agreed to shut down its money-losing Los Angeles New Times when Village Voice Media agreed to shut down its money-losing paper in Cleveland. New Times received more than $8 million from the two transactions, according to people with knowledge of the deal. 
The willingness of the two ferociously competitive chains to make a deal in their common interest could mean that the next big deal by the companies could leave only one standing.
The closings also raise the question of whether alternative weeklies are becoming pint-size versions of their daily counterparts -- print media franchises that need a monopoly in their respective markets to prosper. New Times lost more than $15 million battling Village Voice Media's more established LA Weekly, while Village Voice Media was losing more than $500,000 a year in Cleveland, with its Free Times.
Both chains, which each have revenues of around $100 million a year, have bought and closed competition in various markets in an effort to garner market share. New Times, which now owns 11 papers, bought and folded two struggling weeklies when it entered the Los Angeles market six years ago, but it never seriously threatened LA Weekly, a paper that had been around for 18 years.
"This fight was called on cuts," said Michael Lacey, executive editor of New Times Inc. "This was the wrong economy to be the second newspaper in a tough market."
The pullback by the two biggest players may be an indication that the industry, grounded in journalistic idiosyncrasy and independent ownership, could continue to consolidate to a point where most of the large papers are owned by a single entity. Both chains have borrowed heavily to finance their businesses. The financial hemorrhaging has stopped temporarily, but the value of collecting weeklies into competing chains is open to question.
Reed Phillips of DeSilva & Phillips, a media banking executive familiar with the weekly industry, does not see how becoming big helps a weekly publisher.
"The efforts at selling national ads have only been moderately successful," he said. "I am a little dubious about putting them all together. The history of most alternative weeklies is a single, strong personality who is stamped on that property."
Jane Levine, chief operating officer of The Chicago Reader, which also owns The Washington City Paper, agrees. "Maybe we're just dumb, but we have never seen the economies of scale. The two big costs in these business are paper and people, and I think it's tough to find the savings. The small amount of money you save doing those things does not offset the huge cost of money."
Since David Schneiderman, chief of Village Voice Media, organized the purchase of the company from Stern Media for a reported $165 million two years ago, the company has shed three of its nine papers.
But Mr. Schneiderman said he was not ruling out another acquisition. "If I thought it was a market I really wanted to be in -- the size of the market and the amount of time it would take were right -- I would do it," he said.
In an internal memo to the staff, Mr. Lacey and Jim Larkin, chief executive of New Times Inc., said they had little choice in their expensive battle against LA Weekly.
"New Times has invested tens of millions of dollars in our attempt to catch the LA Weekly, but their 18-year head start proved unassailable," they wrote. All employees were given severance, and Mr. Lacey said that most of the journalists from the Los Angeles New Times would work elsewhere in the chain.
Reached at a hotel in Santa Monica last week, Mr. Lacey said that the process of telling 60 people that worked at the Los Angeles New Times that their paper was disappearing made him physically ill. An award-winning journalist with a reputation for competitiveness and combativeness, Mr. Lacey was asked what part of it stuck in his craw.
"All of it," he said. "Every single bit of it."
During most of the 90's, alternative weeklies managed to counter the declining readership that was afflicting most newspapers and prosper.
There are 121 papers that are members of the Association of Alternative Newsweeklies, the industry's trade association, and they generate more than half a billion dollars in sales, according to Richard Karpel, executive director of the association.
That is a fraction of the $45 billion newspaper industry, but the industry as a whole was growing at a rate of 12 to 15 percent a year until recently, according to investment bankers who follow the sector.
But tobacco ads began to wither in 2000, and then national and classified ad sales fell over 20 percent in 2001, according to industry executives.
In the absence of that growth and with a lending market that has little enthusiasm for media properties, New Times and Village Voice Media needed to sacrifice money-losing papers to free up cash flow. 
"Sometimes, you have to cut off an arm to make the body stronger," said Mr. Karpel of the weekly association. "There is no doubt for newspaper people like Lacey, Larkin, and Schneiderman, this was about as fun as severing a limb."
In the short term, each organization gains additional financial strength for operations and potential expansion, but the banks and private equity firms backing the respective chains will expect to cash out within several years and one or both of the chains could be sold.
The economies of scale, which have not worked well with competing chains, might dictate a single large ownership, say people involved in the most recent deal.
Rick Barrs, editor in chief of the Los Angeles New Times, said the whole episode reminded him of an earlier period of Los Angeles newspaper history.
"It sort of reeks of the days of when the Chandlers were cutting deals with other papers," Mr. Barrs said. In 1962, the Chandler family, which then owned The Los Angeles Times, made a deal with the Hearst family, which then owned The Los Angeles Herald-Examiner, to shut afternoon and morning papers in Los Angeles to grant each other monopolies during different parts of the day.
"It's probably not a dumb idea," Mr. Barrs said of the decision to close the Los Angeles New Times. "I tried to be in denial about it, but we could never turn a profit. The sad part is I don't think anybody out there will be doing the kind of stories we were doing."

 BODY:
As Baby Bells Struggle, A Debate Over What to Do
Investors, lawmakers, regulators and consumers are debating what should be done with, or for, the Baby Bells, the large local phone carriers that are struggling with their first decline in customers since the Depression. The erosion is fueling talk of whether the government should step in.
 At the heart of the debate is regulation that forces Verizon Communications, SBC Communications, BellSouth and Qwest to sell access on their networks to competitors at prices that can be determined by state regulators. Market Place. Page C2.

HEADLINE: MEDIA; 
A Glut of Sept. 11 Books Cuts Into Sales

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
The anniversary of Sept. 11 may have prompted American publishers to produce more titles on a single subject in a single month than ever before, and the American consumer's appetite was quickly sated, according to publishers and booksellers interviewed this week.
 At the same time, the glut of books published around the anniversary of the World Trade Center attacks effectively shaved the month of September off the book industry's all-important fall season and left it in the grip of a post-anniversary sales letdown just when pre-Christmas momentum usually kicks in. 
 "The window for these books on the anniversary has been very small," said Sallye Leventhal, a buyer for Barnes & Noble, who said the nationwide chain of stores carried about 60 of the estimated 70 recently published titles tied generally or specifically to the trade center attacks.
Jeff Seroy, senior vice president for publishing and marketing at Farrar, Straus & Giroux, which published the best-selling collection of essays "Longitudes and Attitudes" by the New York Times columnist Thomas L. Friedman, said, "If you are not selling in the first few weeks of the book's life on a title like this, you are very unlikely to sell more later." 
A Borders executive said on Friday that stores are no longer expected to have front-and-center Sept. 11 displays, so managers who choose to are shelving all but the best sellers by traditional categories like autobiography, history or photography.
Overall sales figures for the anniversary titles are not available, but people in the industry said last week they thought that, except for top-selling books like Lisa Beamer's "Let's Roll!" written with Ken Abraham (Tyndale), consumers have bought less than half the copies printed. In a business whose sales patterns increasingly mimic those of the movies -- "we don't publish a book now; we open it, as it were," one executive said -- a slow start often means a quick trip to the remainder bin.
The falloff in interest can be seen in the most recent best-seller data. The New York Times best-seller list to be published on Oct. 13, based on data gathered through Sept. 28, shows four attack-related books among the top 15 sellers, down from 7 the previous week. There were 9 attack-related best sellers on the lists of Sept. 22 and 29, which were based on data gathered the week before the anniversary and the anniversary week itself.
The 60 or so books that never made it onto the list effectively limited each other by their sheer numbers, according to Nora Rawlinson, editor of Publishers Weekly. "That's inevitable," she said. "If you've got 5 books on a subject of strong interest, each one is going to sell better than if you have 30 on the subject." 
But David Rosenthal, executive vice president and publisher of Simon & Schuster, which published the best-selling book and DVD "What We Saw," by CBS News, said the glut was almost inevitable. "Everybody was inundated with proposals and material," he said. "It was a huge, cataclysmic event and everybody felt inclined to write and to package and to publish. And so we did."
Carole Horne, the buyer at Harvard Books in Cambridge, Mass., said that, while the glut of attack-related books came from a series of individual decisions, "to look at it collectively is strange -- that there was even a thought" that scores of books "would have a shot at being even somewhat successful."
She added: "For us, the books that seemed like anniversary books have by and large stopped selling. The books that were more political or historical, or had more than just this-is-a-year-later content, are still selling for us."
And with wide concern about war with Iraq, she said, her customers have a strong appetite for books on Saddam Hussein and his country.
John Sterling, president and publisher of Henry Holt, said that, after the publication of the last few current 9/11 books, like William Langewiesche's "American Ground," publishers will give the subject a rest for awhile. "I wouldn't be delighted with publishing anything on 9/11 in the next few months," he said.
With the Sept. 11 books fading, a new phenomenon has emerged, which the agent Amanda Urban of International Creative Management calls "best-seller-list gridlock." Many publishers, she and other industry executives said, held back their best non-attack-related prospects, reasoning that no broadcast airtime would be given to any subject other than the anniversary during much of September.
"The prevailing feeling at the moment is that the further away you are from 9/11, the better shot you have," Ms. Urban said.
Susan Yeager, associate director of merchandising for Borders Books, said publishers wanted to "wait for a chance to focus the customer's attention" on new subjects.
So new books by authors like Stephen King and Nicholas Sparks have been crowded into a smaller pre-Christmas season and are now fighting each other for space in book reviews and on store shelves, a situation as unusual as three summer blockbuster movies hitting the multiplexes the same weekend. 
And whether because of a post-Sept. 11 lull in sales, or because of the slumping economy, "the sales, the season, is soft for everybody," Mr. Rosenthal of Simon & Schuster said.

Other new books were delayed and are now competing in some places for space. (Chris Maynard)

HEADLINE: J. P. Morgan Plans Job Cuts Up to 4,000, Executives Say 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN with RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
J. P. Morgan Chase is planning to cut as many as 4,000 employees, including many managing directors, from its investment banking operation over the next several weeks, executives with the firm said yesterday.
 The executives said that William B. Harrison, J. P. Morgan's chief executive, had instructed his top lieutenants several weeks ago to draft lists of possible candidates to be dismissed and has now directed them to be ready to lay off 10 percent to 25 percent of certain groups within the firm. J. P. Morgan has some 20,000 employees worldwide. 
 The layoff plan comes after the bank's warning last month that its third-quarter results would be worse than been expected, in part, because of bad loans to telecommunications companies and weak trading results. 
The bank said that write-offs and additional reserves against potential losses on loans to companies would rise to $1.4 billion in the third quarter. That would be a sharp increase from $302 million in the second quarter. It said it had trading revenue of $100 million in July and August, compared with $1.1 billion for the full previous quarter. 
Mr. Harrison had indicated earlier that he planned to trim some of the staff, though he did not say how deep the cuts would be. 
"We have to see how much expenses we can take out without cutting into the bone," he said, explaining how he wanted to avoid damaging the banks competitive position when the economy recovers. The company has cut 10,000 jobs, double what it originally expected, since the merger of J. P. Morgan and Chase was announced in September 2000. 
According to the executives within the firm, most of the job cuts will come from the bank's mergers and acquisitions group, equity and debt underwriting operations, asset management and private banking. Those areas have been hard hit by the decline in the economy in the last two years. Most of the layoffs are expected to come from operations in New York and Asia, the executives said. J. P. Morgan's European operations, which have held up best, will be relatively unaffected, the executives said.
A spokesman for J. P. Morgan declined to comment.
Across Wall Street, new lists of possible layoff candidates are being drawn up as banks try to pare down costs before the end of the year, one of the most dismal in decades. Some 60,000 people on Wall Street have lost their job in the last two years.
Top managers at Merrill Lynch have begun reviewing a list of nearly 1,000 employees who could be laid off, according to executives at the firm. 
At Goldman Sachs, David Viniar, its chief financial officer, said last month that it would again make another round of cuts. Analysts estimate Goldman could cut 4 percent of its staff or 800 jobs. Some banks, like Lehman Brothers Holdings, are taking a different tack by paying smaller bonuses to avoid broad layoffs.

HEADLINE: Publisher of Fitness Magazines Is for Sale 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CARR 

 BODY:
Weider Publications, a niche publisher of fitness and body-building magazines, is for sale, two bankers who expect to be involved in bids said.
 Bids will be accepted beginning today for the 63-year-old family-owned publisher. The auction is expected to bring several substantial offers. 
 The company, based in Woodland Hills, Calif., was started in 1939 by the co-founders of the Mr. Olympia contest, Joe and Ben Weider. It employs about 325 people who produce seven magazines -- including Men's Fitness and Shape -- with a total circulation of more than four million.
One potential bidder, who declined to be identified, described the company as "a classic special-interest publisher." He added, "It has been an excellent property for a number of years. There are tons of financial players who have gotten killed in telecom and they want to get into something that has cash flow, which Weider has."
The parent company, Weider Health and Fitness, also owns the publicly traded Weider Nutrition International, which sells nutritional supplements, sports drinks and energy bars. That division will not be part of the sale.
The publishing unit is estimated to have annual revenue of $130 million. One potential bidder said that the division could attract as much as $250 million, but other bidders believe the current economic conditions could take the sales figure much lower.
The company did not return calls for comment, but potential bidders suggested the company is selling the publishing unit because Joe Weider, founder and chairman, who is around 80 years old, wants to leave publishing.
Most of the bidders are expected to be financial players, in part because the endemic mix of muscle-building powders and supplements ads are seen as too marginal to fit strategically with existing magazine companies.
The company's consumer-oriented magazines like Men's Fitness and Shape could be attractive to consumer magazine publishers, but some of the companies that have shopped for magazines in the past, like Primedia and Gruner & Jahr USA, are busy digesting purchases they have already made. In March 2001, Gruner & Jahr USA acquired Jump, Weider's teenager-oriented magazine and folded it into YM, its own publication.
"The whole category of health and fitness is doing well," said Chip Block, vice chairman of USA Pubs Inc., a direct marketing company. "Weider is right in the middle of the category, so if they are for sale, I think there will be a great deal of interest. There haven't been viable auctions on consumer-magazine properties for some time and there is plenty of cash around to buy them. And there are plenty of logical, strategic buyers."
Weider's top publication, Shape, a women's fitness magazine, has been something of a juggernaut. Its circulation has grown from 950,000 in 1997 to 1.7 million for the first six months of this year. Ad pages, year to date, are up 10 percent, according to the Publishers Information Bureau.
Weider's next largest title, Men's Fitness, has a circulation of about 635,000 readers, more than double its circulation in 1997. Ad pages at the magazine are up 7 percent so far this year compared with the period last year, according to the bureau.
